   <h1 class="firstHeading" id="firstHeading" lang="en">
    Plug-in hybrid
   </h1>
   <div class="mw-body-content" id="bodyContent">
    <div id="siteSub">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div>
    <div id="contentSub">
    </div>

     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:DCA_06_2012_Chevy_Volt_4035.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1300" data-file-width="1950" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/DCA_06_2012_Chevy_Volt_4035.JPG/290px-DCA_06_2012_Chevy_Volt_4035.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/DCA_06_2012_Chevy_Volt_4035.JPG/435px-DCA_06_2012_Chevy_Volt_4035.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/DCA_06_2012_Chevy_Volt_4035.JPG/580px-DCA_06_2012_Chevy_Volt_4035.JPG 2x" width="290"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:DCA_06_2012_Chevy_Volt_4035.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
         Chevrolet Volt
        </a>
        is the world's all-time top selling plug-in hybrid. Global combined Volt/Ampera family sales passed the 100,000 unit milestone in October 2015.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt100K_1-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Volt100K-1">
          [1]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top2015Global_2-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Top2015Global-2">
          [2]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>

     <p>
      A
      <b>
       plug-in hybrid
      </b>
      electric vehicle (PHEV) is a
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
       hybrid electric vehicle
      </a>
      that uses
      <a href="/wiki/Rechargeable_battery" title="Rechargeable battery">
       rechargeable batteries
      </a>
      , or another energy storage device, that can be recharged by plugging it in to an external source of
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_power" title="Electric power">
       electric power
      </a>
      . A PHEV shares the characteristics both of a conventional hybrid electric vehicle, having an
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_motor" title="Electric motor">
       electric motor
      </a>
      and an
      <a href="/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine" title="Internal combustion engine">
       internal combustion engine
      </a>
      (ICE), and of an
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_vehicle" title="All-electric vehicle">
       all-electric vehicle
      </a>
      , having a
      <a href="/wiki/AC_power_plugs_and_sockets" title="AC power plugs and sockets">
       plug
      </a>
      to connect to the
      <a href="/wiki/Electrical_grid" title="Electrical grid">
       electrical grid
      </a>
      . Most PHEVs are passenger cars but there are also PHEV versions of commercial vehicles and vans, utility trucks, buses, trains, motorcycles,
      <a href="/wiki/Scooter_(motorcycle)" title="Scooter (motorcycle)">
       scooters
      </a>
      , and military vehicles.
     </p>
     <p>
      The cost of electricity to power plug-in hybrids for
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric operation
      </a>
      has been estimated at less than one quarter of the cost of
      <a href="/wiki/Gasoline" title="Gasoline">
       gasoline
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">
       California
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hevctr_3-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-hevctr-3">
        [3]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Compared to conventional vehicles, PHEVs produce less
      <a href="/wiki/Air_pollution" title="Air pollution">
       air pollution
      </a>
      locally and require less
      <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">
       petroleum
      </a>
      . PHEVs may produce less in the way of
      <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">
       greenhouse gases
      </a>
      , which contribute to
      <a href="/wiki/Global_warming" title="Global warming">
       global warming
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-epri07_4-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-epri07-4">
        [4]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Argonne_5-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Argonne-5">
        [5]
       </a>
      </sup>
      than conventional vehicles do. PHEVs also eliminate the problem of
      <a href="/wiki/Range_anxiety" title="Range anxiety">
       range anxiety
      </a>
      associated with all-electric vehicles, because the combustion engine works as a backup when the batteries are depleted, giving PHEVs driving-range comparable to that of other vehicles that have gasoline and diesel tanks.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-6">
        [6]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boschert06_7-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Boschert06-7">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HotFlat_8-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-HotFlat-8">
        [8]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Plug-in hybrids use no
      <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">
       fossil fuel
      </a>
      at the point of use during their
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Plug-in hybrids greenhouse-gas emissions, during the operating in the all-electric range mode, depends on the type of power plant used to feed the electrical grid when the battery is charged.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-9">
       <a href="#cite_note-9">
        [9]
       </a>
      </sup>
      (See "
      <a href="#Greenhouse_gas_emissions">
       Greenhouse gas emissions
      </a>
      ", below.) If the batteries are charged directly from renewable sources off the electrical grid, then the tailpipe greenhouse gas emissions are zero when running only on battery power. Other benefits include improved national
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_security" title="Energy security">
       energy security
      </a>
      , less frequent fill-ups at the
      <a href="/wiki/Filling_station" title="Filling station">
       filling station
      </a>
      , the convenience of home recharging, opportunities to provide
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Emergency_backup_power" title="Emergency backup power">
       emergency backup power
      </a>
      in the home, and
      <a href="/wiki/Vehicle-to-grid" title="Vehicle-to-grid">
       vehicle-to-grid
      </a>
      (V2G) applications.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cba_10-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-cba-10">
        [10]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RSC_11-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RSC-11">
        [11]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Several countries, including the United States, China, and several European countries, have enacted laws to ease the introduction of PHEVs through
      <a href="/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles" title="Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles">
       grants and tax credits
      </a>
      , emissions mandates, and financing research and development in advanced batteries and related technology.
     </p>
     <p>
      Chinese battery manufacturer and automaker
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Auto" title="BYD Auto">
       BYD Auto
      </a>
      released the
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_F3DM" title="BYD F3DM">
       F3DM
      </a>
      to the Chinese fleet market in December 2008
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-F3DM_12-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-F3DM-12">
        [12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bwf3dm_13-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-bwf3dm-13">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC1208_14-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC1208-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and began sales to the public in
      <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">
       Shenzhen
      </a>
      in March 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC0310_15-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC0310-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edmunds310_16-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Edmunds310-16">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">
       General Motors
      </a>
      began delivering the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      in the United States in December 2010; it was the first electric car with a range extender for retail sale in the American market.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt1stDelivery_17-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt1stDelivery-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of February 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , there are over 25 models of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_production" title="Series production">
       series-production
      </a>
      highway legal plug-in hybrids for retail sales, including some
      <a href="/wiki/Production_vehicle#Limited_production_cars" title="Production vehicle">
       limited-production
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Luxury_vehicle" title="Luxury vehicle">
       luxury
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sport_car" title="Sport car">
       sport cars
      </a>
      . Plug-in hybrid cars are available mainly in the United States, Canada,
      <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">
       Western Europe
      </a>
      , Japan, and China. As of June 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt_family" title="Chevrolet Volt family">
       Chevrolet Volt family
      </a>
      , including its siblings Opel/Vauxhall Ampera, is the world's all-time best-selling plug-in hybrid with combined sales of over 117,000 units. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Outlander_P-HEV" title="Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV">
       Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV
      </a>
      is the world's second top-selling plug-in hybrid, with global sales of about 107,000 units, followed by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_PHV" title="Toyota Prius PHV">
       Toyota Prius PHV
      </a>
      , with over 75,000 units delivered globally.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TopPEV062016_18-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TopPEV062016-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      As of December 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the global stock of highway-capable plug-in hybrid electric cars totaled over 517,000 units, out of total cumulative global sales of 1.257 million light-duty
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlook2016_19-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlook2016-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of December 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the United States is the world's largest plug-in hybrid car market with a stock of 193,770 units, followed by China with 86,580 vehicles, the Netherlands with 78,160, Japan with 55,470 units, and the UK with 28,250.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlook2016_19-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlook2016-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Flexibility in power demand, diverse usage patterns and storage capability of PHEVs grow the elasticity of residential electricity demand remarkably. This elasticity can be used to form the daily aggregated demand profile and/or alter instantaneous demand of a system wherein a large number of residential PHEVs share one electricity retailer.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20">
       <a href="#cite_note-20">
        [20]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21">
       <a href="#cite_note-21">
        [21]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22">
       <a href="#cite_note-22">
        [22]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
     </p>

     <p>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Terminology">
       Terminology
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Terminology">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HybridsPlusPriusBatteries.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="864" data-file-width="1152" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/HybridsPlusPriusBatteries.jpg/220px-HybridsPlusPriusBatteries.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/HybridsPlusPriusBatteries.jpg/330px-HybridsPlusPriusBatteries.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/HybridsPlusPriusBatteries.jpg/440px-HybridsPlusPriusBatteries.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HybridsPlusPriusBatteries.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Hybrids_Plus" title="Hybrids Plus">
         Hybrids Plus
        </a>
        plug-in hybrid
        <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
         Toyota Prius
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_conversion" title="Electric vehicle conversion">
         conversion
        </a>
        with PHEV-30 (30 mile or 48 km
        <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
         all-electric range
        </a>
        ) battery packs
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      A plug-in hybrid's
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      is designated by PHEV-
      <i>
       [miles]
      </i>
      or PHEV
      <i>
       [kilometers]
      </i>
      km in which the number represents the distance the vehicle can travel on battery power alone. For example, a PHEV-20 can travel twenty miles (32 km) without using its combustion engine, so it may also be designated as a PHEV32km.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reduct_23-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-reduct-23">
        [23]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_Independence_and_Security_Act_of_2007" title="Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007">
       Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007
      </a>
      defines a plug-in electric drive vehicle as a vehicle that:
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/draw" title="wikt:draw">
        draws
       </a>
       motive power from a battery with a capacity of at least 4
       <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt_hour" title="Kilowatt hour">
        kilowatt hours
       </a>
       ;
      </li>
      <li>
       can be recharged from an external source of electricity for motive power; and
      </li>
      <li>
       is a light-, medium-, or heavy-duty
       <a href="/wiki/Motor_vehicle" title="Motor vehicle">
        motor vehicle
       </a>
       or
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nonroad_vehicle" title="Nonroad vehicle">
        nonroad vehicle
       </a>
       .
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      This distinguishes PHEVs from
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Regular_hybrid" title="Regular hybrid">
       regular hybrid
      </a>
      cars
      <a href="/wiki/Mass_market" title="Mass market">
       mass marketed
      </a>
      today, which do not use any electricity from the grid.
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Electrical_and_Electronics_Engineers" title="Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers">
       Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers
      </a>
      (IEEE) defines PHEVs similarly, but also requires that the
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
       hybrid electric vehicle
      </a>
      be able to drive at least ten miles (16 km) in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      (PHEV-10; PHEV16km), while consuming no
      <a href="/wiki/Gasoline" title="Gasoline">
       gasoline
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Diesel_fuel" title="Diesel fuel">
       diesel fuel
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24">
       <a href="#cite_note-24">
        [24]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/California_Air_Resources_Board" title="California Air Resources Board">
       California Air Resources Board
      </a>
      uses the term "off-vehicle charge capable" (OVCC) to mean having the capability to charge a battery from an off-vehicle electric energy source that cannot be connected or coupled to the vehicle in any manner while the vehicle is being driven.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25">
       <a href="#cite_note-25">
        [25]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Other popular terms sometimes used for plug-in hybrids are "grid-connected hybrids", "Gas-Optional Hybrid Electric Vehicle" (GO-HEV) or simply "gas-optional hybrids".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26">
       <a href="#cite_note-26">
        [26]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27">
       <a href="#cite_note-27">
        [27]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28">
       <a href="#cite_note-28">
        [28]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">
       General Motors
      </a>
      calls its
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
       series
      </a>
      plug-in hybrid an "Extended-Range Electric Vehicle".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RSC_11-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-RSC-11">
        [11]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29">
       <a href="#cite_note-29">
        [29]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="History">
       History
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: History">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/History_of_plug-in_hybrids" title="History of plug-in hybrids">
       History of plug-in hybrids
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Felix-car-batteries-full.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1944" data-file-width="2592" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Felix-car-batteries-full.jpg/220px-Felix-car-batteries-full.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Felix-car-batteries-full.jpg/330px-Felix-car-batteries-full.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Felix-car-batteries-full.jpg/440px-Felix-car-batteries-full.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Felix-car-batteries-full.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery" title="Lithium-ion battery">
         Lithium-ion battery
        </a>
        pack, with cover removed, in a
        <a href="/wiki/CalCars" title="CalCars">
         CalCars
        </a>
        "PRIUS+" plug-in hybrid converted
        <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
         Toyota Prius
        </a>
        converted by EnergyCS.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:CalCars_Plug_ins_August_2007.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/CalCars_Plug_ins_August_2007.jpg/220px-CalCars_Plug_ins_August_2007.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/CalCars_Plug_ins_August_2007.jpg/330px-CalCars_Plug_ins_August_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/CalCars_Plug_ins_August_2007.jpg/440px-CalCars_Plug_ins_August_2007.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:CalCars_Plug_ins_August_2007.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Several plug-in hybrid converted
        <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
         Toyota Prius
        </a>
        at
        <a href="/wiki/Professorville" title="Professorville">
         Professorville
        </a>
        ,
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Palo_Alto" title="Palo Alto">
         Palo Alto
        </a>
        . The right side car is a Prius + converted by
        <a href="/wiki/CalCars" title="CalCars">
         CalCars
        </a>
        with a
        <a href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles" title="Fuel economy in automobiles">
         fuel economy
        </a>
        of over 100
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon" title="Miles per gallon">
         miles per gallon
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Invention_and_early_interest">
       Invention and early interest
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Invention and early interest">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lohner-Porsche_Mixte_Hybrid" title="Lohner-Porsche Mixte Hybrid">
       Lohner-Porsche Mixte Hybrid
      </a>
      , produced as early as 1899, was the first
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_car" title="Hybrid electric car">
       hybrid electric car
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HybridCarHist_30-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-HybridCarHist-30">
        [30]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31">
       <a href="#cite_note-31">
        [31]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Early hybrids could be charged from an external source before operation. However, the term "plug-in hybrid" has come to mean a hybrid vehicle that can be charged from a standard electrical wall socket. The term "plug-in hybrid electric vehicle" was coined by
      <a href="/wiki/University_of_California,_Davis" title="University of California, Davis">
       UC Davis
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dr._Andrew_Alfonso_Frank" title="Dr. Andrew Alfonso Frank">
       Professor Andrew Frank
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32">
       <a href="#cite_note-32">
        [32]
       </a>
      </sup>
      who has been called the "father of the modern plug-in hybrid."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33">
       <a href="#cite_note-33">
        [33]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34">
       <a href="#cite_note-34">
        [34]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Plug_in_35-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Plug_in-35">
        [35]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The July 1969 issue of
      <i>
       <a href="/wiki/Popular_Science" title="Popular Science">
        Popular Science
       </a>
      </i>
      featured an article on the
      <a href="/wiki/General_Motors_XP-883" title="General Motors XP-883">
       General Motors XP-883
      </a>
      plug-in hybrid. The concept commuter vehicle housed six
      <span class="nowrap">
       12-volt
      </span>
      lead–acid batteries in the trunk area and a transverse-mounted DC electric motor turning a front-wheel drive. The car could be plugged into a standard North American 120 volt AC outlet for recharging.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36">
       <a href="#cite_note-36">
        [36]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Revival_of_interest">
       Revival of interest
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: Revival of interest">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In 2003,
      <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">
       Renault
      </a>
      began selling the
      <a href="/wiki/Elect%27road" title="Elect'road">
       Elect'road
      </a>
      , a plug-in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
       series hybrid
      </a>
      version of their popular
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kangoo" title="Kangoo">
       Kangoo
      </a>
      , in Europe. It was sold alongside Renault's "Electri'cité" electric-drive Kangoo battery electric van. The Elect'road had a 150 km (93 mi) range using a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nickel-cadmium_battery" title="Nickel-cadmium battery">
       nickel-cadmium battery
      </a>
      pack and a 500
      <a href="/wiki/Cubic_centimetre" title="Cubic centimetre">
       cc
      </a>
      (31
      <a href="/wiki/Cubic_inch" title="Cubic inch">
       cu in
      </a>
      ),
      <span class="nowrap">
       16 kilowatt
      </span>
      liquid-cooled gasoline "range-extender" engine. It powered two high voltage/high output/low volume alternators, each of which supplied up to
      <span class="nowrap">
       5.5 kW
      </span>
      at
      <span class="nowrap">
       132 volts
      </span>
      at
      <span class="nowrap">
       5000 rpm
      </span>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kangoo_37-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-kangoo-37">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The operating speed of the internal combustion engine—and therefore the output delivered by the generators—varied according to demand. The fuel tank had a capacity of 10 liters (2.6 U.S. gal; 2.2 imp gal) and was housed within the right rear wheel arch. The range extender function was activated by a switch on the dashboard. The on-board
      <span class="nowrap">
       3.5 kilowatt
      </span>
      charger could charge a depleted battery pack to 95% charge in about four hours from a
      <span class="nowrap">
       240 volts
      </span>
      supply.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-38">
       <a href="#cite_note-38">
        [38]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Passenger compartment heating was powered by the battery pack as well as an auxiliary coolant circuit that was supplied by the range extender engine. After selling about 500 vehicles, primarily in France, Norway and the UK, at a price of about €25,000,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kangoo_37-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-kangoo-37">
        [37]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the Elect'road was redesigned in 2007.
     </p>
     <p>
      In September 2004,
      <a href="/wiki/CalCars" title="CalCars">
       CalCars
      </a>
      converted a 2004 Toyota Prius into a prototype of what it called the PRIUS+. With the addition of
      <span class="nowrap">
       130 kg
      </span>
      (
      <span class="nowrap">
       300 lb
      </span>
      ) of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lead%E2%80%93acid_batteries" title="Lead–acid batteries">
       lead–acid batteries
      </a>
      , the PRIUS+ achieved roughly double the fuel economy of a standard Prius and could make trips of up to 15 km (9 mi) using only electric power. The vehicle, which is owned by CalCars technical lead Ron Gremban, is used in daily driving, as well as a test bed for various improvements to the system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-priusplus_39-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-priusplus-39">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On July 18, 2006,
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">
       Toyota
      </a>
      announced that it "plans to develop a hybrid vehicle that will run locally on batteries charged by a household electrical outlet before switching over to a gasoline engine for longer hauls."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-toyota_40-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-toyota-40">
        [40]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In April 2007 Toyota said it planned to migrate to
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithium-ion_batteries" title="Lithium-ion batteries">
       lithium-ion batteries
      </a>
      in future hybrid models,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41">
       <a href="#cite_note-41">
        [41]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but not in the 2009 model year Prius.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-halvorson_42-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-halvorson-42">
        [42]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Lithium-ion batteries are expected to significantly improve fuel economy, and have a higher energy-to-weight ratio, but cost more to produce, and raise safety concerns due to high operating temperatures.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-halvorson_42-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-halvorson-42">
        [42]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On November 29, 2006, GM announced plans to introduce a production plug-in hybrid version of
      <a href="/wiki/Saturn_Vue" title="Saturn Vue">
       Saturn's Greenline Vue SUV
      </a>
      with an all-electric range of 10 mi (16 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gm_43-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-gm-43">
        [43]
       </a>
      </sup>
      GM announced in January 2007 that contracts had been awarded to two companies to design and test lithium-ion batteries for the vehicle
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44">
       <a href="#cite_note-44">
        [44]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but the Saturn line was discontinued before the hybrid Vue could be released. GM has said that they plan on introducing plug-in and other hybrids "for the next several years".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gm_43-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-gm-43">
        [43]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bush-feb07.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="366" data-file-width="515" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Bush-feb07.jpg/220px-Bush-feb07.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Bush-feb07.jpg/330px-Bush-feb07.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Bush-feb07.jpg/440px-Bush-feb07.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bush-feb07.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">
         President Bush
        </a>
        with
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A123Systems" title="A123Systems">
         A123Systems
        </a>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CEO" title="CEO">
         CEO
        </a>
        on the
        <a href="/wiki/South_Lawn_(White_House)" title="South Lawn (White House)">
         White House South Lawn
        </a>
        examining a
        <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
         Toyota Prius
        </a>
        converted to plug-in hybrid with
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hymotion" title="Hymotion">
         Hymotion
        </a>
        technology.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In January 2007, GM unveiled the
      <a href="/wiki/Prototype" title="Prototype">
       prototype
      </a>
      of the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      , which was expected to feature a plug-in capable, battery-dominant
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
       series hybrid
      </a>
      architecture called E-Flex.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45">
       <a href="#cite_note-45">
        [45]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Future E-Flex plug-in hybrid vehicles may use gasoline, diesel, or hydrogen fuel cell power to supplement the vehicle's battery. General Motors envisions an eventual progression of E-Flex vehicles from plug-in hybrids to pure electric vehicles, as battery technology improves.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46">
       <a href="#cite_note-46">
        [46]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On July 25, Japan's
      <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Land,_Infrastructure,_Transport_and_Tourism" title="Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism">
       Ministry of Land, Infrastructure and Transport
      </a>
      certified Toyota's plug-in hybrid for use on public roads, making it the first automobile to attain such approval. Toyota plans to conduct road tests to verify its all-electric range. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Prius Plug-in Hybrid">
       Prius Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      was said to have an all-electric range of 13 km (8 mi).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47">
       <a href="#cite_note-47">
        [47]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_drives_Chevy_Volt.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2731" data-file-width="4096" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Barack_Obama_drives_Chevy_Volt.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_drives_Chevy_Volt.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Barack_Obama_drives_Chevy_Volt.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_drives_Chevy_Volt.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Barack_Obama_drives_Chevy_Volt.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_drives_Chevy_Volt.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_drives_Chevy_Volt.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        President
        <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
         Barack Obama
        </a>
        behind the wheel of a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chevy_Volt" title="Chevy Volt">
         Chevy Volt
        </a>
        plug-in during his tour of the
        <a href="/wiki/Detroit/Hamtramck_Assembly" title="Detroit/Hamtramck Assembly">
         General Motors Auto Plant in Hamtramck
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Michigan" title="Michigan">
         Michigan
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      On August 9, 2007, General Motors vice-president
      <a href="/wiki/Bob_Lutz_(businessman)" title="Bob Lutz (businessman)">
       Robert Lutz
      </a>
      announced that GM is on track for
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      road testing in 2008 and production to begin by 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gmwhen_48-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-gmwhen-48">
        [48]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Volt was designed with all-electric range of 40 mi (64 km). On September 5,
      <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Quantum_Technologies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Quantum Technologies (page does not exist)">
       Quantum Technologies
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Fisker_Coachbuild" title="Fisker Coachbuild">
       Fisker Coachbuild
      </a>
      , LLC announced the launch of a joint venture in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fisker_Automotive" title="Fisker Automotive">
       Fisker Automotive
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fisker_automotive_49-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-fisker_automotive-49">
        [49]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Fisker intended to build a US$80,000 luxury PHEV-50, the
      <a href="/wiki/Fisker_Karma" title="Fisker Karma">
       Fisker Karma
      </a>
      , initially scheduled for late 2009.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karma_50-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-karma-50">
        [50]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In September 2007,
      <a href="/wiki/Aptera_Motors" title="Aptera Motors">
       Aptera Motors
      </a>
      announced their
      <a href="/wiki/Aptera_2_Series" title="Aptera 2 Series">
       Typ-1
      </a>
      two-seater. They planned to produce both an electric 2e and a plug-in series hybrid 2h with a common three-wheeled, composite body design. As of 2009, over two thousand hybrid pre-orders had been accepted and production of the hybrid configuration was expected to begin in 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aptera_51-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-aptera-51">
        [51]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, the company folded in December 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52">
       <a href="#cite_note-52">
        [52]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On October 9, 2007, Chinese manufacturer
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Auto" title="BYD Auto">
       BYD Automobile Company
      </a>
      (which is owned by China's largest mobile phone battery maker) announced that it would be introducing a production PHEV-60 sedan in China in the second half of 2008. BYD exhibited it January 2008 at the
      <a href="/wiki/North_American_International_Auto_Show" title="North American International Auto Show">
       North American International Auto Show
      </a>
      in Detroit. Based on BYD's midsize F6 sedan, it uses lithium iron phosphate (LiFeP0
      <sub>
       4
      </sub>
      )-based batteries instead of lithium-ion, and can be recharged to 70% of capacity in just 10 minutes.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-byd_53-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-byd-53">
        [53]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ford_Escape_plug-in_hybrid.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1296" data-file-width="2008" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ford_Escape_plug-in_hybrid.jpg/220px-Ford_Escape_plug-in_hybrid.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ford_Escape_plug-in_hybrid.jpg/330px-Ford_Escape_plug-in_hybrid.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e0/Ford_Escape_plug-in_hybrid.jpg/440px-Ford_Escape_plug-in_hybrid.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ford_Escape_plug-in_hybrid.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Demonstration
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_Escape_Hybrid" title="Ford Escape Hybrid">
         Ford Escape
        </a>
        plug-in hybrid in
        <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">
         New York City
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In December 2007 Ford delivered the first
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_Escape_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Ford Escape Plug-in Hybrid">
       Ford Escape Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      of a fleet of 20 demonstration PHEVs to
      <a href="/wiki/Southern_California_Edison" title="Southern California Edison">
       Southern California Edison
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54">
       <a href="#cite_note-54">
        [54]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As part of this demonstration program Ford also developed the first ever
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flexible-fuel" title="Flexible-fuel">
       flexible-fuel
      </a>
      plug-in hybrid
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUV" title="SUV">
       SUV
      </a>
      , which was delivered in June 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USDoE_55-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USDoE-55">
        [55]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This demonstration fleet of plug-ins has been in field testing with utility company fleets in the U.S. and Canada,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HC032009_56-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-HC032009-56">
        [56]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and during the first two years since the program began, the fleet has logged more than 75,000 miles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-V2G_57-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-V2G-57">
        [57]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In August 2009 Ford delivered the first Escape Plug-in equipped with intelligent
      <a href="/wiki/Vehicle-to-grid" title="Vehicle-to-grid">
       vehicle-to-grid
      </a>
      (V2G) communications and control system technology, and Ford plans to equip all 21 plug-in hybrid Escapes with the vehicle-to-grid communications technology.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-V2G_57-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-V2G-57">
        [57]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sales of the Escape PHEV are scheduled for 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HC032009_56-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-HC032009-56">
        [56]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On January 14, 2008, Toyota announced they would start sales of lithium-ion battery PHEVs by 2010,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58">
       <a href="#cite_note-58">
        [58]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59">
       <a href="#cite_note-59">
        [59]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but later in the year Toyota indicated they would be offered to commercial fleets in 2009.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-toyota09_60-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-toyota09-60">
        [60]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On March 27, the
      <a href="/wiki/California_Air_Resources_Board" title="California Air Resources Board">
       California Air Resources Board
      </a>
      modified their regulations, requiring automobile manufacturers to produce 58,000 plug-in hybrids during 2012 through 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61">
       <a href="#cite_note-61">
        [61]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This requirement is an asked-for alternative to an earlier mandate to produce 25,000 pure
      <a href="/wiki/Zero-emissions_vehicle" title="Zero-emissions vehicle">
       zero-emissions vehicles
      </a>
      , reducing that requirement to 5,000.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62">
       <a href="#cite_note-62">
        [62]
       </a>
      </sup>
      On June 26,
      <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen" title="Volkswagen">
       Volkswagen
      </a>
      announced that they would be introducing production plug-ins based on the
      <a href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf" title="Volkswagen Golf">
       Golf
      </a>
      compact. Volkswagen uses the term 'TwinDrive' to denote a PHEV.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vwgolf_63-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-vwgolf-63">
        [63]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In September,
      <a href="/wiki/Mazda" title="Mazda">
       Mazda
      </a>
      was reported to be planning PHEVs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64">
       <a href="#cite_note-64">
        [64]
       </a>
      </sup>
      On September 23,
      <a href="/wiki/Chrysler" title="Chrysler">
       Chrysler
      </a>
      announced that they had prototyped a plug-in
      <a href="/wiki/Jeep_Wrangler" title="Jeep Wrangler">
       Jeep Wrangler
      </a>
      and a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chrysler_Town_and_Country" title="Chrysler Town and Country">
       Chrysler Town and Country
      </a>
      mini-van, both PHEV-40s with
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
       series
      </a>
      powertrains, and an all-electric Dodge sports car, and said that one of the three vehicles would go into production.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65">
       <a href="#cite_note-65">
        [65]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66">
       <a href="#cite_note-66">
        [66]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      On October 3, the U.S. enacted the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_Improvement_and_Extension_Act_of_2008" title="Energy Improvement and Extension Act of 2008">
       Energy Improvement and Extension Act of 2008
      </a>
      . The legislation provided tax credits for the purchase of
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
      of battery capacity over 4 kilowatt-hours.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schoenberger_67-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Schoenberger-67">
        [67]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vijayenthiran_68-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Vijayenthiran-68">
        [68]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle#United_States" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       federal tax credits
      </a>
      were extended and modified by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Clean_Energy_and_Security_Act_of_2009" title="American Clean Energy and Security Act of 2009">
       American Clean Energy and Security Act of 2009
      </a>
      , but now the battery capacity must be over 5
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/KWh" title="KWh">
       kWh
      </a>
      and the credit phases out after the automaker has sold at least 200,000 vehicles in the U.S.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yahoo0330_69-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Yahoo0330-69">
        [69]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Series_production">
       Series production
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Series production">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      On December 15, 2008
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Auto" title="BYD Auto">
       BYD Auto
      </a>
      began selling its
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_F3DM" title="BYD F3DM">
       F3DM
      </a>
      in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="People's Republic of China">
       China
      </a>
      , becoming the first production plug-in hybrid sold in the world, though initially was available only for corporate and government customers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-F3DM_12-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-F3DM-12">
        [12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bwf3dm_13-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-bwf3dm-13">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC1208_14-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC1208-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sales to the general public began in
      <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">
       Shenzhen
      </a>
      in March 2010,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC0310_15-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC0310-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edmunds310_16-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Edmunds310-16">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but because the F3DM nearly doubles the price of cars that run on conventional fuel, BYD expects subsidies from the local government to make the plug-in affordable to personal buyers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC0310_15-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC0310-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014_Cadillac_ELR_trimmed.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="2943" height="120" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/2014_Cadillac_ELR_trimmed.jpg/220px-2014_Cadillac_ELR_trimmed.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/2014_Cadillac_ELR_trimmed.jpg/330px-2014_Cadillac_ELR_trimmed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/2014_Cadillac_ELR_trimmed.jpg/440px-2014_Cadillac_ELR_trimmed.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2014_Cadillac_ELR_trimmed.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Retail deliveries of the
        <a href="/wiki/Cadillac_ELR" title="Cadillac ELR">
         Cadillac ELR
        </a>
        began in the U.S. in December 2013.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      A global demonstration program involving 600
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid">
       Toyota Prius Plug-in
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Pre-production_car" title="Pre-production car">
       pre-production test cars
      </a>
      began in late 2009 in Japan and by mid-2010 field testing had begun in France, Germany, the United Kingdom, Canada, and the United States.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ToyotaDemo2009_70-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ToyotaDemo2009-70">
        [70]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCCEDF_71-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCCEDF-71">
        [71]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReutersUK0610_72-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ReutersUK0610-72">
        [72]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73">
       <a href="#cite_note-73">
        [73]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74">
       <a href="#cite_note-74">
        [74]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75">
       <a href="#cite_note-75">
        [75]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Volvo_Cars" title="Volvo Cars">
       Volvo Cars
      </a>
      , in a
      <a href="/wiki/Joint_venture" title="Joint venture">
       joint venture
      </a>
      with
      <a href="/wiki/Vattenfall" title="Vattenfall">
       Vattenfall
      </a>
      , a Swedish energy company, began a demonstration project with two
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_V70_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Volvo V70 Plug-in Hybrid">
       Volvo V70 Plug-in Hybrids
      </a>
      in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G%C3%B6teborg,_Sweden" title="Göteborg, Sweden">
       Göteborg, Sweden
      </a>
      since December 2009. As reported by the test drivers, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_V70_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Volvo V70 Plug-in Hybrid">
       V70 Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      demonstrators have an
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      between 20 kilometres (12 mi) to 30 kilometres (19 mi). The test plug-in hybrids were built with a button to allow test drivers to manually choose between electricity or diesel engine power at any time.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Emobility_76-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Emobility-76">
        [76]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PluginCars_77-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PluginCars-77">
        [77]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Volvo announced
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_production" title="Series production">
       series production
      </a>
      of plug-in diesel-electric hybrids as early as 2012. Volvo claimed that its plug-in hybrid could achieve 125 miles per US gallon (1.88 L/100 km; 150 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ), based on the European test cycle.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PluginCars_77-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-PluginCars-77">
        [77]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volvo03_78-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volvo03-78">
        [78]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In October 2010
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lotus_Engineering" title="Lotus Engineering">
       Lotus Engineering
      </a>
      unveiled the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lotus_CityCar" title="Lotus CityCar">
       Lotus CityCar
      </a>
      at the
      <a href="/wiki/2010_Paris_Motor_Show" title="2010 Paris Motor Show">
       2010 Paris Motor Show
      </a>
      , a plug-in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
       series hybrid
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Concept_car" title="Concept car">
       concept car
      </a>
      designed for
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Flex-fuel" title="Flex-fuel">
       flex-fuel
      </a>
      operation on
      <a href="/wiki/Ethanol_fuel" title="Ethanol fuel">
       ethanol
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/Methanol_fuel" title="Methanol fuel">
       methanol
      </a>
      as well as regular
      <a href="/wiki/Gasoline" title="Gasoline">
       gasoline
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AbG_79-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AbG-79">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Car.26Driver_80-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Car.26Driver-80">
        [80]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium_battery" title="Lithium battery">
       lithium battery
      </a>
      pack provides an
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 60 kilometres (37 mi), and the 1.2-liter flex-fuel engine kicks in to allow to extend the range to more than 500 kilometres (310 mi).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AbG_79-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-AbG-79">
        [79]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Car.26Driver_80-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Car.26Driver-80">
        [80]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BMW_automobile_in_Toompea.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2056" data-file-width="3648" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/BMW_automobile_in_Toompea.JPG/220px-BMW_automobile_in_Toompea.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/BMW_automobile_in_Toompea.JPG/330px-BMW_automobile_in_Toompea.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/BMW_automobile_in_Toompea.JPG/440px-BMW_automobile_in_Toompea.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BMW_automobile_in_Toompea.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/BMW_i8" title="BMW i8">
         BMW i8
        </a>
        plug-in hybrid was released to retail customers in Germany in 2014.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      GM officially launched the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      in the U.S. on November 30, 2010, and retail deliveries began in December 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt1stDelivery_17-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt1stDelivery-17">
        [17]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Its sibling the Opel/Vauxhall Ampera was launched in Europe between late 2011 and early 2012. The first deliveries of the
      <a href="/wiki/Fisker_Karma" title="Fisker Karma">
       Fisker Karma
      </a>
      took place in July 2011,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Karma1stDelivery_81-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Karma1stDelivery-81">
        [81]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and deliveries to retail customers began in November 2011. The
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid">
       Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      was released in Japan in January 2012,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JapanStartDate_82-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-JapanStartDate-82">
        [82]
       </a>
      </sup>
      followed by the United States in February 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PEVsalesUS_83-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PEVsalesUS-83">
        [83]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Deliveries of the Prius PHV in Europe began in late June 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriuSales0612EU_84-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PriuSales0612EU-84">
        [84]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_C-Max_Energi" title="Ford C-Max Energi">
       Ford C-Max Energi
      </a>
      was released in the U.S. in October 2012,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnergiSales_85-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EnergiSales-85">
        [85]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid">
       Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      in Sweden by late 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2011_13_86-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2011_13-86">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honda_Accord_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid">
       Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      was released in selected U.S. markets in January 2013,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pete_Brissette_87-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Pete_Brissette-87">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Outlander_P-HEV" title="Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV">
       Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV
      </a>
      in Japan in January 2013, becoming the first
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUV" title="SUV">
       SUV
      </a>
      plug-in hybrid in the market.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JapPHEV_88-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-JapPHEV-88">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Deliveries of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_Fusion_Energi" title="Ford Fusion Energi">
       Ford Fusion Energi
      </a>
      began in February 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnergiDelivery01_89-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EnergiDelivery01-89">
        [89]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnergiDelivery02_90-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EnergiDelivery02-90">
        [90]
       </a>
      </sup>
      BYD Auto stopped production of its BYD F3DM due to low sales,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EndF3DM_91-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EndF3DM-91">
        [91]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and its successor, the
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Qin" title="BYD Qin">
       BYD Qin
      </a>
      , began sales in
      <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">
       Costa Rica
      </a>
      in November 2013, with sales in other countries in
      <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">
       Latin America
      </a>
      scheduled to begin in 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinLatam01_92-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinLatam01-92">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinLatam02_93-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinLatam02-93">
        [93]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinLatam03_94-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinLatam03-94">
        [94]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Qin deliveries began in China in mid December 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriceChina_95-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PriceChina-95">
        [95]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2016_Chevrolet_Volt_NAIAS_2015_trimmed.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1780" data-file-width="3317" height="118" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/2016_Chevrolet_Volt_NAIAS_2015_trimmed.jpg/220px-2016_Chevrolet_Volt_NAIAS_2015_trimmed.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/2016_Chevrolet_Volt_NAIAS_2015_trimmed.jpg/330px-2016_Chevrolet_Volt_NAIAS_2015_trimmed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/2016_Chevrolet_Volt_NAIAS_2015_trimmed.jpg/440px-2016_Chevrolet_Volt_NAIAS_2015_trimmed.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2016_Chevrolet_Volt_NAIAS_2015_trimmed.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Deliveries of the
        <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt_(second_generation)" title="Chevrolet Volt (second generation)">
         second generation Chevrolet Volt
        </a>
        began in the U.S. and Canada in October 2015.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt2016_96-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Volt2016-96">
          [96]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canada2015_97-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Canada2015-97">
          [97]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Deliveries to retail customers of the limited edition
      <a href="/wiki/McLaren_P1" title="McLaren P1">
       McLaren P1
      </a>
      supercar began in the UK in October 2013,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McLarenP1_98-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-McLarenP1-98">
        [98]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Porsche_Panamera_S_E-Hybrid" title="Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid">
       Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid
      </a>
      began deliveries in the U.S. in November 2013. The first retail deliveries of the
      <a href="/wiki/Cadillac_ELR" title="Cadillac ELR">
       Cadillac ELR
      </a>
      took place in the U.S. in December 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ELR1st_99-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ELR1st-99">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_i8" title="BMW i8">
       BMW i8
      </a>
      and the limited edition
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_XL1" title="Volkswagen XL1">
       Volkswagen XL1
      </a>
      were released to retail customers in Germany in June 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BMWi8First_100-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BMWi8First-100">
        [100]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VWXL1first_101-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-VWXL1first-101">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Porsche_918_Spyder" title="Porsche 918 Spyder">
       Porsche 918 Spyder
      </a>
      was also released in Europe and the U.S. in 2014. The first units of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Audi_A3_Sportback_e-tron" title="Audi A3 Sportback e-tron">
       Audi A3 Sportback e-tron
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf_GTE" title="Volkswagen Golf GTE">
       Volkswagen Golf GTE
      </a>
      were registered in Germany in August 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Germany082014_102-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Germany082014-102">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In December 2014 BMW announced the group is planning to offer plug-in hybrid versions of all its core-brand models using eDrive technology developed for its
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_i" title="BMW i">
       BMW i
      </a>
      brand plug-in vehicles (
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_i3" title="BMW i3">
       BMW i3
      </a>
      and BMW i8). The goal of the company is to use plug-in technology to continue offering high performance vehicles while reducing CO
      <sub>
       2
      </sub>
      emissions below 100g/km. At the time of the announcement the carmaker was already testing a
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_3_Series" title="BMW 3 Series">
       BMW 3 Series
      </a>
      plug-in hybrid prototype.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-103">
       <a href="#cite_note-103">
        [103]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first model available for retail sales will be the 2016
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_X5_eDrive" title="BMW X5 eDrive">
       BMW X5 eDrive
      </a>
      , with the production version unveiled at the 2015
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shanghai_Motor_Show" title="Shanghai Motor Show">
       Shanghai Motor Show
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104">
       <a href="#cite_note-104">
        [104]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt_(second_generation)" title="Chevrolet Volt (second generation)">
       second generation Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      was unveiled at the January 2015
      <a href="/wiki/North_American_International_Auto_Show" title="North American International Auto Show">
       North American International Auto Show
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2016Volt_105-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-2016Volt-105">
        [105]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and retail deliveries began in the U.S. and Canada in October 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt2016_96-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt2016-96">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canada2015_97-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Canada2015-97">
        [97]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BYD_Tang_03_Auto_China_2014-04-23.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="659" data-file-width="1300" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/BYD_Tang_03_Auto_China_2014-04-23.jpg/220px-BYD_Tang_03_Auto_China_2014-04-23.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/BYD_Tang_03_Auto_China_2014-04-23.jpg/330px-BYD_Tang_03_Auto_China_2014-04-23.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/BYD_Tang_03_Auto_China_2014-04-23.jpg/440px-BYD_Tang_03_Auto_China_2014-04-23.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BYD_Tang_03_Auto_China_2014-04-23.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/BYD_Tang" title="BYD Tang">
         BYD Tang
        </a>
        was released in China in June 2015.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In March 2015
      <a href="/wiki/Audi" title="Audi">
       Audi
      </a>
      announced plans to have a plug-in hybrid version in every model series in the coming years. The carmaker expects plug-in hybrids, together with natural gas vehicles and battery-electric drive systems, to have a key contribution in achieving the company's CO
      <sub>
       2
      </sub>
      targets. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Audi_Q7_e-tron" title="Audi Q7 e-tron">
       Audi Q7 e-tron
      </a>
      will follow the A3 e-tron already in the market.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106">
       <a href="#cite_note-106">
        [106]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Also in March 2015,
      <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">
       Mercedes-Benz
      </a>
      announced that the company's main emphasis regarding alternative drives in the next years will be on plug-in hybrids. The carmaker plans to introduce 10 new plug-in hybrid models by 2017, and its next release was the
      <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_C-Class_(W205)#C_350_e" title="Mercedes-Benz C-Class (W205)">
       Mercedes-Benz C 350 e
      </a>
      , Mercedes’ second plug-in hybrid after the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_S_500_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Mercedes-Benz S 500 Plug-in Hybrid">
       S 500 Plug-In Hybrid
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MBphevs_107-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MBphevs-107">
        [107]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other plug-in hybrid released in 2015 are the
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Tang" title="BYD Tang">
       BYD Tang
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Passat_GTE" title="Volkswagen Passat GTE">
       Volkswagen Passat GTE
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_XC90_T8" title="Volvo XC90 T8">
       Volvo XC90 T8
      </a>
      , and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyundai_Sonata_PHEV" title="Hyundai Sonata PHEV">
       Hyundai Sonata PHEV
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Global combined
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volt/Ampera_family" title="Volt/Ampera family">
       Volt/Ampera family
      </a>
      sales passed the 100,000 unit milestone in October 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt100K_1-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt100K-1">
        [1]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By the end of 2015, over 517,000 highway legal plug-in hybrid electric cars have been sold worldwide since December 2008 out of total global sales of more than 1.25 million light-duty
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_car" title="Plug-in electric car">
       plug-in electric cars
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlook2016_19-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlook2016-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TopSix2015_108-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TopSix2015-108">
        [108]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in_(16).JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2960" data-file-width="4544" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in_%2816%29.JPG/220px-Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in_%2816%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in_%2816%29.JPG/330px-Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in_%2816%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in_%2816%29.JPG/440px-Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in_%2816%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in_(16).JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The 2017
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in" title="Hyundai Ioniq Plug-in">
         Hyundai Ioniq Plug-in
        </a>
        is scheduled to be released in the U.S. in the fourth quarter of 2016.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In February 2016, BMW announced the introduction of the "iPerformance" model designation, which will be given to all BMW plug-in hybrid vehicles from July 2016. The aim is to provide a visible indicator of the transfer of technology from
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_i" title="BMW i">
       BMW i
      </a>
      to the BMW core brand. The new designation will be used first on the plug-in hybrid variants of the new
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_7_Series" title="BMW 7 Series">
       BMW 7 Series
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_740e_iPerformance" title="BMW 740e iPerformance">
       BMW 740e iPerformance
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109">
       <a href="#cite_note-109">
        [109]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_3_Series" title="BMW 3 Series">
       3 Series
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_330e_iPerformance" title="BMW 330e iPerformance">
       BMW 330e iPerformance
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US330e_110-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-US330e-110">
        [110]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Hyundai_Motor_Company" title="Hyundai Motor Company">
       Hyundai Motor Company
      </a>
      made the official debut of its three model
      <a href="/wiki/Hyundai_Ioniq" title="Hyundai Ioniq">
       Hyundai Ioniq
      </a>
      ine-up at the 2016
      <a href="/wiki/Geneva_Motor_Show" title="Geneva Motor Show">
       Geneva Motor Show
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KoreaTimes_111-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-KoreaTimes-111">
        [111]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Ioniq family of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electric_drive_vehicle" title="Electric drive vehicle">
       electric drive vehicles
      </a>
      includes the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in" title="Hyundai Ioniq Plug-in">
       Ioniq Plug-in
      </a>
      , which is expected to achieve a fuel economy of 125 mpg-e (28 kW·h/100 mi; 17.1 kW·h/100 km) in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCG032016_112-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCG032016-112">
        [112]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Ioniq Plug-in is scheduled to be released in the U.S. in the fourth quarter of 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113">
       <a href="#cite_note-113">
        [113]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The second generation Prius plug-in hybrid, called
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Prime" title="Toyota Prius Prime">
       Prius Prime
      </a>
      in the U.S. and Prius PHV in Japan,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prime_PHV_114-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Prime_PHV-114">
        [114]
       </a>
      </sup>
      was unveiled at the 2016
      <a href="/wiki/New_York_International_Auto_Show" title="New York International Auto Show">
       New York International Auto Show
      </a>
      . The model is expected to be released in the U.S. and Japan by the end of 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Prime_PHV_114-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Prime_PHV-114">
        [114]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriusPrime1_115-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PriusPrime1-115">
        [115]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Prime has an EPA-rated
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 25 mi (40 km), over twice the range of the first generation model, and an EPA rated fuel economy of 133 mpg-e (25.9 kW·h/100 mi) in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      (EV mode), the highest
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon equivalent">
       MPGe
      </a>
      rating in EV mode of any vehicle rated by EPA.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2017Prime_116-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-2017Prime-116">
        [116]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117">
       <a href="#cite_note-117">
        [117]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Unlike its predecessor, the Prime runs entirely on electricity in EV mode.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriusPrime3_118-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PriusPrime3-118">
        [118]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Global sales of the Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV passed the 100,000 unit milestone in March 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlander100K_119-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlander100K-119">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OutlanderPHEV100K_120-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-OutlanderPHEV100K-120">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Qin" title="BYD Qin">
       BYD Qin
      </a>
      sales in China reached the 50,000 unit milestone in April 2016, becoming the fourth plug-in hybrid to pass that mark.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Qin50K_121-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Qin50K-121">
        [121]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In June 2016, Nissan announced it will introduce a compact
      <a href="/wiki/Range_extender_(vehicle)" title="Range extender (vehicle)">
       range extender
      </a>
      car in Japan before March 2017. The series plug-in hybrid will use a new hybrid system, dubbed e-Power, which debuted with the
