      <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Nissan_Gripz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Nissan Gripz (page does not exist)">
       Nissan Gripz
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Concept_car" title="Concept car">
       concept
      </a>
      crossover showcased at the 2015
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Frankfurt_Auto_Show" title="Frankfurt Auto Show">
       Frankfurt Auto Show
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122">
       <a href="#cite_note-122">
        [122]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Technology">
       Technology
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: Technology">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Powertrains">
       Powertrains
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: Powertrains">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle_drivetrains" title="Hybrid vehicle drivetrains">
       Hybrid vehicle drivetrains
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chevrolet_Volt_charging_WAS_2011_833.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Chevrolet_Volt_charging_WAS_2011_833.jpg/220px-Chevrolet_Volt_charging_WAS_2011_833.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Chevrolet_Volt_charging_WAS_2011_833.jpg/330px-Chevrolet_Volt_charging_WAS_2011_833.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/Chevrolet_Volt_charging_WAS_2011_833.jpg/440px-Chevrolet_Volt_charging_WAS_2011_833.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Chevrolet_Volt_charging_WAS_2011_833.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The Generation 1
        <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
         Chevrolet Volt
        </a>
        operates primarily as a
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
         series hybrid
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg/220px-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg/330px-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg/440px-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-111.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid">
         Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid
        </a>
        is a
        <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle_drivetrain#Power-split_or_series-parallel_hybrid" title="Hybrid vehicle drivetrain">
         series-parallel hybrid
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      PHEVs are based on the same three basic
      <a href="/wiki/Powertrain" title="Powertrain">
       powertrain
      </a>
      architectures as
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conventional_electric_hybrid" title="Conventional electric hybrid">
       conventional electric hybrids
      </a>
      :
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ucs_123-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ucs-123">
        [123]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <b>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
        Series hybrids
       </a>
      </b>
      use an
      <a href="/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine" title="Internal combustion engine">
       internal combustion engine
      </a>
      (ICE) to turn a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electrical_generator" title="Electrical generator">
       generator
      </a>
      , which in turn supplies current to an electric motor, which then rotates the vehicle’s drive wheels. A battery or
      <a href="/wiki/Supercapacitor" title="Supercapacitor">
       supercapacitor
      </a>
      pack, or a combination of the two, can be used to store excess charge. Examples of series hybrids vehicles include the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      (first generation),
      <a href="/wiki/Fisker_Karma" title="Fisker Karma">
       Fisker Karma
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Renault_Kangoo" title="Renault Kangoo">
       Renault Kangoo
      </a>
      , Elect'Road, Toyota's Japan-only
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Coaster" title="Toyota Coaster">
       Coaster
      </a>
      light-duty passenger bus,
      <a href="/wiki/Daimler_AG" title="Daimler AG">
       Daimler AG
      </a>
      's hybrid
      <a href="/wiki/Orion_International" title="Orion International">
       Orion
      </a>
      bus,
      <a href="/wiki/Opel_Flextreme" title="Opel Flextreme">
       Opel Flextreme
      </a>
      concept car, Swissauto REX VW Polo
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124">
       <a href="#cite_note-124">
        [124]
       </a>
      </sup>
      prototype and many
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Diesel-electric_locomotive" title="Diesel-electric locomotive">
       diesel-electric locomotives
      </a>
      . With an appropriate balance of components this type can operate over a substantial distance with its full range of power without engaging the ICE. As is the case for other architectures, series hybrids can operate without recharging as long as there is liquid fuel in the tank.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125">
       <a href="#cite_note-125">
        [125]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <b>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parallel_hybrid" title="Parallel hybrid">
        Parallel hybrids
       </a>
      </b>
      , such as Honda's
      <a href="/wiki/Honda_Insight" title="Honda Insight">
       Insight
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Honda_Civic_Hybrid" title="Honda Civic Hybrid">
       Civic
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honda_Accord_Hybrid" title="Honda Accord Hybrid">
       Accord
      </a>
      hybrids, can simultaneously transmit power to their drive wheels from two distinct sources—for example, an internal combustion engine and a battery-powered electric drive. Although most parallel hybrids incorporate an electric motor between the vehicle's engine and transmission, a parallel hybrid can also use its engine to drive one of the vehicle's axles, while its electric motor drives the other axle and/or a generator used for recharging the batteries. This type is called a road-coupled hybrid. The
      <a href="/wiki/Audi" title="Audi">
       Audi
      </a>
      Duo plug-in hybrid concept car is an example of this type of parallel hybrid architecture. Parallel hybrids can be programmed to use the electric motor to substitute for the ICE at lower power demands as well as to substantially increase the power available to a smaller ICE, both of which substantially increase fuel economy compared to a simple ICE vehicle.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126">
       <a href="#cite_note-126">
        [126]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <b>
       <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle_drivetrain#Power-split_or_series-parallel_hybrid" title="Hybrid vehicle drivetrain">
        Series-parallel hybrids
       </a>
      </b>
      have the flexibility to operate in either
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
       series
      </a>
      or
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parallel_hybrid" title="Parallel hybrid">
       parallel
      </a>
      mode. Hybrid powertrains currently used by
      <a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">
       Ford
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Lexus" title="Lexus">
       Lexus
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Nissan" title="Nissan">
       Nissan
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet" title="Chevrolet">
       Chevrolet
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota" title="Toyota">
       Toyota
      </a>
      , which some refer to as “series-parallel with power-split,” can operate in both series and parallel mode at the same time. As of 2007, most plug-in hybrid conversions of conventional hybrids utilize this architecture.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127">
       <a href="#cite_note-127">
        [127]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid">
       Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      operates as a series-parallel hybrid.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128">
       <a href="#cite_note-128">
        [128]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Charging_systems">
       Charging systems
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Charging systems">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Batteries are DC devices while grid power is AC. In order to charge the batteries, a DC charger must be utilized. The charger can be located in several locations:
     </p>
     <p>
      <b>
       On-board chargers
      </b>
      are mounted inside the vehicle. Since the charger takes up space and adds weight, its power capacity is generally limited by practical considerations, avoiding carrying a more powerful charger that can only be fully utilized at certain locations. However, carrying the charger along with the vehicle ensures that power will be available anywhere a power connection can be found.
     </p>
     <p>
      <b>
       Off-board chargers
      </b>
      can be as large as needed and mounted at fixed locations, like the garage or dedicated charging stations. Built with dedicated wiring, these chargers can handle much more power and charge the batteries more quickly. However, as the output of these chargers is DC, each battery system requires the output to be changed for that car. Modern charging stations have a system for identifying the voltage of the battery pack and adjusting accordingly.
     </p>
     <p>
      <b>
       Using electric motor's inverter
      </b>
      allows the motor windings to act as the transformer coils, and the existing high-power inverter as the AC-to-DC charger. As these components are already required on the car, and are designed to handle any practical power capability, they can be used to create a very powerful form of on-board charger with zero additional weight or size.
      <a href="/wiki/AC_Propulsion" title="AC Propulsion">
       AC Propulsion
      </a>
      uses this charging method, referred to as "reductive charging".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129">
       <a href="#cite_note-129">
        [129]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Modes_of_operation">
       Modes of operation
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Modes of operation">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Regardless of its architecture, a plug-in hybrid may be capable of
      <a href="/wiki/Charge-depleting" title="Charge-depleting">
       charge-depleting
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charge-sustaining" title="Charge-sustaining">
       charge-sustaining
      </a>
      modes. Combinations of these two modes are termed
      <a href="/wiki/Blended_mode" title="Blended mode">
       blended mode
      </a>
      or mixed-mode. These vehicles can be designed to drive for an extended range in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      , either at low speeds only or at all speeds. These modes manage the vehicle's battery discharge strategy, and their use has a direct effect on the size and type of battery required:
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130">
       <a href="#cite_note-130">
        [130]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <b>
       Charge-depleting mode
      </b>
      allows a fully charged PHEV to operate exclusively (or depending on the vehicle, almost exclusively, except during hard acceleration) on electric power until its battery state of charge is depleted to a predetermined level, at which time the vehicle's internal combustion engine or fuel cell will be
      <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/engaged" title="wikt:engaged">
       engaged
      </a>
      . This period is the vehicle's
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      . This is the only mode that a
      <a href="/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle" title="Battery electric vehicle">
       battery electric vehicle
      </a>
      can operate in, hence their limited range.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-energy_131-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-energy-131">
        [131]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Renault_Kangoo_plug-in_hybrid.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="400" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Renault_Kangoo_plug-in_hybrid.jpg/220px-Renault_Kangoo_plug-in_hybrid.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Renault_Kangoo_plug-in_hybrid.jpg/330px-Renault_Kangoo_plug-in_hybrid.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b9/Renault_Kangoo_plug-in_hybrid.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Renault_Kangoo_plug-in_hybrid.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The redesigned
        <a href="/wiki/Renault_Kangoo" title="Renault Kangoo">
         Renault Kangoo
        </a>
        <a href="/wiki/Elect%27road" title="Elect'road">
         Elect'road
        </a>
        operates in blended mode, using engine and battery power simultaneously.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       <b>
        Blended mode
       </b>
       is a kind of charge-depleting mode. It is normally employed by vehicles which do not have enough electric power to sustain high speeds without the help of the internal combustion portion of the powertrain. A blended control strategy typically increases the distance from stored grid electricity compared to a charge-depleting strategy.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132">
        <a href="#cite_note-132">
         [132]
        </a>
       </sup>
       The
       <a href="/wiki/Renault_Kangoo" title="Renault Kangoo">
        Renault Kangoo
       </a>
       and some Toyota Prius conversions are examples of vehicles that use this mode of operation. The Electri'cité and Elect'road versions of the Kangoo were charge-depleting battery electric vehicles: the Elect'road had a modest internal combustion engine which extended its range somewhat. Conversions of 2004 and later model Toyota Prius can only run without using the ICE at speeds of less than about 42 mph (68 km/h) due to the limits dictated by the vehicle's powertrain control software. However, at faster speeds electric power can still be used to displace gasoline, thus improving the fuel economy in blended mode and generally doubling the fuel efficiency.
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <p>
      <b>
       Charge-sustaining mode
      </b>
      is used by
      <a href="/wiki/Production_vehicle" title="Production vehicle">
       production
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle" title="Hybrid vehicle">
       hybrid vehicles
      </a>
      (HEVs) today, and combines the operation of the vehicle's two power sources in such a manner that the vehicle is operating as efficiently as possible without allowing the battery state of charge to move outside a predetermined narrow band. Over the course of a trip in a HEV the state of charge may fluctuate but will have no net change.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133">
       <a href="#cite_note-133">
        [133]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The battery in a HEV can thus be thought of as an energy accumulator rather than a fuel storage device. Once a plug-in hybrid has exhausted its all-electric range in charge-depleting mode, it can switch into charge-sustaining mode automatically.
     </p>
     <p>
      <b>
       Mixed mode
      </b>
      describes a trip in which a combination of the above modes are utilized.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134">
       <a href="#cite_note-134">
        [134]
       </a>
      </sup>
      For example, a PHEV-20 Prius conversion may begin a trip with 5 miles (8 km) of low speed charge-depleting, then get onto a freeway and operate in blended mode for 20 miles (32 km), using 10 miles (16 km) worth of all-electric range at twice the fuel economy. Finally the driver might exit the freeway and drive for another 5 miles (8 km) without the internal combustion engine until the full 20 miles (32 km) of all-electric range are exhausted. At this point the vehicle can revert to a charge sustaining-mode for another 10 miles (16 km) until the final destination is reached. Such a trip would be considered a mixed mode, as multiple modes are employed in one trip. This contrasts with a charge-depleting trip which would be driven within the limits of a PHEV's all-electric range. Conversely, the portion of a trip which extends beyond the all-electric range of a PHEV would be driven primarily in charge-sustaining mode, as used by a conventional hybrid.
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Electric_power_storage">
       Electric power storage
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Electric power storage">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_battery" title="Electric vehicle battery">
       Electric vehicle battery
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
       Charging station
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      PHEVs typically require deeper
      <a href="/wiki/Battery_(electricity)" title="Battery (electricity)">
       battery
      </a>
      charging and discharging cycles than conventional hybrids. Because the number of full cycles influences battery life, this may be less than in traditional HEVs which do not deplete their batteries as fully. However, some authors argue that PHEVs will soon become standard in the automobile industry.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135">
       <a href="#cite_note-135">
        [135]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Design issues and trade-offs against battery life, capacity, heat dissipation, weight, costs, and safety need to be solved.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136">
       <a href="#cite_note-136">
        [136]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Advanced battery technology is under development, promising greater energy densities by both mass and volume,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137">
       <a href="#cite_note-137">
        [137]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and battery life expectancy is expected to increase.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138">
       <a href="#cite_note-138">
        [138]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The cathodes of some early 2007 lithium-ion batteries are made from lithium-cobalt metal oxide. This material is expensive, and cells made with it can release oxygen if overcharged. If the cobalt is replaced with
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium_iron_phosphate_battery" title="Lithium iron phosphate battery">
       iron phosphates
      </a>
      , the cells will not burn or release oxygen under any charge. The price premium for early 2007 conventional hybrids is about US$5000, some US$3000 of which is for their NiMH battery packs. At early 2007 gasoline and electricity prices, that would mean a break-even point after six to ten years of operation. The conventional hybrid premium could fall to US$2000 in five years, with US$1200 or more of that being cost of lithium-ion batteries, providing for a three-year payback. The payback period may be longer for plug-in hybrids, because of their larger, more expensive batteries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ieee_139-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ieee-139">
        [139]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Nickel–metal hydride and lithium-ion batteries can be recycled; Toyota, for example, has a recycling program in place under which dealers are paid a US$200 credit for each battery returned.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140">
       <a href="#cite_note-140">
        [140]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, plug-in hybrids typically use larger battery packs than comparable conventional hybrids, and thus require more resources.
      <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Gas_and_Electric_Company" title="Pacific Gas and Electric Company">
       Pacific Gas and Electric Company
      </a>
      (PG&amp;E) has suggested that utilities could purchase used batteries for backup and load leveling purposes. They state that while these used batteries may be no longer usable in vehicles, their residual capacity still has significant value.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-woody_141-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-woody-141">
        [141]
       </a>
      </sup>
      More recently,
      <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">
       General Motors
      </a>
      (GM) has said it has been "approached by utilities interested in using recycled Volt batteries as a power storage system, a secondary market that could bring down the cost of the Volt and other plug-in vehicles for consumers."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jansen_142-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-jansen-142">
        [142]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium_iron_phosphate" title="Lithium iron phosphate">
       Lithium iron phosphate
      </a>
      (LiFePO
      <sub>
       4
      </sub>
      ) is a class of cathode materials used in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithium_iron_phosphate_batteries" title="Lithium iron phosphate batteries">
       lithium iron phosphate batteries
      </a>
      that is getting attention from the auto industry. Valence Technologies produce a lithium iron manganese phosphate (LiFeMnPO
      <sub>
       4
      </sub>
      ) battery with LG Chem selling lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO
      <sub>
       4
      </sub>
      ) batteries for the Chevy Volt and A123 produces a lithium nano-phosphate battery. The most important merit of this battery type is safety and high-power.
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium_iron_phosphate_battery" title="Lithium iron phosphate battery">
       Lithium iron phosphate batteries
      </a>
      are one of three major types in
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium_iron_phosphate" title="Lithium iron phosphate">
       LFP
      </a>
      family, the other two being
      <a href="/wiki/Nanoparticle" title="Nanoparticle">
       nano
      </a>
      -phosphate and nano-cocrystalline-
      <a href="/wiki/Olivine" title="Olivine">
       olivine
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      In France,
      <a href="/wiki/%C3%89lectricit%C3%A9_de_France" title="Électricité de France">
       Électricité de France
      </a>
      (EDF) and Toyota are installing
      <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
       charging stations
      </a>
      for PHEVs on roads, streets and
      <a href="/wiki/Parking_lot" title="Parking lot">
       parking lots
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143">
       <a href="#cite_note-143">
        [143]
       </a>
      </sup>
      EDF is also partnering with Elektromotive, Ltd.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144">
       <a href="#cite_note-144">
        [144]
       </a>
      </sup>
      to install 250 new charging points over six months from October 2007 in London and elsewhere in the UK.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145">
       <a href="#cite_note-145">
        [145]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Recharging points also can be installed for specific uses, as in
      <a href="/wiki/Taxicab_stand" title="Taxicab stand">
       taxicab stands
      </a>
      .
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Project_Better_Place" title="Project Better Place">
       Project Better Place
      </a>
      began in October 2007 and is working with
      <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">
       Renault
      </a>
      on development of exchangeable batteries (battery swapping).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146">
       <a href="#cite_note-146">
        [146]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ultracapacitor" title="Ultracapacitor">
       Ultracapacitors
      </a>
      (or "supercapacitors") are used in some plug-in hybrids, such as
      <a href="/wiki/AFS_Trinity" title="AFS Trinity">
       AFS Trinity
      </a>
      's concept prototype, to store rapidly available energy with their high
      <a href="/wiki/Power_density" title="Power density">
       power density
      </a>
      , in order to keep batteries within safe resistive heating limits and extend battery life.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTXH_147-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYTXH-147">
        [147]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trinity_148-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Trinity-148">
        [148]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The CSIRO's
      <a href="/wiki/UltraBattery" title="UltraBattery">
       UltraBattery
      </a>
      combines a
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_double-layer_capacitor" title="Electric double-layer capacitor">
       supercapacitor
      </a>
      and a lead acid battery in a single unit, creating a hybrid car battery that lasts longer, costs less and is more powerful than current technologies used in plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149">
       <a href="#cite_note-149">
        [149]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The optimum battery size varies depending on whether the aim is to reduce oil consumption, running costs, or emissions, but a recent study
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150">
       <a href="#cite_note-150">
        [150]
       </a>
      </sup>
      concluded that "The best choice of PHEV battery capacity depends critically on the distance that the vehicle will be driven between charges. Our results suggest that for urban driving conditions and frequent charges every 10 miles or less, a low-capacity PHEV sized with an AER (all electric range) of about 7 miles would be a robust choice for minimizing gasoline consumption, cost, and greenhouse gas emissions. For less frequent charging, every 20–100 miles, PHEVs release fewer GHGs, but HEVs are more cost effective. "
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Conversions_of_production_vehicles">
       Conversions of production vehicles
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: Conversions of production vehicles">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_conversion" title="Electric vehicle conversion">
       Electric vehicle conversion
      </a>
     </div>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Conversion_of_fossil-fuel_vehicles">
       Conversion of fossil-fuel vehicles
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Conversion of fossil-fuel vehicles">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/CalCars" title="CalCars">
       CalCars
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Retrofit" title="Retrofit">
       Retrofit
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Electrification" title="Electrification">
       electrification
      </a>
      requires only one-fifth the energy required to build a new vehicle. This is called ACEV-to-PHEV conversion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-calcars.org_151-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-calcars.org-151">
        [151]
       </a>
      </sup>
      There are several companies that are converting
      <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel" title="Fossil fuel">
       fossil fuel
      </a>
      non-hybrid vehicles (also called all-
      <a href="/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine" title="Internal combustion engine">
       combustion engine
      </a>
      vehicles) to plug-in hybrids:
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152">
       <a href="#cite_note-152">
        [152]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153">
       <a href="#cite_note-153">
        [153]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Colorado is going to offer $6,000 credit for PHEV conversions (in addition to a federal 10% credit up to $4,000 for qualifying vehicles).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154">
       <a href="#cite_note-154">
        [154]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="plainlinks metadata ambox mbox-small-left ambox-content" role="presentation">
      <tr>
       <td class="mbox-image">
        <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg">
         <img alt="[icon]" data-file-height="31" data-file-width="44" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/20px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/30px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg/40px-Wiki_letter_w_cropped.svg.png 2x" width="20"/>
        </a>
       </td>
       <td class="mbox-text">
        <span class="mbox-text-span">
         <b>
          This section needs expansion
         </b>
         .
         <small>
          You can help by
          <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=">
           adding to it
          </a>
          .
         </small>
         <small>
          <i>
           (February 2009)
          </i>
         </small>
        </span>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Conversions_of_production_hybrids">
       Conversions of production hybrids
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Conversions of production hybrids">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:WanacheBuild88large.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="640" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/WanacheBuild88large.JPG/220px-WanacheBuild88large.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/WanacheBuild88large.JPG/330px-WanacheBuild88large.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/WanacheBuild88large.JPG/440px-WanacheBuild88large.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:WanacheBuild88large.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        15
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lead%E2%80%93acid_batteries" title="Lead–acid batteries">
         lead–acid batteries
        </a>
        , PFC charger, and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battery_regulator" title="Battery regulator">
         regulators
        </a>
        installed into
        <a class="external text" href="http://www.eaa-phev.org/wiki/WhiteBird" rel="nofollow">
         WhiteBird
        </a>
        , a PHEV-10 conversion of a Toyota Prius
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Aftermarket_(automotive)" title="Aftermarket (automotive)">
       Aftermarket conversion
      </a>
      of an existing production hybrid (a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Charge-maintaining_hybrid" title="Charge-maintaining hybrid">
       charge-maintaining hybrid
      </a>
      ) to a plug-in hybrid (called CHEV-to-PHEV conversion
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-calcars.org_151-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-calcars.org-151">
        [151]
       </a>
      </sup>
      ) typically involves increasing the capacity of the vehicle's
      <a href="/wiki/Battery_pack" title="Battery pack">
       battery pack
      </a>
      and adding an on-board AC-to-DC charger. Ideally, the vehicle's powertrain software would be reprogrammed to make full use of the battery pack's additional energy storage capacity and power output.
     </p>
     <p>
      Many early plug-in hybrid
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_conversion" title="Electric vehicle conversion">
       electric vehicle conversions
      </a>
      have been based on the 2004 or later model
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
       Toyota Prius
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155">
       <a href="#cite_note-155">
        [155]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Some of the systems have involved replacement of the vehicle's original NiMH battery pack and its electronic control unit. Others, such as
      <a href="/wiki/A123_Hymotion" title="A123 Hymotion">
       A123 Hymotion
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/CalCars#Prius.2B_and_Kits" title="CalCars">
       CalCars Prius+
      </a>
      , and the PiPrius,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Piggy-back_(transportation)" title="Piggy-back (transportation)">
       piggyback
      </a>
      an additional battery back onto the original battery pack, this is also referred to as Battery Range Extender Modules (BREMs).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-156">
       <a href="#cite_note-156">
        [156]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Within the
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_conversion" title="Electric vehicle conversion">
       electric vehicle conversion
      </a>
      community this has been referred to as a "hybrid battery pack configuration".
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157">
       <a href="#cite_note-157">
        [157]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Early
      <a href="/wiki/Lead%E2%80%93acid_battery" title="Lead–acid battery">
       lead–acid battery
      </a>
      conversions by CalCars demonstrated
      <span class="nowrap">
       10 miles
      </span>
      (
      <span class="nowrap">
       15 km
      </span>
      ) of EV-only and
      <span class="nowrap">
       20 miles
      </span>
      (
      <span class="nowrap">
       30 km
      </span>
      ) of double mileage
      <a href="/wiki/Blended_mode" title="Blended mode">
       blended mode
      </a>
      range.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-priusplus_39-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-priusplus-39">
        [39]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      EDrive Systems use
      <a href="/wiki/Valence_Technology" title="Valence Technology">
       Valence Technology
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithium-ion_polymer_battery" title="Lithium-ion polymer battery">
       Li-ion
      </a>
      batteries and have a claimed 40 to 50 miles
      <span class="nowrap">
       (64 to 80 km)
      </span>
      of electric range.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158">
       <a href="#cite_note-158">
        [158]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other companies offering plug-in conversions or kits for the Toyota Prius (some of them also for
      <a href="/wiki/Ford_Escape" title="Ford Escape">
       Ford Escape
      </a>
      Hybrid) include Hymotion,
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrids_Plus" title="Hybrids Plus">
       Hybrids Plus
      </a>
      <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Manzanita_Micro&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Manzanita Micro (page does not exist)">
       Manzanita Micro
      </a>
      and OEMtek BREEZ (PHEV-30).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159">
       <a href="#cite_note-159">
        [159]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/AFS_Trinity" title="AFS Trinity">
       AFS Trinity
      </a>
      's XH-150 claims that it has created a functioning plug-in hybrid with a 40 miles (64 km)
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      and that it has solved the overheating problem that rapid acceleration can cause in PHEVs and extend battery life.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTXH_147-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYTXH-147">
        [147]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Trinity_148-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Trinity-148">
        [148]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The EAA-PHEV project was conceived by CalCars and the Electric Auto Association in October 2005 to accelerate efforts to document existing HEVs and their potential for conversion into PHEVs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160">
       <a href="#cite_note-160">
        [160]
       </a>
      </sup>
      It includes a "conversion interest" page.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161">
       <a href="#cite_note-161">
        [161]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_Auto_Association" title="Electric Auto Association">
       Electric Auto Association
      </a>
      -PHEV "Do-It-Yourself"
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Open_Source" title="Open Source">
       Open Source
      </a>
      community's primary focus is to provide conversion instructions to help guide experienced converters through the process, and to provide a common design that could demonstrate multiple battery technologies. Many members of organizations such as
      <a href="/wiki/CalCars" title="CalCars">
       CalCars
      </a>
      and the EAA as well as companies like
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrids_Plus" title="Hybrids Plus">
       Hybrids Plus
      </a>
      , Hybrid Interfaces of Canada, and Manzanita Micro participate in the development of the project.
     </p>
     <p>
      Plug-In Supply, Inc. of
      <a href="/wiki/Petaluma,_California" title="Petaluma, California">
       Petaluma, California
      </a>
      offers components and assemblies to build the Prius+, the plug-in conversion invented by CalCars.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162">
       <a href="#cite_note-162">
        [162]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Their
      <a href="/wiki/Lead%E2%80%93acid_battery" title="Lead–acid battery">
       lead–acid battery
      </a>
      box assembly forms a complete install package, providing access to the spare tire and containing twenty 12 volt lead–acid batteries and all high voltage components and control electronics. The "PbA Battery Box Assembly" is also available without batteries. It provides about 10 miles (16 km) of EV mode range.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163">
       <a href="#cite_note-163">
        [163]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Conversion time was reduced by plug-in supply to one day.
     </p>
     <p>
      Oemtek offers a
      <a href="/wiki/Valence_Technology" title="Valence Technology">
       Valence
      </a>
      powered
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium_iron_phosphate" title="Lithium iron phosphate">
       lithium iron phosphate
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_conversion" title="Electric vehicle conversion">
       conversion
      </a>
      that should provide 50 miles (80 km) of
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      . The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Motor_Industry_Research_Association" title="Motor Industry Research Association">
       Motor Industry Research Association
      </a>
      has announced a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Retrofit" title="Retrofit">
       retrofit
      </a>
      hybrid conversion kit that provides removable battery packs that plug into a wall outlet for charging.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164">
       <a href="#cite_note-164">
        [164]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Poulsen Hybrid is developing a conversion kit that will add through-the-road plug-in hybrid capability to conventional vehicles by externally mounting electric motors onto two of the wheels.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165">
       <a href="#cite_note-165">
        [165]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      MD-Tech offers a PHEV Kit for hybrid vehicles that acts as a hybrid battery re-charger.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2012)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      The kit supplies power to the hybrid battery without modifying the
      <a href="/wiki/Powertrain" title="Powertrain">
       powertrain
      </a>
      of the hybrid vehicle. It fits into the back of a hybrid vehicle, originally designed to fit under the rear floor of a
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
       Toyota Prius
      </a>
      . The kit uses lithium iron phosphate cells in a battery supplying 4 kWh of energy. This gives it a range of 30 km in
      <a href="/wiki/Charge-depleting" title="Charge-depleting">
       charge-depleting
      </a>
      , EV mode and provides a boost of power in
      <a href="/wiki/Blended_mode" title="Blended mode">
       blended mode
      </a>
      . The battery charger uses
      <a href="/wiki/Mains_electricity" title="Mains electricity">
       mains electricity
      </a>
      and takes 4–5 hours to charge. The battery supplies power to the DC to DC
      <a href="/wiki/Boost_converter" title="Boost converter">
       boost converter
      </a>
      which regulates power to the hybrid battery. The converter output can be adjusted to set voltage and current output. A proprietary
      <a href="/wiki/Battery_management_system" title="Battery management system">
       battery management system
      </a>
      uses active
      <a href="/wiki/Battery_balancing" title="Battery balancing">
       battery balancing
      </a>
      to monitor the battery
      <a href="/wiki/State_of_health" title="State of health">
       state of health
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      Enginer Inc. of
      <a href="/wiki/Troy,_Michigan" title="Troy, Michigan">
       Troy, Michigan
      </a>
      offers universal plugin conversion kits with components and assemblies to build two stage hybrid battery system.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (December 2012)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      Their
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery" title="Lithium-ion battery">
       lithium-ion battery
      </a>
      box assembly forms a complete install package, providing access to the spare tire and containing 16/32 lithium phosphate battery cells, a DC/DC converter, a BMS and a charger. It provides about 10 miles (16 km) of EV mode range for under $2000 (2 kWh model). Longer range 4 kWh model is also available for $1000 more. Conversion time was reduced to two/three hours.
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Target_market">
       Target market
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Target market">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:277px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:All-electric_range_for_2013-14_plug_in_hybrids_observed_in_Popular_Mechanics_magazine_test.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="463" data-file-width="600" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/52/All-electric_range_for_2013-14_plug_in_hybrids_observed_in_Popular_Mechanics_magazine_test.png/275px-All-electric_range_for_2013-14_plug_in_hybrids_observed_in_Popular_Mechanics_magazine_test.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/52/All-electric_range_for_2013-14_plug_in_hybrids_observed_in_Popular_Mechanics_magazine_test.png/413px-All-electric_range_for_2013-14_plug_in_hybrids_observed_in_Popular_Mechanics_magazine_test.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/52/All-electric_range_for_2013-14_plug_in_hybrids_observed_in_Popular_Mechanics_magazine_test.png/550px-All-electric_range_for_2013-14_plug_in_hybrids_observed_in_Popular_Mechanics_magazine_test.png 2x" width="275"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:All-electric_range_for_2013-14_plug_in_hybrids_observed_in_Popular_Mechanics_magazine_test.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
         All-electric range
        </a>
        , in miles, for several popular model year 2013 plug-in hybrids, as observed in testing by
        <a href="/wiki/Popular_Mechanics" title="Popular Mechanics">
         Popular Mechanics
        </a>
        magazine. Providing greater all-electric range adds cost and entails compromises, so different all-electric ranges may suit different customers' needs.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      With the exception of
      <a href="/wiki/Tesla_Motors" title="Tesla Motors">
       Tesla Motors
      </a>
      , demand for all-electric vehicles, especially in the U.S. market, has been driven by
      <a href="/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles" title="Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles">
       government incentives
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2016)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      In particular, American sales of the
      <a href="/wiki/Nissan_Leaf" title="Nissan Leaf">
       Nissan Leaf
      </a>
      have depended on generous incentives and special treatment in the
      <a href="/wiki/Georgia_(U.S._state)" title="Georgia (U.S. state)">
       state of Georgia
      </a>
      , the top selling Leaf market.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166">
       <a href="#cite_note-166">
        [166]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to international market research, 60% of respondents believe a battery driving range of less than 160 km (99 mi) is unacceptable even though only 2% drive more than that distance per day.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167">
       <a href="#cite_note-167">
        [167]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Among popular current all-electric vehicles, only the Tesla (with the most expensive version of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Model_S" title="Model S">
       Model S
      </a>
      offering a 265 miles (426 km) range in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="U.S. Environmental Protection Agency">
       U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
      </a>
      5-cycle test) significantly exceeds this threshold. The Nissan Leaf has an EPA rated range of 75 miles (121 km) for the 2013 model year.
     </p>
     <p>
      Plug-in hybrids provide the extended range and potential for refueling of conventional hybrids while enabling drivers to utilize battery electric power for at least a significant part of their typical daily driving. The average trip to or from work in the United States in 2009 was 11.8 miles (19.0 km),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168">
       <a href="#cite_note-168">
        [168]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while the average distance commuted to work in England and Wales in 2011 was slightly lower at 9.3 miles (15 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169">
       <a href="#cite_note-169">
        [169]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since building a PHEV with a longer all-electric range adds weight and cost, and reduces cargo and/or passenger space, there is not a specific all-electric range that is optimal. The accompanying graph shows the observed all-electric range, in miles, for four popular U.S. market plug-in hybrids, as tested by
      <a href="/wiki/Popular_Mechanics" title="Popular Mechanics">
       Popular Mechanics
      </a>
      magazine.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170">
       <a href="#cite_note-170">
        [170]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A key design parameter of the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      was a target of 40 miles (64 km) for the
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      , selected to keep the battery size small and lower costs, and mainly because research showed that 78% of daily
      <a href="/wiki/Commuting" title="Commuting">
       commuters
      </a>
      in the U.S. travel 40 mi (64 km) or less. This target range would allow most travel to be accomplished electrically driven and the assumption was made that charging will take place at home overnight. This requirement translated using a
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery" title="Lithium-ion battery">
       lithium-ion battery
      </a>
      pack with an energy storage capacity of 16
      <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt_hour" title="Kilowatt hour">
       kWh
      </a>
      considering that the battery would be used until the
      <a href="/wiki/State_of_charge" title="State of charge">
       state of charge
      </a>
      (SOC) of the battery reached 30%.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171">
       <a href="#cite_note-171">
        [171]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172">
       <a href="#cite_note-172">
        [172]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In October 2014 General Motors reported, based on data collected through its
      <a href="/wiki/OnStar" title="OnStar">
       OnStar
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Telematics" title="Telematics">
       telematics
      </a>
      system since Volt deliveries began, and with over 1 billion miles (1.6 billion km) traveled, that Volt owners drive about 62.5% of their trips in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173">
       <a href="#cite_note-173">
        [173]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In May 2016, Ford reported, based on data collected from more than 610 million miles (976 million km) logged by its electrified vehicles through its telematics system, that drivers of these vehicles run an average of 13,500 miles (21,700 km) annually on their vehicles, with about half of those miles operating in all-electric mode. A break down of these figures show an average daily commute of 42 mi (68 km) for Ford Energi plug-in hybrid drivers. Ford notes that with the enhanced electric range of the 2017 model year model, the average
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_Fusion_Energi" title="Ford Fusion Energi">
       Fusion Energi
      </a>
      commuter could go the entire day using no gasoline, if the car is fully charged both, before leaving for work and before leaving for home. According to Ford data, currently most customers are likely charging their vehicles only at home.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174">
       <a href="#cite_note-174">
        [174]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The 2015 edition of the EPA's annual report "
      <i>
       Light-Duty Automotive Technology, Carbon Dioxide Emissions, and Fuel Economy Trends
      </i>
      " estimates the following utility factors for 2015
      <a href="/wiki/Model_year" title="Model year">
       model year
      </a>
      plug-in hybrids to represent the percentage of miles that will be driven using electricity by an average driver, whether in electric only or blended modes: 83% for the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_i3_REx" title="BMW i3 REx">
       BMW i3 REx
      </a>
      , 66% for the Chevrolet Volt, 45% for the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_Fusion_Energi" title="Ford Fusion Energi">
       Ford Energi models
      </a>
      , 43% for the
      <a href="/wiki/McLaren_P1" title="McLaren P1">
       McLaren P1
      </a>
      , 37% for the
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_i8" title="BMW i8">
       BMW i8
      </a>
      , and 29% for the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_PHV" title="Toyota Prius PHV">
       Toyota Prius PHV
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPAtrends2015_175-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPAtrends2015-175">
        [175]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A 2014 analysis conducted by the
      <a href="/wiki/Idaho_National_Laboratory" title="Idaho National Laboratory">
       Idaho National Laboratory
      </a>
      using a sample of 21,600 all-electric cars and plug-in hybrids, found that Volt owners traveled on average 9,112 miles in all-electric mode (e-miles) per year, while Leaf owners traveled 9,697 e-miles per year, despite the Volt's shorter
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      , about half of the Leaf's.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176">
       <a href="#cite_note-176">
        [176]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Between January and August 2014, a period during which US sales of conventional hybrids slowed, US sales of plug-in hybrids grew from 28,241 to 40,748 compared to the same period in 2013. US sales of all-electric vehicles also grew during the same period: from 29,917 vehicles in the January to August 2013 period to 40,349 in January to August 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177">
       <a href="#cite_note-177">
        [177]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Advantages">
       Advantages
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Advantages">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Fuel_efficiency_and_petroleum_displacement">
       Fuel efficiency and petroleum displacement
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Fuel efficiency and petroleum displacement">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main articles:
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_conversion_efficiency" title="Energy conversion efficiency">
       Energy conversion efficiency
      </a>
      and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Well-to-wheel" title="Well-to-wheel">
       Well-to-wheel
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Erev_PHEVseries_98mpg_500px.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="322" data-file-width="500" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Erev_PHEVseries_98mpg_500px.jpg/220px-Erev_PHEVseries_98mpg_500px.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Erev_PHEVseries_98mpg_500px.jpg/330px-Erev_PHEVseries_98mpg_500px.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Erev_PHEVseries_98mpg_500px.jpg/440px-Erev_PHEVseries_98mpg_500px.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Typical
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_and_environment_label" title="Fuel economy and environment label">
          fuel economy label
         </a>
         for
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
          series
         </a>
         plug-in hybrid or extended range electric vehicle
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Phev-blended_paralell_65mpge_500px.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="322" data-file-width="500" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Phev-blended_paralell_65mpge_500px.jpg/220px-Phev-blended_paralell_65mpge_500px.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Phev-blended_paralell_65mpge_500px.jpg/330px-Phev-blended_paralell_65mpge_500px.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0a/Phev-blended_paralell_65mpge_500px.jpg/440px-Phev-blended_paralell_65mpge_500px.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Typical
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_and_environment_label" title="Fuel economy and environment label">
          fuel economy label
         </a>
         for blended or
         <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle_drivetrain#Power-split_or_series-parallel_hybrid" title="Hybrid vehicle drivetrain">
          series-parallel
         </a>
         plug-in hybrid
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Each
      <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt_hour" title="Kilowatt hour">
       kilowatt hour
      </a>
      of battery capacity in use will displace up to 50 U.S. gallons (190 l; 42 imp gal) of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Petroleum_fuel" title="Petroleum fuel">
       petroleum fuels
      </a>
      per year (gasoline or diesel fuels).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178">
       <a href="#cite_note-178">
        [178]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Also, electricity is multi-sourced and, as a result, it gives the greatest degree of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_resilience" title="Energy resilience">
       energy resilience
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179">
       <a href="#cite_note-179">
        [179]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The actual
      <a href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles" title="Fuel economy in automobiles">
       fuel economy
      </a>
      for PHEVs depends on their powertrain operating modes, their all-electric range, and the amount of driving between charges. If no gasoline is used the
      <a href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_gasoline_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon gasoline equivalent">
       miles per gallon gasoline equivalent
      </a>
      (MPG-e) depends only on the efficiency of the electric system. The first
      <a href="/wiki/Mass_production" title="Mass production">
       mass production
      </a>
      PHEV available in the U.S. market, the 2011
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      , with an EPA rated
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 35 miles (56 km), and an additional gasoline-only extended range of 344 miles (554 km) has an EPA combined city/highway fuel economy of 93 MPG-e in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      , and 37 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      (6.4 L/100 km; 44 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ) in gasoline-only mode, for an overall combined gas-electric fuel economy rating of 60 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      (3.9 L/100 km; 72 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ) equivalent (MPG-e).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPAmpge_180-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPAmpge-180">
        [180]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCCEPAVolt_181-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCCEPAVolt-181">
        [181]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The EPA also included in the Volt's
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_label" title="Fuel economy label">
       fuel economy label
      </a>
      a table showing fuel economy and electricity consumed for five different scenarios: 30, 45, 60 and 75 miles (121 km) driven between a full charge, and a never charge scenario.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCCEPAVolt_181-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCCEPAVolt-181">
        [181]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to this table the fuel economy goes up to 168 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      (1.40 L/100 km; 202 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ) equivalent (MPG-e) with 45 miles (72 km) driven between full charges.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPAmpge_180-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPAmpge-180">
        [180]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      For the more comprehensive
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_and_environment_label" title="Fuel economy and environment label">
       fuel economy and environment label
      </a>
      that will be mandatory in the U.S. beginning in
      <a href="/wiki/Model_year" title="Model year">
       model year
      </a>
      2013, the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Highway_Traffic_Safety_Administration" title="National Highway Traffic Safety Administration">
       National Highway Traffic Safety Administration
      </a>
      (NHTSA) and
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="United States Environmental Protection Agency">
       Environmental Protection Agency
      </a>
      (EPA) issued two separate fuel economy labels for plug-in hybrids because of their design complexity, as PHEVS can operate in two or three operating modes: all-electric, blended, and gasoline-only.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC2013_182-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC2013-182">
        [182]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA2013_183-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPA2013-183">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
      One label is for
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
       series hybrid
      </a>
      or extended range electric vehicle (like the Chevy Volt), with all-electric and gasoline-only modes; and a second label for blended mode or
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle_drivetrain#Power-split_or_series-parallel_hybrid" title="Hybrid vehicle drivetrain">
       series-parallel hybrid
      </a>
      , that includes a combination of both gasoline and plug-in electric operation; and gasoline only, like a
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
       conventional hybrid vehicle
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC2013_182-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC2013-182">
        [182]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA2013_183-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPA2013-183">
        [183]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Google%27s_RechargeIT_charging_garage_2009.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2840" data-file-width="1893" height="300" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Google%27s_RechargeIT_charging_garage_2009.jpg/200px-Google%27s_RechargeIT_charging_garage_2009.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Google%27s_RechargeIT_charging_garage_2009.jpg/300px-Google%27s_RechargeIT_charging_garage_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Google%27s_RechargeIT_charging_garage_2009.jpg/400px-Google%27s_RechargeIT_charging_garage_2009.jpg 2x" width="200"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Google%27s_RechargeIT_charging_garage_2009.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        RechargeIT
        <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
         charging stations
        </a>
        available in the garage designated for converted plug-in hybrids at Google's Mountain View campus.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      A further advantage of PHEVs is that they have potential to be even more efficient than conventional hybrids because a more limited use of the PHEV's internal combustion engine may allow the engine to be used at closer to its maximum efficiency. While a Prius is likely to convert fuel to motive energy on average at about 30% efficiency (well below the engine's 38% peak efficiency) the engine of a PHEV-70 would be likely to operate far more often near its peak efficiency because the batteries can serve the modest power needs at times when the combustion engine would be forced to run well below its peak efficiency.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-energy_131-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-energy-131">
        [131]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The actual efficiency achieved depends on losses from electricity generation, inversion, battery charging/discharging, the motor controller and motor itself, the way a vehicle is used (its
      <a href="/wiki/Duty_cycle" title="Duty cycle">
       duty cycle
      </a>
      ), and the opportunities to recharge by connecting to the electrical grid.
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Society_of_Automotive_Engineers" title="Society of Automotive Engineers">
       Society of Automotive Engineers
      </a>
      (SAE) developed their recommended practice in 1999 for testing and reporting the fuel economy of hybrid vehicles and included language to address PHEVs. An SAE committee is currently working to review procedures for testing and reporting the fuel economy of PHEVs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184">
       <a href="#cite_note-184">
        [184]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Toronto Atmospheric Fund tested ten retrofitted plug-in hybrid vehicles that achieved an average of 5.8 litres per 100 kilometre or 40.6 miles per gallon over six months in 2008, which was considered below the technology's potential.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hamilton_185-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-hamilton-185">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      PHEV batteries also allow for an additional efficiency when converting solar power directly into a DC storage system, as opposed to converting the energy into AC home or building. DC to DC direct conversion is more efficient, therefore, potentially allowing the more efficient capture of solar energy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Johnson_186-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Johnson-186">
        [186]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In real world testing using normal drivers, some Prius PHEV conversions may not achieve much better fuel economy than HEVs. For example, a plug-in Prius fleet, each with a 30 miles (48 km) all-electric range, averaged only 51 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      (4.6 L/100 km; 61 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ) in a 17,000-mile (27,000 km) test in Seattle,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187">
       <a href="#cite_note-187">
        [187]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and similar results with the same kind of conversion battery models at
      <a href="/wiki/Google.org" title="Google.org">
       Google
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/RechargeIT" title="RechargeIT">
       RechargeIT
      </a>
      initiative. Moreover, the additional battery pack costs
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$10,000
      </span>
      –
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$11,000
      </span>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188">
       <a href="#cite_note-188">
        [188]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189">
       <a href="#cite_note-189">
        [189]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Operating_costs">
       Operating costs
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Operating costs">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The following table compares EPA's estimated out-of-pocket fuel costs and fuel economy ratings of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Serial_production" title="Serial production">
       serial production
      </a>
      <strong class="selflink">
       plug-in hybrid electric vehicles
      </strong>
      rated by EPA as of October 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      expressed in
      <a href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_gasoline_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon gasoline equivalent">
       miles per gallon gasoline equivalent
      </a>
      (mpg-e),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPAFEG2016MY_190-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPAFEG2016MY-190">
        [190]
       </a>
      </sup>
      versus the most fuel efficient
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
       gasoline-electric hybrid car
      </a>
      , the 2016
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius#Fourth_generation_.282015.E2.80.93present.29" title="Toyota Prius">
       Toyota Prius Eco (fourth generation)
      </a>
      , rated 56 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      (4.2 L/100 km; 67 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ), and EPA's average new 2016 vehicle, which has a fuel economy of 25 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      (9.4 L/100 km; 30 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPAFEG2016MY_190-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPAFEG2016MY-190">
        [190]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA2015Best_191-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPA2015Best-191">
        [191]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA2015_16Prius_192-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPA2015_16Prius-192">
        [192]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The table also shows the fuel efficiency for plug-in hybrids in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      expressed as KWh/100 mile, the metric used by EPA to rate electric cars before November 2010.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EVN2009_193-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EVN2009-193">
        [193]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="8" style="text-align:center; background:#cfc;">

         <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
          [update]
         </a>
        </sup>
        with MPGe and conventional MPG
        <sup>
         (1)
        </sup>
        <br/>
        (as displayed in the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monroney_label" title="Monroney label">
         Monroney label
        </a>
        and the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Energy" title="U.S. Department of Energy">
         US DoE
        </a>
        fueleconomy.gov website)
       </th>
      </tr>

         <br/>

         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">

         </a>
         (EV mode).
         <br/>
         The Prime runs entirely on electricity in
         <br/>
         EV mode in more situations.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriusPrime3_118-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-PriusPrime3-118">
           [118]
          </a>
         </sup>

         <br/>
         is not available yet.
        </small>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr style="text-align:center;">
       <td>
        Gasoline only
       </td>
       <td>
        54 mpg
       </td>
       <td>
        55 mpg/
        <br/>
        53 mpg
       </td>
       <td>
        -
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr style="text-align:center;">
       <td rowspan="2" style="text-align:left;">
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_i3_REx" title="BMW i3 REx">
         BMW i3 REx
        </a>
        (60
        <a href="/wiki/Ampere-hour" title="Ampere-hour">
         A·h
        </a>
        )
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA2015_194-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-EPA2015-194">
          [194]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPAi3REx_195-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-EPAi3REx-195">
          [195]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </td>
       <td rowspan="2">
        2014
        <br/>
        2015
        <br/>
        2016
       </td>
       <td>
        Electricity only
        <br/>
        (72 mi)
       </td>
       <td>
        117 mpg-e
        <br/>
        (29 kWh/100 mi)
       </td>
       <td>
        97 mpg-e (35 kW·h/100 mi)/
        <br/>
        79 mpg-e (44 kW·h/100 mi)
       </td>
       <td>
        $0.94
       </td>
       <td rowspan="2">
        $650
       </td>
       <td rowspan="2" style="text-align:left;">
        <small>
         The EPA classifies the i3 REx as a
         <br/>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
          series
         </a>
         <strong class="selflink">
          plug-in hybrid
         </strong>
         while
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/CARB" title="CARB">
          CARB
         </a>
         as a
         <br/>
         <a href="/wiki/Range_extender_(vehicle)#CARB_regulation" title="Range extender (vehicle)">
          range-extended battery-electric vehicle
         </a>
         (BEVx).
         <br/>
         The 2014/16 i3 REx is the most fuel efficient
         <br/>
         EPA-certified current year vehicle with
         <br/>
         a gasoline engine with a combined
         <br/>
         gasoline/electricity rating of 88 mpg-e
         <br/>
         (city 97 mpg-e/hwy 79 mpg-e).

       </td>

         <br/>
         as it consumes 0.1 gallons per 100 mi
         <br/>
         in EV mode (
         <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
          all-electric range
         </a>
         = 0 mi)

         <br/>
         operation of 37 mpg-e.
