       <td colspan="8" style="text-align:left; background:#cfc;">
        <small>
         Notes: (1) Based on 45% highway and 55% city driving. Electricity cost of
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$0.13
         </span>
         /kWh, premium gasoline price of
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$2.51
         </span>
         per gallon (used by the 2015 Volt, i3 REx, ELR, i8, Mercedes S500e, Karma and all Porsche models), and regular gasoline price of
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$2.04
         </span>
         per gallon (as of 18 December 2015
         <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
          <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
           [update]
          </a>
         </sup>
         ). Conversion 1 gallon of gasoline=33.7 kWh.
        </small>
       </td>

     <p>
      A study published in 2014 by researchers from
      <a href="/wiki/Lamar_University" title="Lamar University">
       Lamar University
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Iowa_State_University" title="Iowa State University">
       Iowa State University
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Oak_Ridge_National_Laboratory" title="Oak Ridge National Laboratory">
       Oak Ridge National Laboratory
      </a>
      compared the operating costs of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles (PHEVs) of various electric ranges (10, 20, 30, and 40 miles) with conventional gasoline vehicles and hybrid-electric vehicles (HEVs) for different payback periods, considering different charging infrastructure deployment levels and gasoline prices. The study concluded that:
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224">
       <a href="#cite_note-224">
        [224]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       PHEVs save around 60% or 40% in energy costs, compared with conventional gasoline vehicles and HEVs, respectively. However, for drivers with significant daily vehicle miles traveled (DVMT), hybrid vehicles may be even a better choice than plug-in hybrids with a range of 40 mi (64 km), particularly when there is lack of public charging infrastructure.
      </li>
      <li>
       The incremental battery cost of large-battery plug-in hybrids is difficult to justify based on the incremental savings of PHEVs’ operating costs unless a subsidy is offered for large-battery PHEVs.
      </li>
      <li>
       When the price of gasoline increases from
       <span style="white-space: nowrap">
        US$4
       </span>
       per gallon to
       <span style="white-space: nowrap">
        US$5
       </span>
       per gallon, the number of drivers who benefit from a larger battery increases significantly. If the gas price is
       <span style="white-space: nowrap">
        US$3
       </span>
       , a plug-in hybrid with a range of 10 mi (16 km) is the least costly option even if the battery cost is $200/kW.
      </li>
      <li>
       Although
       <a href="/wiki/Charging_station#DC_charging_stations_.28fast.29" title="Charging station">
        quick chargers
       </a>
       can reduce charging time, they contribute little to energy cost savings for PHEVs, as opposed to
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Level_1,_2,_and_3_charging" title="Level 1, 2, and 3 charging">
        Level-2 chargers
       </a>
       .
      </li>
     </ul>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Range_anxiety_elimination">
       Range anxiety elimination
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Range anxiety elimination">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FedEx_Hybrid_Sprinter.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="331" data-file-width="514" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/FedEx_Hybrid_Sprinter.jpg/220px-FedEx_Hybrid_Sprinter.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/FedEx_Hybrid_Sprinter.jpg/330px-FedEx_Hybrid_Sprinter.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/FedEx_Hybrid_Sprinter.jpg/440px-FedEx_Hybrid_Sprinter.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:FedEx_Hybrid_Sprinter.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Former President
        <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">
         George W. Bush
        </a>
        is shown the PHEV
        <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_Sprinter" title="Mercedes-Benz Sprinter">
         Mercedes-Benz Sprinter
        </a>
        van in the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Postal_Service" title="US Postal Service">
         US Postal Service
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Range_anxiety" title="Range anxiety">
       Range anxiety
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      One of the main barriers for the general adoption of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_car" title="All-electric car">
       all-electric cars
      </a>
      is the
      <a href="/wiki/Range_anxiety" title="Range anxiety">
       range anxiety
      </a>
      factor, the driver's fear of being
      <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/stranded" title="wikt:stranded">
       stranded
      </a>
      by a
      <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/depleted" title="wikt:depleted">
       depleted
      </a>
      battery before reaching the final destination.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DiscoveyG_225-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-DiscoveyG-225">
        [225]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226">
       <a href="#cite_note-226">
        [226]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Plug-in hybrids, as opposed to pure electric cars, eliminate the range anxiety concerns because the gasoline engine serves as a back-up to recharge the battery to provide electric power to the electric motor, or to provide propulsion directly. Access to a regular fuel station guarantees that a PHEV has similar driving ranges as conventional gasoline-powered automobile.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DiscoveyG_225-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-DiscoveyG-225">
        [225]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227">
       <a href="#cite_note-227">
        [227]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      As of 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , there are five plug-in hybrids in the European market capable of driving around 50 km (31 mi) (under
      <a href="/wiki/New_European_Driving_Cycle" title="New European Driving Cycle">
       NEDC
      </a>
      cycle) on the battery alone, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Audi_A3_e-tron" title="Audi A3 e-tron">
       Audi A3 e-tron
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Outlander_P-HEV" title="Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV">
       Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf_GTE" title="Volkswagen Golf GTE">
       Volkswagen Golf GTE
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Passat_GTE" title="Volkswagen Passat GTE">
       Volkswagen Passat GTE
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid">
       Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228">
       <a href="#cite_note-228">
        [228]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other models with larger
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      are the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Cadillac_ELR" title="Cadillac ELR">
       Cadillac ELR
      </a>
      , sold in the U.S. and Canada, and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_i3_REx" title="BMW i3 REx">
       BMW i3 REx
      </a>
      , available in 49 countries.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BMWi2yrs_229-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BMWi2yrs-229">
        [229]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MA0710_230-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MA0710-230">
        [230]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BMW_i3_(19939421151).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2304" data-file-width="3072" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/BMW_i3_%2819939421151%29.jpg/220px-BMW_i3_%2819939421151%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/BMW_i3_%2819939421151%29.jpg/330px-BMW_i3_%2819939421151%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/83/BMW_i3_%2819939421151%29.jpg/440px-BMW_i3_%2819939421151%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BMW_i3_(19939421151).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_i3_REx" title="BMW i3 REx">
         BMW i3 REx
        </a>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      As a response to range anxiety concerns, BMW is offering an optional limited capability gasoline
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Range_extender" title="Range extender">
       range extender
      </a>
      engine for its all-electric
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_i3" title="BMW i3">
       BMW i3
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MA0710_230-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-MA0710-230">
        [230]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The range-extender option costs an additional
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$3,850
      </span>
      in the United States,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT072013_231-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT072013-231">
        [231]
       </a>
      </sup>
      €4,710 (~
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$6,300
      </span>
      ) in France,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232">
       <a href="#cite_note-232">
        [232]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and €4,490 (~
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$6,000
      </span>
      ) in the Netherlands.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233">
       <a href="#cite_note-233">
        [233]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The range-extender option of the BMW i3 was designed to meet the
      <a href="/wiki/California_Air_Resources_Board" title="California Air Resources Board">
       California Air Resources Board
      </a>
      (CARB) regulation for an auxiliary power unit (APU) called REx. According to rules adopted in March 2012 by CARB, the 2014 BMW i3 with a REx unit fitted will be the first car to qualify as a
      <a href="/wiki/Range_extender_(vehicle)#CARB_regulation" title="Range extender (vehicle)">
       range-extended battery-electric vehicle
      </a>
      or "BEVx." CARB describes this type of electric vehicle as "a relatively high-electric range battery-electric vehicle (BEV) to which an APU is added." The unit, which maintains battery charge at about 30% after the pack has been depleted in normal use, is strictly limited in the additional range it can provide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BEVx_234-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BEVx-234">
        [234]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      According to BMW, at the beginning of the i3 release, the use of range-extender was much more than the carmaker expected, more than 60%. Over time it has decreased significantly, with some people almost never using it, and by 2016 it is being regularly used in fewer than 5% of i3s.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-i5_235-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-i5-235">
        [235]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In early October 2014, General Motors reported, based on data collected through its
      <a href="/wiki/OnStar" title="OnStar">
       OnStar
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Telematics" title="Telematics">
       telematics
      </a>
      system, that Volt owners in North America have accumulated a total of 1 billion miles (1.6 billion km) traveled, of which, about 62.5% were driven in all-electric mode.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236">
       <a href="#cite_note-236">
        [236]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A similar report, issued by GM in August 2016, reported that Volt owners have accumulated almost 1.5 billion miles (2.4 billion km) driven in EV mode, representing 60% of their total miles traveled.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt100Kmilestone_237-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt100Kmilestone-237">
        [237]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In a study published in June 2016, conducted by the Norwegian
      <a href="/wiki/Institute_of_Transport_Economics" title="Institute of Transport Economics">
       Institute of Transport Economics
      </a>
      , the researchers found that plug-in hybrid owners in Norway drive on average 55% of their annual distance in charge-depleting or all-electric mode (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/EV_mode" title="EV mode">
       EV mode
      </a>
      ), and the share goes up to about 63% for work trips. The share of electric travel is higher for trips to work and in the summer, and lower in the winter. The average plug-in hybrid user in the survey drives 60% of the total distance in EV mode in the summer and 53% in winter. The estimate for work trips is higher at 70% in the summer and 59% in winter.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TOI2016_238-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TOI2016-238">
        [238]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      One of the advantages of the plug-in hybrid design is that the generator can be completely decoupled from the traction. Unlike a conventional engine, which operates over a wide variety of power settings and operational conditions, the range extender can be operated under optimum conditions at all times. High-efficiency power sources that are not suitable for normal automotive use may be perfectly suitable for PEV use. These include advanced close-cycle steam engines,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stirling_engines" title="Stirling engines">
       stirling engines
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Wankel_engine" title="Wankel engine">
       Wankel engines
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Gas_turbine#Microturbines" title="Gas turbine">
       microturbines
      </a>
      due primarily to their light weight and small size.
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2016)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Smog">
       Smog
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Smog">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Ontario_Medical_Association" title="Ontario Medical Association">
       Ontario Medical Association
      </a>
      announced that
      <a href="/wiki/Smog" title="Smog">
       smog
      </a>
      is responsible for an estimated 9,500 premature deaths in its province every year.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239">
       <a href="#cite_note-239">
        [239]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Plug-in hybrids in emission-free electric mode may contribute to the reduction of smog.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hamilton_185-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-hamilton-185">
        [185]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Vehicle-to-grid_electricity">
       Vehicle-to-grid electricity
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Vehicle-to-grid electricity">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Vehicle-to-grid" title="Vehicle-to-grid">
       Vehicle-to-grid
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      PHEVs and fully electric cars may allow for more efficient use of existing electric production capacity, much of which sits idle as
      <a href="/wiki/Operating_reserve" title="Operating reserve">
       operating reserve
      </a>
      most of the time. This assumes that vehicles are charged primarily during
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Off_peak" title="Off peak">
       off peak
      </a>
      periods (i.e., at night), or equipped with technology to shut off charging during periods of peak demand. Another advantage of a plug-in vehicle is their potential ability to load balance or help the grid during peak loads. This is accomplished with
      <a href="/wiki/Vehicle-to-grid" title="Vehicle-to-grid">
       vehicle-to-grid
      </a>
      technology. By using excess battery capacity to send power back into the grid and then recharge during off peak times using cheaper power, such vehicles are actually advantageous to utilities as well as their owners. Even if such vehicles just led to an increase in the use of nighttime electricity they would even out electricity demand which is typically higher in the daytime, and provide a greater return on capital for electricity infrastructure.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reduct_23-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-reduct-23">
        [23]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In the UK, VTG would need to comply with generation connection standard "G59/2", which means that it would need an earth rod at the premises, and would be unable to export more than 17 kW without the network firm's permission (which feeding onto one phase, i.e. for a normal house, would not be given - to maintain a balance of load across the three phases).
     </p>
     <p>
      In October 2005, five Toyota engineers and one Asian AW engineer published an
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IEEE" title="IEEE">
       IEEE
      </a>
      technical paper detailing a Toyota-approved project to add vehicle-to-grid capability to a Toyota Prius.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240">
       <a href="#cite_note-240">
        [240]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although the technical paper described "a method for generating voltage between respective lines of neutral points in the generator and motor of the THS-II (Toyota Hybrid System) to add a function for generating electricity", it did not state whether or not the experimental vehicle could be charged through the circuit, as well. However, the vehicle was featured in a Toyota Dream House, and a brochure for the exhibit stated that "the house can supply electricity to the battery packs of the vehicles via the stand in the middle of the garage", indicating that the vehicle may have been a plug-in hybrid.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241">
       <a href="#cite_note-241">
        [241]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_Edison_Electric_Vehicle_Technical_Center_3-19-09.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="350" data-file-width="525" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Barack_Obama_at_Edison_Electric_Vehicle_Technical_Center_3-19-09.jpg/220px-Barack_Obama_at_Edison_Electric_Vehicle_Technical_Center_3-19-09.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Barack_Obama_at_Edison_Electric_Vehicle_Technical_Center_3-19-09.jpg/330px-Barack_Obama_at_Edison_Electric_Vehicle_Technical_Center_3-19-09.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Barack_Obama_at_Edison_Electric_Vehicle_Technical_Center_3-19-09.jpg/440px-Barack_Obama_at_Edison_Electric_Vehicle_Technical_Center_3-19-09.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Barack_Obama_at_Edison_Electric_Vehicle_Technical_Center_3-19-09.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        U.S. President
        <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
         Barack Obama
        </a>
        examines hybrid vehicles in the Edison Electric Vehicle Technical Center in
        <a href="/wiki/Pomona,_California" title="Pomona, California">
         Pomona, California
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      In November 2005, more than 50 leaders from public power utility companies across the United States met at the
      <a href="/wiki/Los_Angeles_Department_of_Water_and_Power" title="Los Angeles Department of Water and Power">
       Los Angeles Department of Water and Power
      </a>
      headquarters to discuss plug-in hybrid and vehicle-to-grid technology. The event, which was sponsored by the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Public_Power_Association" title="American Public Power Association">
       American Public Power Association
      </a>
      , also provided an opportunity for association members to plan strategies that public power utility companies could use to promote plug-in hybrid technology. Greg Hanssen and Peter Nortman of EnergyCS and EDrive attended the two-day session, and during a break in the proceedings, made an impromptu display in the LADWP parking lot of their converted Prius plug-in hybrid.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242">
       <a href="#cite_note-242">
        [242]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In September 2006, the
      <a href="/wiki/California_Air_Resources_Board" title="California Air Resources Board">
       California Air Resources Board
      </a>
      held a Zero Emission Vehicle symposium that included several presentations on
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/V2G" title="V2G">
       V2G
      </a>
      technology.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243">
       <a href="#cite_note-243">
        [243]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In April 2007,
      <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Gas_and_Electric_Company" title="Pacific Gas and Electric Company">
       Pacific Gas and Electric Company
      </a>
      showcased a PHEV at the Silicon Valley Leadership Alternative Energy Solutions Summit with vehicle-to-grid capability, and demonstrated that it could be used as a source of emergency home power in the event of an electrical power failure.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244">
       <a href="#cite_note-244">
        [244]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Regulations intended to protect electricians against power other than from grid sources would need to be changed, or regulations requiring consumers to disconnect from the grid when connected to non-grid sources will be required before such backup power solutions would be feasible.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pge_245-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-pge-245">
        [245]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/Jon_Wellinghoff" title="Jon Wellinghoff">
       Jon Wellinghoff
      </a>
      , from the US
      <a href="/wiki/Federal_Energy_Regulatory_Commission" title="Federal Energy Regulatory Commission">
       Federal Energy Regulatory Commission
      </a>
      , coined the term "Cash-Back Hybrids" to describe payments to car owners for putting their batteries on the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Power_grid" title="Power grid">
       power grid
      </a>
      . Batteries could also be offered in low-cost
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leasing" title="Leasing">
       leasing
      </a>
      or
      <a href="/wiki/Renting" title="Renting">
       renting
      </a>
      or by
      <a href="/wiki/Donation" title="Donation">
       donation
      </a>
      (including maintenance) to the car owners by the public utilities, in a vehicle-to-grid agreement.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246">
       <a href="#cite_note-246">
        [246]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Disadvantages">
       Disadvantages
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Disadvantages">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Cost_of_batteries">
       Cost of batteries
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Cost of batteries">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_battery" title="Electric vehicle battery">
       Electric vehicle battery
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Disadvantages of plug-in hybrids include the additional cost, weight, and size of a larger
      <a href="/wiki/Battery_pack" title="Battery pack">
       battery pack
      </a>
      . According to a 2010 study by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_States_National_Research_Council" title="United States National Research Council">
       National Research Council
      </a>
      , the cost of a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lithium-ion" title="Lithium-ion">
       lithium-ion
      </a>
      battery pack is about
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$1,700
      </span>
      /
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/KW%C2%B7h" title="KW·h">
       kW·h
      </a>
      of usable energy, and considering that a PHEV-10 requires about 2.0 kW·h and a PHEV-40 about 8 kW·h, the manufacturer cost of the battery pack for a PHEV-10 is around
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$3,000
      </span>
      and it goes up to
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$14,000
      </span>
      for a PHEV-40.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NRC09_1_247-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NRC09_1-247">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT1209_248-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT1209-248">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to the same study, even though costs are expected to decline by 35% by 2020, market penetration is expected to be slow and therefore PHEVs are not expected to significantly impact oil consumption or carbon emissions before 2030, unless a fundamental breakthrough in battery technologies occurs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NRC09_1_247-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NRC09_1-247">
        [247]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT1209_248-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT1209-248">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NRC09_2_249-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NRC09_2-249">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="8" style="text-align:center; background:#cfc;">
        Cost comparison between a PHEV-10 and a PHEV-40
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NRC09_1_247-2">
         <a href="#cite_note-NRC09_1-247">
          [247]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NRC09_2_249-1">
         <a href="#cite_note-NRC09_2-249">
          [249]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <br/>
        (prices for 2010)
       </th>
      </tr>

        <center>

          <a href="/wiki/Mid-size_car" title="Mid-size car">
           mid-size
          </a>
         </b>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td style="background:#cfc;">
        <center>
         <b>
          Cost of
          <br/>

         </b>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td style="background:#cfc;">
        <center>
         <b>
          Cost of
          <br/>

          <br/>
          upgrade at home
         </b>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td style="background:#cfc;">
        <center>

          <br/>

          <br/>
          savings
          <br/>
          compared
          <br/>

          <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
           HEV
          </a>
         </b>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td style="background:#cfc;">
        <center>
         <b>
          Annual
          <br/>
          gasoline
          <br/>
          savings
          <br/>

          <br/>
