          <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
           HEV
          </a>
          <sup>
           (2)
          </sup>
         </b>
        </center>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        PHEV-10
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid">
          Prius Plug-in
         </a>
         <sup>
          (1)
         </sup>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Parallel_hybrid" title="Parallel hybrid">
          Parallel
         </a>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$6,300
         </span>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$3,300
         </span>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         More than
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$1,000
         </span>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         20%
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         70 gallons
        </center>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        PHEV-40
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chevy_Volt" title="Chevy Volt">
          Chevy Volt
         </a>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">
          Series
         </a>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$18,100
         </span>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$14,000
         </span>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         More than
         <span style="white-space: nowrap">
          US$1,000
         </span>
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         55%
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         200 gallons
        </center>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td colspan="8" style="text-align:left;">
        <small>
         Notes: (1) Considers the
         <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
          HEV
         </a>
         technology used in the
         <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
          Toyota Prius
         </a>
         with a larger battery pack. The Prius Plug-in estimated
         <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
          all-electric range
         </a>
         is 14.5 mi (23 km)
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT122009_250-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-NYT122009-250">
           [250]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <br/>
         (2) Assuming 15,000 miles per year.
        </small>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      According to the 2010 NRC study, although a mile driven on electricity is cheaper than one driven on gasoline, lifetime fuel savings are not enough to offset plug-ins high upfront costs, and it will take decades before the break even point is achieved.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NRC09_2_249-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NRC09_2-249">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Furthermore, hundreds of billions of dollars in government subsidies and incentives are likely to be required to achieve a rapid plug-in market penetration in the U.S.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT1209_248-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT1209-248">
        [248]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NRC09_2_249-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-NRC09_2-249">
        [249]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A 2013 study by the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Council_for_an_Energy-Efficient_Economy" title="American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy">
       American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy
      </a>
      reported that battery costs came down from
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$1,300
      </span>
      per kilowatt hour in 2007 to
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$500
      </span>
      per kilowatt hour in 2012. The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Energy" title="U.S. Department of Energy">
       U.S. Department of Energy
      </a>
      has set cost targets for its sponsored battery research of
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$300
      </span>
      per kilowatt hour in 2015 and
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$125
      </span>
      per kilowatt hour by 2022. Cost reductions through advances in battery technology and higher production volumes will allow plug-in electric vehicles to be more competitive with conventional internal combustion engine vehicles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251">
       <a href="#cite_note-251">
        [251]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A study published in 2011 by the
      <a href="/wiki/Belfer_Center_for_Science_and_International_Affairs" title="Belfer Center for Science and International Affairs">
       Belfer Center
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Harvard_University" title="Harvard University">
       Harvard University
      </a>
      , found that the gasoline costs savings of
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_car" title="Plug-in electric car">
       plug-in electric cars
      </a>
      over the vehicles’ lifetimes do not offset their higher purchase prices. This finding was estimated comparing their lifetime
      <a href="/wiki/Net_present_value" title="Net present value">
       net present value
      </a>
      at 2010 purchase and operating costs for the U.S. market, and assuming no
      <a href="/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#United_States" title="Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles">
       government subidies
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KSG11_252-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-KSG11-252">
        [252]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KSGpdf_253-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-KSGpdf-253">
        [253]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to the study estimates, a PHEV-40 is
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$5,377
      </span>
      more expensive than a conventional internal combustion engine, while a
      <a href="/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle" title="Battery electric vehicle">
       battery electric vehicle
      </a>
      (BEV) is
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$4,819
      </span>
      more expensive. The study also examined how this balance will change over the next 10 to 20 years, assuming that battery costs will decrease while gasoline prices increase. Under the future scenarios considered, the study found that BEVs will be significantly less expensive than conventional cars (
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$1,155
      </span>
      to
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$7,181
      </span>
      cheaper), while PHEVs, will be more expensive than BEVs in almost all comparison scenarios, and only less expensive than conventional cars in a scenario with very low battery costs and high gasoline prices. BEVs are simpler to build and do not use liquid fuel, while PHEVs have more complicated powertrains and still have gasoline-powered engines.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KSG11_252-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-KSG11-252">
        [252]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Lithium iron phosphate batteries from Valence Technologies
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254">
       <a href="#cite_note-254">
        [254]
       </a>
      </sup>
      were used in the first plug-in hybrids from
      <a href="/wiki/CalCars" title="CalCars">
       CalCars
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255">
       <a href="#cite_note-255">
        [255]
       </a>
      </sup>
      They are providing a conversion for the Toyota Prius priced at
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$12,000
      </span>
      . Hymotion also offers a conversion for
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$10,000
      </span>
      but their conversion is only 5 kW where Oemtek's is 9 kW.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256">
       <a href="#cite_note-256">
        [256]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Recharging_outside_home_garages">
       Recharging outside home garages
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Recharging outside home garages">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
       Charging station
      </a>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prius_RechargeIT_03_2008_at_Google%27s_campus.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2588" data-file-width="3888" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Prius_RechargeIT_03_2008_at_Google%27s_campus.jpg/220px-Prius_RechargeIT_03_2008_at_Google%27s_campus.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Prius_RechargeIT_03_2008_at_Google%27s_campus.jpg/330px-Prius_RechargeIT_03_2008_at_Google%27s_campus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5f/Prius_RechargeIT_03_2008_at_Google%27s_campus.jpg/440px-Prius_RechargeIT_03_2008_at_Google%27s_campus.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prius_RechargeIT_03_2008_at_Google%27s_campus.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        <a href="/wiki/RechargeIT" title="RechargeIT">
         RechargeIT
        </a>
        converted plug-in hybrids at
        <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">
         Google
        </a>
        's
        <a href="/wiki/Mountain_View,_California" title="Mountain View, California">
         Mountain View
        </a>
        campus. The garage has
        <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
         recharging facilities
        </a>
        powered by
        <a href="/wiki/Solar_panel" title="Solar panel">
         solar panels
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Charging_stations_in_SF_City_Hall_02_2009_02.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Charging_stations_in_SF_City_Hall_02_2009_02.jpg/220px-Charging_stations_in_SF_City_Hall_02_2009_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Charging_stations_in_SF_City_Hall_02_2009_02.jpg/330px-Charging_stations_in_SF_City_Hall_02_2009_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Charging_stations_in_SF_City_Hall_02_2009_02.jpg/440px-Charging_stations_in_SF_City_Hall_02_2009_02.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Charging_stations_in_SF_City_Hall_02_2009_02.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Three plug-in converted
        <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
         Toyota Prius
        </a>
        recharging at
        <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_City_Hall" title="San Francisco City Hall">
         San Francisco City Hall
        </a>
        public
        <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
         charging station
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:E-vehicle_charging_station_at_Hillsboro_Civic_Center_-_Oregon.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2423" data-file-width="2088" height="255" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/E-vehicle_charging_station_at_Hillsboro_Civic_Center_-_Oregon.JPG/220px-E-vehicle_charging_station_at_Hillsboro_Civic_Center_-_Oregon.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/E-vehicle_charging_station_at_Hillsboro_Civic_Center_-_Oregon.JPG/330px-E-vehicle_charging_station_at_Hillsboro_Civic_Center_-_Oregon.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/E-vehicle_charging_station_at_Hillsboro_Civic_Center_-_Oregon.JPG/440px-E-vehicle_charging_station_at_Hillsboro_Civic_Center_-_Oregon.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:E-vehicle_charging_station_at_Hillsboro_Civic_Center_-_Oregon.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        On-street
        <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
         electric charging unit
        </a>
        located at the
        <a href="/wiki/Hillsboro_Civic_Center" title="Hillsboro Civic Center">
         Hillsboro Civic Center
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Hillsboro,_Oregon" title="Hillsboro, Oregon">
         Hillsboro, Oregon
        </a>
        .
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Many authors have assumed that plug-in recharging will take place overnight at home. However, residents of cities, apartments, dormitories, and townhouses might not have garages or driveways with available power outlets, and they might be less likely to buy plug-ins unless recharging infrastructure is developed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257">
       <a href="#cite_note-257">
        [257]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DoE2008_258-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-DoE2008-258">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Electrical outlets or
      <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
       charging stations
      </a>
      near their places of residence, or in commercial or public
      <a href="/wiki/Parking_lot" title="Parking lot">
       parking lots
      </a>
      or streets or workplaces are required for these potential users to gain the full advantage of PHEVs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DoE2008_258-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-DoE2008-258">
        [258]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_SFO_259-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_SFO-259">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even house dwellers might need to charge at the office or to take advantage of opportunity charging at shopping centers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260">
       <a href="#cite_note-260">
        [260]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261">
       <a href="#cite_note-261">
        [261]
       </a>
      </sup>
      However, this infrastructure is not in place today and it will require investments by both the private and public sectors.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_SFO_259-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_SFO-259">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Several cities in
      <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">
       California
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Oregon" title="Oregon">
       Oregon
      </a>
      , and particularly
      <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">
       San Francisco
      </a>
      and other cities in the
      <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area" title="San Francisco Bay Area">
       San Francisco Bay Area
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley" title="Silicon Valley">
       Silicon Valley
      </a>
      , as well as some local private firms such as
      <a href="/wiki/Google" title="Google">
       Google
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Adobe_Systems" title="Adobe Systems">
       Adobe Systems
      </a>
      , already have deployed
      <a href="/wiki/Charging_station" title="Charging station">
       charging stations
      </a>
      and have expansion plans to attend both plug-ins and
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_car" title="Electric car">
       all-electric cars
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_SFO_259-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_SFO-259">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In Google's case, its
      <a href="/wiki/Mountain_View,_California" title="Mountain View, California">
       Mountain View
      </a>
      campus has 100 available charging stations for its share-use fleet of converted plug-ins available to its employees.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT_SFO_259-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT_SFO-259">
        [259]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RechargeIT_262-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RechargeIT-262">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Solar_panel" title="Solar panel">
       Solar panels
      </a>
      are used to generate the electricity, and this pilot program is being monitored on a daily basis, with performance results published on the
      <a href="/wiki/RechargeIT" title="RechargeIT">
       RechargeIT
      </a>
      website.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RechargeIT_262-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-RechargeIT-262">
        [262]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Emissions_shifted_to_electric_plants">
       Emissions shifted to electric plants
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Emissions shifted to electric plants">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Increased
      <a href="/wiki/Pollution" title="Pollution">
       pollution
      </a>
      is expected to occur in some areas with the adoption of PHEVs, but most areas will experience a decrease.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-knipping_263-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-knipping-263">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A study by the ACEEE predicts that widespread PHEV use in heavily coal-dependent areas would result in an increase in local net
      <a href="/wiki/Sulfur_dioxide" title="Sulfur dioxide">
       sulfur dioxide
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Mercury_(element)" title="Mercury (element)">
       mercury
      </a>
      emissions, given emissions levels from most coal plants currently supplying power to the grid.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264">
       <a href="#cite_note-264">
        [264]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Although
      <a href="/wiki/Clean_coal_technology" title="Clean coal technology">
       clean coal technologies
      </a>
      could create power plants which supply grid power from coal without emitting significant amounts of such pollutants, the higher cost of the application of these technologies may increase the price of coal-generated electricity. The net effect on pollution is dependent on the fuel source of the electrical grid (fossil or renewable, for example) and the pollution profile of the power plants themselves. Identifying, regulating and upgrading single point pollution source such as a power plant—or replacing a plant altogether—may also be more practical. From a human health perspective, shifting pollution away from large urban areas may be considered a significant advantage.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265">
       <a href="#cite_note-265">
        [265]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      According to a 2009 study by The National Academy of Science, "Electric vehicles and grid-dependent (plug-in) hybrid vehicles showed somewhat higher nonclimate damages than many other technologies."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266">
       <a href="#cite_note-266">
        [266]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Efficiency of plug-in hybrids is also impacted by the overall efficiency of
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_power_transmission" title="Electric power transmission">
       electric power transmission
      </a>
      . Transmission and distribution losses in the USA were estimated at 7.2% in 1995
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267">
       <a href="#cite_note-267">
        [267]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 6.5% in 2007.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268">
       <a href="#cite_note-268">
        [268]
       </a>
      </sup>
      By life cycle analysis of air pollution emissions, natural gas vehicles are currently the lowest emitter
      <sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">
       [
       <i>
        <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed">
         <span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2010)">
          citation needed
         </span>
        </a>
       </i>
       ]
      </sup>
      .
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Tiered_rate_structure_for_electric_bills">
       Tiered rate structure for electric bills
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Tiered rate structure for electric bills">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Electric utility companies generally do not utilize flat rate pricing. For example,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacific_Gas_and_Electric" title="Pacific Gas and Electric">
       Pacific Gas and Electric
      </a>
      (PG&amp;E) normally charges $0.10 per
      <a href="/wiki/Kilowatt_hour" title="Kilowatt hour">
       kilowatt hour
      </a>
      (kW·h) for the base tier, but additional tiers are priced as high as $0.30 per kW·h to customers without electric vehicles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269">
       <a href="#cite_note-269">
        [269]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270">
       <a href="#cite_note-270">
        [270]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Some utilities offer electric vehicle users a rate
      <a href="/wiki/Tariff" title="Tariff">
       tariff
      </a>
      that provides discounts for off-peak usage, such as overnight recharging. PG&amp;E offers a special, discounted rate for plug-in and other electric vehicle customers, the "Experimental Time-of-Use Low Emission Vehicle rate."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271">
       <a href="#cite_note-271">
        [271]
       </a>
      </sup>
      That tariff gives people much cheaper rates if they charge at night, especially during the summer months.
     </p>
     <p>
      The additional electrical utilization required to recharge the plug-in vehicles could push many households in areas that do not have off-peak tariffs into the higher priced tier and negate financial benefits.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272">
       <a href="#cite_note-272">
        [272]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Without an off-peak charging tariff, one study of a certain PHEV-20 model having an all-electric range of 20 miles, gasoline-fueled efficiency of 52.7 mi/gal U.S., and all-electric efficiency of 4 mi/kW·h, found that household electricity customers who consumed 131%–200% of baseline electricity at $0.220/(kW·h) would see benefits if gasoline was priced above US$2.89/US gal; those that consumed 201%–300% of baseline electricity at $0.303/(kW·h) would only see benefits if gas was priced above $3.98; and households consuming over 300% of baseline electricity at $0.346/(kW·h) would only see benefits if gasoline was priced above $4.55 (USD/gal).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273">
       <a href="#cite_note-273">
        [273]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Off-peak tariff rates can lower the break-even point. The PG&amp;E tariff would change those break-even gasoline prices to US$1.96, $3.17 and $3.80 per gallon, respectively, for the given PHEV and usage pattern in question.
     </p>
     <p>
      Customers under such tariffs could see significant savings by being careful about when the vehicle was charged, for example, by using a timer to restrict charging to off-peak hours. Thus, an accurate comparison of the benefit requires each household to evaluate its current electrical usage tier and tariffs weighed against the cost of gasoline and the actual observed operational cost of electric mode vehicle operation.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1320" data-file-width="2000" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg/220px-Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg/330px-Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg/440px-Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Piles_of_Salt_Salar_de_Uyuni_Bolivia_Luca_Galuzzi_2006_a.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Salar_de_Uyuni" title="Salar de Uyuni">
         Salar de Uyuni
        </a>
        in
        <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">
         Bolivia
        </a>
        is one of the largest known
        <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">
         lithium
        </a>
        reserves in the world.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274">
         <a href="#cite_note-274">
          [274]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTBolivia_275-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-NYTBolivia-275">
          [275]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Lithium_availability_and_supply_security">
       Lithium availability and supply security
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Lithium availability and supply security">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle#Rare_earth_metals_availability_and_supply_security" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       Lithium and rare earth metals availability and supply security
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Current technology for plug-ins is based on the
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium-ion_battery" title="Lithium-ion battery">
       lithium-ion battery
      </a>
      and an
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_motor" title="Electric motor">
       electric motor
      </a>
      , and the demand for
      <a href="/wiki/Lithium" title="Lithium">
       lithium
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_(chemistry)" title="Heavy metal (chemistry)">
       heavy metals
      </a>
      and other
      <a href="/wiki/Rare_earth_element" title="Rare earth element">
       rare elements
      </a>
      (such as
      <a href="/wiki/Neodymium" title="Neodymium">
       neodymium
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Boron" title="Boron">
       boron
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Cobalt" title="Cobalt">
       cobalt
      </a>
      ) required for the batteries and powertrain is expected to grow significantly due to the incoming market entrance of plug-ins and electric vehicles in the mid and long term. Some of the largest world reserves of lithium and other rare metals are located in countries with strong
      <a href="/wiki/Resource_nationalism" title="Resource nationalism">
       resource nationalism
      </a>
      , unstable governments or hostile to U.S. interests, raising concerns about the risk of replacing dependence on foreign oil with a new dependence on hostile countries to supply
      <a href="/wiki/Strategic_material" title="Strategic material">
       strategic materials
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTBolivia_275-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYTBolivia-275">
        [275]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mintzer_276-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mintzer-276">
        [276]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT030910_277-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT030910-277">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT041710_278-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT041710-278">
        [278]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Even though the metals used in electric vehicle batteries are rare, they can be recycled.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279">
       <a href="#cite_note-279">
        [279]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Fossil fuels are finite and nonrenewable.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280">
       <a href="#cite_note-280">
        [280]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Currently, the main deposits of lithium are found in China and South America throughout the
      <a href="/wiki/Andes" title="Andes">
       Andes
      </a>
      mountain chain. In 2008
      <a href="/wiki/Chile" title="Chile">
       Chile
      </a>
      was the leading lithium metal producer, followed by Australia, China, and Argentina.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT030910_277-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT030910-277">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USGS_281-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USGS-281">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the United States lithium is recovered from
      <a href="/wiki/Brine" title="Brine">
       brine
      </a>
      pools in
      <a href="/wiki/Nevada" title="Nevada">
       Nevada
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USGS_281-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-USGS-281">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CRC_282-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-CRC-282">
        [282]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Nearly half the world's known reserves are located in Bolivia,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTBolivia_275-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYTBolivia-275">
        [275]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT030910_277-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT030910-277">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and according to the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Geological_Survey" title="US Geological Survey">
       US Geological Survey
      </a>
      , Bolivia's
      <a href="/wiki/Salar_de_Uyuni" title="Salar de Uyuni">
       Salar de Uyuni
      </a>
      desert has 5.4 million tons of lithium, which can be used to make lithium batteries for
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_vehicle" title="Hybrid vehicle">
       hybrid
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle" title="Electric vehicle">
       electric vehicles
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTBolivia_275-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYTBolivia-275">
        [275]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USGS_281-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-USGS-281">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Other important reserves are located in Chile, China, and Brazil.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT030910_277-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT030910-277">
        [277]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USGS_281-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-USGS-281">
        [281]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Regarding rare earth elements, most reserves are located in China, which controls the world market for these elements.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT041710_278-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT041710-278">
        [278]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Hazard_to_pedestrians">
       Hazard to pedestrians
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Hazard to pedestrians">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle_warning_sounds" title="Electric vehicle warning sounds">
       Electric vehicle warning sounds
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      At low speeds, electric-drive cars produced less
      <a href="/wiki/Roadway_noise" title="Roadway noise">
       roadway noise
      </a>
      as compared to vehicles propelled by
      <a href="/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine" title="Internal combustion engine">
       internal combustion engines
      </a>
      . Blind people or the
      <a href="/wiki/Visual_impairment" title="Visual impairment">
       visually impaired
      </a>
      consider the noise of combustion engines a helpful aid while crossing streets, hence plug-in electric cars and hybrids could pose an unexpected hazard.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283">
       <a href="#cite_note-283">
        [283]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist0509_284-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Economist0509-284">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Tests have shown that this is a valid concern, as vehicles operating in electric mode can be particularly hard to hear below 20 mph (30 km/h) for all types of road users and not only the visually impaired. At higher speeds, the sound created by tire friction and the air displaced by the vehicle start to make sufficient audible noise.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist0509_284-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Economist0509-284">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Japan" title="Government of Japan">
       Government of Japan
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Congress" title="U.S. Congress">
       U.S. Congress
      </a>
      , and the
      <a href="/wiki/European_Parliament" title="European Parliament">
       European Parliament
      </a>
      passed legislation to regulate the minimum level of sound for hybrids and
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
      when operating in electric mode, so that blind people and other pedestrians and cyclists can hear them coming and detect from which direction they are approaching.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Economist0509_284-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Economist0509-284">
        [284]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285">
       <a href="#cite_note-285">
        [285]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TMC0810_286-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TMC0810-286">
        [286]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287">
       <a href="#cite_note-287">
        [287]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of March 2013
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , most of the hybrids and plug-in electric cars available in the United States make warning noises using a speaker system.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AutoNews0313_288-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AutoNews0313-288">
        [288]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Greenhouse_gas_emissions">
       Greenhouse gas emissions
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Greenhouse gas emissions">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle#Air_pollution_and_greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       Greenhouse gas emissions in plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      The effect of PHEVs on greenhouse emissions is complex. Plug-in hybrid vehicles operating on
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      do not emit harmful
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Motor_vehicle_emissions" title="Motor vehicle emissions">
       tailpipe pollutants
      </a>
      from the onboard source of power. The clean air benefit is usually local because depending on the source of the electricity used to recharge the batteries, air pollutant emissions are shifted to the location of the generation plants.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TwoBillion_289-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TwoBillion-289">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the same way, PHEVs do not emit
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gases" title="Greenhouse gases">
       greenhouse gases
      </a>
      from the onboard source of power, but from the point of view of a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tank-to-wheel" title="Tank-to-wheel">
       well-to-wheel assessment
      </a>
      , the extent of the benefit also depends on the fuel and technology used for
      <a href="/wiki/Electricity_generation" title="Electricity generation">
       electricity generation
      </a>
      . From the perspective of a full
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_cycle_analysis" title="Life cycle analysis">
       life cycle analysis
      </a>
      , the electricity used to recharge the batteries must be generated from renewable or clean sources such as
      <a href="/wiki/Wind_power" title="Wind power">
       wind
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Solar_energy" title="Solar energy">
       solar
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hydroelectric" title="Hydroelectric">
       hydroelectric
      </a>
      , or
      <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">
       nuclear power
      </a>
      for PEVs to have almost none or zero well-to-wheel emissions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TwoBillion_289-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TwoBillion-289">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PEVs_290-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PEVs-290">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
      On the other hand, when PEVs are recharged from
      <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">
       coal
      </a>
      -fired plants, they usually produce slightly more greenhouse gas emissions than
      <a href="/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine" title="Internal combustion engine">
       internal combustion engine
      </a>
      vehicles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TwoBillion_289-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-TwoBillion-289">
        [289]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the case of plug-in hybrid electric vehicle when operating in hybrid mode with assistance of the internal combustion engine, tailpipe and greenhouse emissions are lower in comparison to conventional cars because of their higher
      <a href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles" title="Fuel economy in automobiles">
       fuel economy
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PEVs_290-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-PEVs-290">
        [290]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      There has been much debate over the potential GHG emissions reductions that can be achieved with PHEV. A study by the
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_Power_Research_Institute" title="Electric Power Research Institute">
       Electric Power Research Institute
      </a>
      reports that a 338
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/TW%C2%B7h" title="TW·h">
       TW·h
      </a>
      or 5.8% increase in power generation needed as a result of PHEV.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-web.archive.org_291-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-web.archive.org-291">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the same report the EPRI also states that CO
      <sub>
       2
      </sub>
      emissions could increase by 430 million metric tons.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-web.archive.org_291-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-web.archive.org-291">
        [291]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The article concludes:
     </p>
     <dl>
      <dd>
       "
       <i>
        In summary, the addition of PHEVs as a significant transportation option adds approximately 6% to the total national electricity demand in 2030 compared to the base case with no PHEVs. Due to the charging profile that results in most of this additional demand occurring during off-peak hours (late night/early morning) there is an increase in the need for baseload generation. The addition of coal-fired generation to meet this need for more baseload generation does not result in any significant differences in annual emissions of SO
        <sub>
         2
        </sub>
        , NO
       </i>
       <sub>
        x
       </sub>
       <i>
        and Hg because of the caps on those pollutants. Therefore, any reductions in emissions of SO
        <sub>
         2
        </sub>
        , NO
       </i>
       <sub>
        x
       </sub>
       <i>
        or Hg from non-electric generating sources would result in a net national decline in these emissions. However, it does result in an appreciable increase in CO
        <sub>
         2
        </sub>
        and PM emissions as this analysis has not assumed any limits on CO
        <sub>
         2
        </sub>
        or PM emissions
       </i>
       ."
      </dd>
     </dl>
     <p>
      A study by the
      <a href="/wiki/American_Council_for_an_Energy-Efficient_Economy" title="American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy">
       American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy (ACEEE)
      </a>
      predicts that, on average, a typical American driver is expected to achieve about a 15% reduction in net
      <span class="chemf nowrap">
       <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">
        CO
        <span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:-0.4em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left">
         <br/>
         2
        </span>
       </a>
      </span>
      emissions compared to the driver of a regular hybrid, based on the 2005 distribution of power sources feeding the US electrical grid.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aceee_292-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-aceee-292">
        [292]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The ACEEE study also predicts that in areas where more than 80% of grid-power comes from coal-burning power plants, local net
      <span class="chemf nowrap">
       CO
       <span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:-0.4em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left">
        <br/>
        2
       </span>
      </span>
      emissions will increase,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-aceee_292-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-aceee-292">
        [292]
       </a>
      </sup>
      while for PHEVs recharged in areas where the grid is fed by power sources with lower
      <span class="chemf nowrap">
       CO
       <span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:-0.4em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left">
        <br/>
        2
       </span>
      </span>
      emissions than the current average, net
      <span class="chemf nowrap">
       CO
       <span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:-0.4em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left">
        <br/>
        2
       </span>
      </span>
      emissions associated with PHEVs will decrease correspondingly.
     </p>
     <p>
      A 2007 joint study by the
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_Power_Research_Institute" title="Electric Power Research Institute">
       Electric Power Research Institute
      </a>
      (EPRI) and the
      <a href="/wiki/Natural_Resources_Defense_Council" title="Natural Resources Defense Council">
       Natural Resources Defense Council
      </a>
      (NRDC) similarly found that the introduction of PHEVs into America’s consumer vehicle fleet could achieve significant greenhouse gas emission reductions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-epri07_4-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-epri07-4">
        [4]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The EPRI-NRDC report estimates that, between 2010 and 2050, a shift toward PHEV use could reduce GHG emissions by 3.4 to 10.4 billion metric tons. The magnitude of these reductions would ultimately depend on the level of PHEV market penetration and the carbon intensity of the US electricity sector. In general, PHEVs can be viewed as an element in the "
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pacala_and_Socolow" title="Pacala and Socolow">
       Pacala and Socolow
      </a>
      wedges" approach which shows a way to stabilize
      <span class="chemf nowrap">
       CO
       <span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:-0.4em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left">
        <br/>
        2
       </span>
      </span>
      emissions using a portfolio of existing techniques, including efficient vehicles.
     </p>
     <p>
      A 2008 study at
      <a href="/wiki/Duke_University" title="Duke University">
       Duke University
      </a>
      suggests that for PHEV's to reduce greenhouse gas emissions more than hybrids a
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carbon_pricing" title="Carbon pricing">
       carbon pricing
      </a>
      signal that encourages the development of low carbon power is needed.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293">
       <a href="#cite_note-293">
        [293]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RAND" title="RAND">
       RAND
      </a>
      also in 2008 studied the questions of a
      <a href="/wiki/Carbon_tax" title="Carbon tax">
       carbon tax
      </a>
      , carbon
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cap_and_trade" title="Cap and trade">
       cap and trade
      </a>
      systems, increasing gasoline tax, and providing renewable energy subsidies under various economic conditions and vehicle type availabilities. RAND found that subsidies were able to provide a smoother transition to new energy sources, especially in the face of energy source price volatility, because subsidies can be structured according to relative costs between renewables and fossil fuel, while taxes and carbon trading schemes alone do not take relative prices of energy into account.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294">
       <a href="#cite_note-294">
        [294]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Minnesota Pollution Control Agency found that if Minnesota's fleet of vehicles making lengthy trips were replaced by plug-in hybrids,
      <span class="chemf nowrap">
       CO
       <span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:-0.4em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left">
        <br/>
        2
       </span>
      </span>
      emissions per vehicle would likely decrease. However, unless more than 40% of the electricity used to charge the vehicles were to come from non-polluting sources, replacing the vehicles with non-plug-in hybrids would engender a larger decrease in
      <span class="chemf nowrap">
       CO
       <span style="display:inline-block;margin-bottom:-0.3em;vertical-align:-0.4em;line-height:1em;font-size:80%;text-align:left">
        <br/>
        2
       </span>
      </span>
      emissions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295">
       <a href="#cite_note-295">
        [295]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Plug-in hybrids use less fuel in all cases, and produce much less carbon dioxide in short commuter trips, which is how most vehicles are used. The difference is such that overall carbon emissions would decrease if all internal combustion vehicles were converted to plug-ins.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-knipping_263-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-knipping-263">
        [263]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      A study by Kantor, Fowler, Hajimiragha, and ElKamel shows that fuel cell plug-in hybrid vehicles achieve twice as much reduction in greenhouse gas emissions than PHEVs and FCVs. The study uses the transportation sector in Ontario Canada as a case study, with the maximum allowable number of vehicles being that which can be supported by the electric grid.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296">
       <a href="#cite_note-296">
        [296]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Argonne_National_Laboratory">
       Argonne National Laboratory
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Argonne National Laboratory">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In 2009 researchers at
      <a href="/wiki/Argonne_National_Laboratory" title="Argonne National Laboratory">
       Argonne National Laboratory
      </a>
      adapted their
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GREET_model" title="GREET model">
       GREET model
      </a>
      to conduct a full
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_cycle_assessment" title="Life cycle assessment">
       well-to-wheels
      </a>
      (WTW) analysis of energy use and
      <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">
       greenhouse gas
      </a>
      (GHG) emissions of plug-in hybrid electric vehicles for several scenarios, considering different on-board fuels and different sources of electricity generation for recharging the vehicle batteries. Three US regions were selected for the analysis,
      <a href="/wiki/California" title="California">
       California
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/New_York_(state)" title="New York (state)">
       New York
      </a>
      , and
      <a href="/wiki/Illinois" title="Illinois">
       Illinois
      </a>
      , as these regions include major metropolitan areas with significant variations in their energy generation mixes. The full cycle analysis results were also reported for the US generation mix and renewable electricity to examine cases of average and clean mixes, respectively
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Argonne_5-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Argonne-5">
        [5]
       </a>
      </sup>
      This 2009 study showed a wide spread of petroleum use and GHG emissions among the different fuel production technologies and grid generation mixes. The following table summarizes the main results:
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Argonne_5-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Argonne-5">
        [5]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="4" style="text-align:center; background:#abcdef;">
        PHEV
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_cycle_assessment" title="Life cycle assessment">
         well-to-wheels
        </a>
        Petroleum energy use and greenhouse gas emissions
        <br/>
        for an all-electric range between 10 and 40 miles (16 and 64 km) with different on-board fuels.
        <sup>
         (1)
        </sup>
        <br/>
        (as a % relative to an
        <a href="/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine" title="Internal combustion engine">
         internal combustion engine
        </a>
        vehicle that uses fossil fuel gasoline)
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th style="background:#abcdef;">
        Analysis
       </th>
       <th style="background:#abcdef;">
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reformulated_gasoline" title="Reformulated gasoline">
         Reformulated gasoline
        </a>
        <br/>
        and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ultra-low_sulfur_diesel" title="Ultra-low sulfur diesel">
         Ultra-low sulfur diesel
        </a>
       </th>
       <th style="background:#abcdef;">
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gasohol#E85" title="Gasohol">
         E85 fuel
        </a>
        from
        <br/>
        <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">
         corn
        </a>
        and
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Switchgrass" title="Switchgrass">
         switchgrass
        </a>
       </th>
       <th style="background:#abcdef;">
        <a href="/wiki/Fuel_cell" title="Fuel cell">
         Fuel cell
        </a>
        <br/>
        <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen_vehicle" title="Hydrogen vehicle">
         hydrogen
        </a>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        Petroleum energy use reduction
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         40–60%
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         70–90%
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         more than 90%
        </center>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td>
        GHG emissions reduction
        <sup>
         (2)
        </sup>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         30–60%
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         40–80%
        </center>
       </td>
       <td>
        <center>
         10–100%
        </center>
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <td colspan="6">
        <small>
         Source: Center for Transportation Research,
         <a href="/wiki/Argonne_National_Laboratory" title="Argonne National Laboratory">
          Argonne National Laboratory
         </a>
         (2009). See Table 1.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Argonne_5-3">
          <a href="#cite_note-Argonne-5">
           [5]
          </a>
         </sup>
         Notes: (1) Simulations for year 2020
         <br/>
         with PHEV model year 2015. (2) No direct or
         <a href="/wiki/Indirect_land_use_change_impacts_of_biofuels" title="Indirect land use change impacts of biofuels">
          indirect land use changes
         </a>
         included in the WTW analysis for bio-mass fuel feedstocks.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Searchinger08_297-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Searchinger08-297">
           [297]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fargione08_298-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Fargione08-298">
           [298]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </small>
       </td>
      </tr>
     </table>
     <p>
      The Argonne study found that PHEVs offered reductions in petroleum energy use as compared with regular hybrid electric vehicles. More petroleum energy savings and also more GHG emissions reductions were realized as the all-electric range increased, except when electricity used to recharged was dominated by coal or oil-fired power generation. As expected, electricity from renewable sources realized the largest reductions in petroleum energy use and GHG emissions for all PHEVs as the all-electric range increased. The study also concluded that plug-in vehicles that employ biomass-based fuels (biomass-E85 and -hydrogen) may not realize GHG emissions benefits over regular hybrids if power generation is dominated by fossil sources.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Argonne_5-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-Argonne-5">
        [5]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Oak_Ridge_National_Laboratory">
       Oak Ridge National Laboratory
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Oak Ridge National Laboratory">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      A 2008 study by researchers at
      <a href="/wiki/Oak_Ridge_National_Laboratory" title="Oak Ridge National Laboratory">
       Oak Ridge National Laboratory
      </a>
      analyzed oil use and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions of plug-in hybrids relative to
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
       hybrid electric vehicles
      </a>
      under several scenarios for years 2020 and 2030. Each type of vehicle was assumed to run 20 miles (32 km) per day and the HEV was assumed to have a
      <a href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles" title="Fuel economy in automobiles">
       fuel economy
      </a>
      of 40 miles per US gallon (5.9 L/100 km; 48 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ORNL_299-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ORNL-299">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The study considered the mix of power sources for 13 U.S. regions, generally a combination of coal, natural gas and nuclear energy, and to a lesser extend renewable energy.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ORNL_299-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ORNL-299">
        [299]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SciMag1_300-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SciMag1-300">
        [300]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A 2010 study conducted at
      <a href="/wiki/Argonne_National_Laboratory" title="Argonne National Laboratory">
       Argonne National Laboratory
      </a>
      reached similar findings, concluding that PHEVs will reduce oil consumption but could produce very different greenhouse gas emissions for each region depending on the energy mix used to generate the electricity to recharge the plug-in hybrids.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Argonne0810_1_301-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Argonne0810_1-301">
        [301]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Argonne0810_2_302-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Argonne0810_2-302">
        [302]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The following table summarizes the main results of the Oak Ridge National Laboratory study for the 2020 scenario:
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="8" style="text-align:center; background:#ffc;">
        Comparison of carbon emissions and oil consumption by plug-in hybrids relative to
        <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
         hybrid electric vehicles
        </a>
        (HEVs)
        <br/>
        by U.S. regional power generation sources on 2020
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SciMag2_303-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-SciMag2-303">
          [303]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th rowspan="2" style="background:#ffc;">
        Region
        <sup>
         (1)
        </sup>
       </th>
       <th rowspan="2" style="background:#ffc;">
        Main
        <br/>
        electricity
        <br/>
        sources
       </th>
       <th rowspan="2" style="background:#ffc;">
        Share
        <br/>
        total
        <br/>
        generation
        <br/>
        2020
       </th>
       <th colspan="2" style="background:#ffc;">
        Carbon
        <br/>
        emissions
        <br/>
        relative to HEVs
       </th>
       <th colspan="2" style="background:#ffc;">
        Oil
        <br/>
        consumption
        <br/>
        relative to HEVs
       </th>
       <th rowspan="2" style="background:#ffc;">
        States included in the region
        <sup>
         (2)
        </sup>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th style="background:#ffc;">
        Plug-in hybrid
       </th>
       <th style="background:#ffc;">
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
         All-electric mode
        </a>
       </th>
       <th style="background:#ffc;">
        Plug-in hybrid
       </th>
       <th style="background:#ffc;">
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
         All-electric mode
        </a>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr align="center">
       <td align="left">
        <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_United_States" title="Northwestern United States">
         Northwest
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">
         Natural gas
        </a>
        <br/>
        <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">
         Nuclear
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        84.3%
        <br/>
        15.7%
       </td>
       <td>
        -20.0%
       </td>
       <td>
        -37.2%
       </td>
       <td>
        -47.0%
       </td>
       <td>
        -99.6%
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        Includes
        <a href="/wiki/Idaho" title="Idaho">
         ID
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Montana" title="Montana">

        <a href="/wiki/Nevada" title="Nevada">

        </a>

        <a href="/wiki/Oregon" title="Oregon">

        </a>

        <a href="/wiki/Utah" title="Utah">

        </a>

        <a href="/wiki/South_Dakota" title="South Dakota">

        <a href="/wiki/Washington_(state)" title="Washington (state)">

        </a>
        .
       </td>
      </tr>

        <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">

        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts" title="Massachusetts">

        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Maine" title="Maine">

        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/New_Hampshire" title="New Hampshire">

        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Rhode_Island" title="Rhode Island">
         RI
        </a>
        , and
        <a href="/wiki/Vermont" title="Vermont">
         VT
        </a>
        .
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr align="center">
       <td align="left">
        Lower Midwest
       </td>
       <td>
        <a href="/wiki/Natural_gas" title="Natural gas">
         Natural gas
        </a>
        <br/>
        <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">
         Coal
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        88.6%
        <br/>
        11.4%
       </td>
       <td>
        -11.0%
       </td>
       <td>
        -16.4%
       </td>
       <td>
        -46.9%
       </td>
       <td>
        -99.4%
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        Includes
        <a href="/wiki/Arkansas" title="Arkansas">
         AR
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Kansas" title="Kansas">
         KS
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Louisiana" title="Louisiana">
         LA
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Minnesota" title="Minnesota">
         NM
        </a>
        ,
        <a href="/wiki/Oklahoma" title="Oklahoma">

        </a>
        , and
        <a href="/wiki/Texas" title="Texas">

        </a>
        .
       </td>
      </tr>

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_Protection_Agency">
       Environmental Protection Agency
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Environmental Protection Agency">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      In October 2014, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="U.S. Environmental Protection Agency">
       U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
      </a>
      published the 2014 edition of its annual report "
      <i>
       Light-Duty Automotive Technology, Carbon Dioxide Emissions, and Fuel Economy Trends
      </i>
      ." For the first time, the report presents an analysis of the impact of
      <a href="/wiki/Alternative_fuel_vehicle" title="Alternative fuel vehicle">
       alternative fuel vehicles
      </a>
      , with emphasis in
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
      because as their market share is approaching 1%, PEVs began to have a measurable impact on the U.S. overall new vehicle fuel economy and CO
      <sub>
       2
      </sub>
      emissions.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA1975_2014_199-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPA1975_2014-199">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCCtrends_304-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCCtrends-304">
        [304]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      EPA's report included the analysis of 12 all-electric passengers cars and 10 plug-in hybrids available in the market as
      <a href="/wiki/Model_year" title="Model year">
       model year
      </a>
      2014. For purposes of an accurate estimation of emissions, the analysis took into consideration the differences in operation between those PHEVs like the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      that can operate in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      without using gasoline, and those that operate in a blended mode like the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_PHV" title="Toyota Prius PHV">
       Toyota Prius PHV
      </a>
      , which uses both energy stored in the battery and energy from the gasoline tank to propel the vehicle, but that can deliver substantial all-electric driving in blended mode. In addition, since the
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of plug-in hybrids depends on the size of the battery pack, the analysis introduced a utility factor as a projection, on average, of the percentage of miles that will be driven using electricity (in electric only and blended modes) by an average driver. The following table shows the overall EV/hybrid fuel economy expressed in terms of
      <a href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_gasoline_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon gasoline equivalent">
       miles per gallon gasoline equivalent
      </a>
      (mpg-e) and the utility factor for the ten MY2014 plug-in hybrids available in the U.S. market. The study used the utility factor (since in pure EV mode there are no tailpipe emissions) and the EPA best estimate of the CO
      <sub>
       2
      </sub>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tailpipe_emissions" title="Tailpipe emissions">
       tailpipe emissions
      </a>
      produced by these vehicles in real world city and highway operation based on the EPA 5-cycle label methodology, using a weighted 55% city/45% highway driving. The results are shown in the following table.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA1975_2014_199-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPA1975_2014-199">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In addition, the EPA accounted for the upstream CO
      <sub>
       2
      </sub>
      emissions associated with the production and distribution of electricity required to charge the PHEVs. Since electricity production in the United States varies significantly from region to region, the EPA considered three scenarios/ranges with the low end of the range corresponding to the California powerplant emissions factor, the middle of the range represented by the national average powerplant emissions factor, and the upper end of the range corresponding to the powerplant emissions factor for the Rockies. The EPA estimates that the electricity GHG emission factors for various regions of the country vary from 346 g CO2/kW-hr in California to 986 g CO2/kW-hr in the Rockies, with a national average of 648 g CO2/kW-hr.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA1975_2014_199-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPA1975_2014-199">
        [199]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The following table shows the tailpipe emissions and the combined tailpipe and upstream emissions for each of the 10 MY 2014 PHEVs available in the U.S. market.
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="7" style="text-align:center; background:#cfc;">
        Comparison of tailpipe and upstream CO
        <sub>
         2
        </sub>
        emissions
        <sup>
         (1)
        </sup>
        estimated by EPA
        <br/>
        for the MY 2014 plug-in hybrids available in the U.S. market as of September 2014
        <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
         <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
          [update]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPA1975_2014_199-7">
         <a href="#cite_note-EPA1975_2014-199">
          [199]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th rowspan="2" style="background:#cfc;">

        <a href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_gasoline_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon gasoline equivalent">

         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Series_hybrid" title="Series hybrid">

        </small>
