     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="National_Bureau_of_Economic_Research">
       National Bureau of Economic Research
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: National Bureau of Economic Research">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Most emission analysis use average emissions rates across regions instead of marginal generation at different times of the day. The former approach does not take into account the generation mix within interconnected electricity markets and shifting load profiles throughout the day.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306">
       <a href="#cite_note-306">
        [306]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBER2014_307-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NBER2014-307">
        [307]
       </a>
      </sup>
      An analysis by three economist affiliated with the
      <a href="/wiki/National_Bureau_of_Economic_Research" title="National Bureau of Economic Research">
       National Bureau of Economic Research
      </a>
      (NBER), published in November 2014, developed a methodology to estimate marginal emissions of electricity demand that vary by location and time of day across the United States. The study used emissions and consumption data for 2007 through 2009, and used the specifications for the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      (
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 35 mi (56 km)). The analysis found that marginal emission rates are more than three times as large in the
      <a href="/wiki/Upper_Midwest" title="Upper Midwest">
       Upper Midwest
      </a>
      compared to the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_U.S." title="Western U.S.">
       Western U.S.
      </a>
      , and within regions, rates for some hours of the day are more than twice those for others.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBER2014_307-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NBER2014-307">
        [307]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Applying the results of the marginal analysis to plug-in electric vehicles, the NBER researchers found that the emissions of charging PEVs vary by region and hours of the day. In some regions, such as the Western U.S. and Texas, CO
      <sub>
       2
      </sub>
      emissions per mile from driving PEVs are less than those from driving a hybrid car. However, in other regions, such as the Upper Midwest, charging during the recommended hours of midnight to 4 a.m. implies that PEVs generate more emissions per mile than the average car currently on the road. The results show a fundamental tension between electricity load management and environmental goals as the hours when electricity is the least expensive to produce tend to be the hours with the greatest emissions. This occurs because coal-fired units, which have higher emission rates, are most commonly used to meet base-level and off-peak electricity demand; while natural gas units, which have relatively low emissions rates, are often brought online to meet peak demand. This pattern of fuel shifting explains why emission rates tend to be higher at night and lower during periods of peak demand in the morning and evening.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NBER2014_307-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NBER2014-307">
        [307]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h2>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Production_and_sales">
       Production and sales
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Production and sales">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h2>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      See also:
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle#Sales_and_main_markets" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       Sales and main markets for plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_modern_production_plug-in_electric_vehicles" title="List of modern production plug-in electric vehicles">
       list of modern production plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Production_models">
       Production models
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Production models">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bilbao_05_2012_BYD_F3DM_2438.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="2400" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Bilbao_05_2012_BYD_F3DM_2438.JPG/220px-Bilbao_05_2012_BYD_F3DM_2438.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Bilbao_05_2012_BYD_F3DM_2438.JPG/330px-Bilbao_05_2012_BYD_F3DM_2438.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Bilbao_05_2012_BYD_F3DM_2438.JPG/440px-Bilbao_05_2012_BYD_F3DM_2438.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Launched in China in December 2008, the
         <a href="/wiki/BYD_F3DM" title="BYD F3DM">
          BYD F3DM
         </a>
         became the world's first
         <a href="/wiki/Mass_production" title="Mass production">
          mass-produced
         </a>
         plug-in hybrid automobile.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308">
          <a href="#cite_note-308">
           [308]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BYD_Qin_(Auto_Shanghai_2013).JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="1568" data-file-width="2352" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/BYD_Qin_%28Auto_Shanghai_2013%29.JPG/220px-BYD_Qin_%28Auto_Shanghai_2013%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/BYD_Qin_%28Auto_Shanghai_2013%29.JPG/330px-BYD_Qin_%28Auto_Shanghai_2013%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3a/BYD_Qin_%28Auto_Shanghai_2013%29.JPG/440px-BYD_Qin_%28Auto_Shanghai_2013%29.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a href="/wiki/BYD_Qin" title="BYD Qin">
          BYD Qin
         </a>
         , released in China in December 2013, replaced the F3DM. The Qin became the all-time best-selling plug-in electric car in China.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_F3DM" title="BYD F3DM">
       BYD F3DM
      </a>
      became the world's first
      <a href="/wiki/Mass_production" title="Mass production">
       mass-produced
      </a>
      plug-in hybrid compact
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sedan_(car)" title="Sedan (car)">
       sedan
      </a>
      as it went on sale in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China" title="People's Republic of China">
       China
      </a>
      to government agencies and corporations on December 15, 2008.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-F3DM_12-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-F3DM-12">
        [12]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bwf3dm_13-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-bwf3dm-13">
        [13]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC1208_14-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC1208-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The F3DM had an
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 100 kilometers (60 mi).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309">
       <a href="#cite_note-309">
        [309]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sales to the general public began in
      <a href="/wiki/Shenzhen" title="Shenzhen">
       Shenzhen
      </a>
      in March 2010
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC0310_15-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC0310-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edmunds310_16-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Edmunds310-16">
        [16]
       </a>
      </sup>
      but because the F3DM nearly doubled the price of cars that run on conventional fuel,
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Auto" title="BYD Auto">
       BYD Auto
      </a>
      was counting on subsidies from the local government to make the plug-in attractive to personal buyers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC0310_15-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC0310-15">
        [15]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The F3DM was sold for 149,800
      <a href="/wiki/Chinese_yuan" title="Chinese yuan">
       yuan
      </a>
      (about
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$21,900
      </span>
      ),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GCC1208_14-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-GCC1208-14">
        [14]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and during its first year in the market the F3DM only sold 48 vehicles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesChina2009_310-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesChina2009-310">
        [310]
       </a>
      </sup>
      During 2010, 417 units were sold,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chinaauto_311-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Chinaauto-311">
        [311]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and cumulative sales in China reached 3,284 units through December 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesChina2009_310-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesChina2009-310">
        [310]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chinaauto_311-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Chinaauto-311">
        [311]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-China201112_312-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-China201112-312">
        [312]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-China122013_313-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-China122013-313">
        [313]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Production of the BYD F3DM was ended due to low sales, and it was replaced by the
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Qin" title="BYD Qin">
       BYD Qin
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EndF3DM_91-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EndF3DM-91">
        [91]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Deliveries of the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
       Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      began in December 2010, initially only in selected U.S. markets, and became available nationwide in November 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314">
       <a href="#cite_note-314">
        [314]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Volt has a
      <a href="/wiki/United_States_Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="United States Environmental Protection Agency">
       United States Environmental Protection Agency
      </a>
      rated all electric range of 35 mi (56 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315">
       <a href="#cite_note-315">
        [315]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316">
       <a href="#cite_note-316">
        [316]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Deliveries of the 2012 Volt began in Canada in September 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317">
       <a href="#cite_note-317">
        [317]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318">
       <a href="#cite_note-318">
        [318]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first deliveries of the Chevrolet Volt in Europe took place on November 30, 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FRAVolt_319-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FRAVolt-319">
        [319]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320">
       <a href="#cite_note-320">
        [320]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The European version of the Volt, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Opel_Ampera" title="Opel Ampera">
       Opel Ampera
      </a>
      , was released to customers in Europe in February 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321">
       <a href="#cite_note-321">
        [321]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Deliveries of the right-hand drive Vauxhall Ampera in the UK began in May 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322">
       <a href="#cite_note-322">
        [322]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Holden Volt was released in Australia in December 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323">
       <a href="#cite_note-323">
        [323]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Chevrolet_Volt_WAS_2010_8852.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="1200" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Chevrolet_Volt_WAS_2010_8852.JPG/220px-Chevrolet_Volt_WAS_2010_8852.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Chevrolet_Volt_WAS_2010_8852.JPG/330px-Chevrolet_Volt_WAS_2010_8852.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Chevrolet_Volt_WAS_2010_8852.JPG/440px-Chevrolet_Volt_WAS_2010_8852.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Deliveries of the
         <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">
          Chevrolet Volt
         </a>
         began in the U.S. in December 2010, and it is the world's all-time top selling plug-in hybrid.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Opel_Ampera_(9820700496).jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Opel_Ampera_%289820700496%29.jpg/220px-Opel_Ampera_%289820700496%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Opel_Ampera_%289820700496%29.jpg/330px-Opel_Ampera_%289820700496%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Opel_Ampera_%289820700496%29.jpg/440px-Opel_Ampera_%289820700496%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The Opel Ampera is the European version of the Chevrolet Volt.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The Volt/Ampera family of vehicles was the world's best selling
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_car" title="Plug-in electric car">
       plug-in electric car
      </a>
      in 2012 with 31,400 units sold, and ranked in the 432nd place among all models sold worldwide in 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324">
       <a href="#cite_note-324">
        [324]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325">
       <a href="#cite_note-325">
        [325]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Opel/Vauxhall Ampera was Europe's top selling plug-in electric car in 2012 with 5,268 units representing a market share of 21.5% of the region's plug-in electric passenger car segment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUsales2011_12_326-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EUsales2011_12-326">
        [326]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TopEUAmpera_327-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TopEUAmpera-327">
        [327]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Combined global Volt/Ampera sales passed the 100,000 unit milestone in October 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt100K_1-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt100K-1">
        [1]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Volt sales in the American market passed the 100,000 unit milestone in July 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VoltUS100K_328-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-VoltUS100K-328">
        [328]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of June 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the Volt family of vehicles ranks as the world's all-time top selling plug-in hybrid, and it is also the third best selling
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_car" title="Plug-in electric car">
       plug-in electric car
      </a>
      ever, after the
      <a href="/wiki/Nissan_Leaf" title="Nissan Leaf">
       Nissan Leaf
      </a>
      (over 228,000) and the
      <a href="/wiki/Tesla_Model_S" title="Tesla Model S">
       Tesla Model S
      </a>
      (over 129,000). As of June 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , global Volt/Ampera sales totaled about 117,300 units.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top10Global062016_329-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top10Global062016-329">
        [329]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The United States is its main market with 98,558 Volts delivered, followed by Canada with more than 6,700 units, both, through June 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VoltUS100K_328-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-VoltUS100K-328">
        [328]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of September 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , about 1,750 Volts had been sold in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt100K_1-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt100K-1">
        [1]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of June 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , over 10,000 Opel/Vauxhall Amperas had been sold in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top10Global062016_329-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top10Global062016-329">
        [329]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ampera10K_330-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ampera10K-330">
        [330]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Netherlands is the leading Ampera market with 5,031 were registered through December 2015,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RAISales2015_331-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RAISales2015-331">
        [331]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RAISales2014_332-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-RAISales2014-332">
        [332]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NED2013_333-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NED2013-333">
        [333]
       </a>
      </sup>
      followed by Germany with 1,542 units,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesGer2011_334-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesGer2011-334">
        [334]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesGer2012_335-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesGer2012-335">
        [335]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesGer2013_336-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesGer2013-336">
        [336]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesGer2014_337-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesGer2014-337">
        [337]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesGer2015_338-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesGer2015-338">
        [338]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the UK with 1,279 Vauxhall Amperas registered by the end of September 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK3Q2015_339-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UK3Q2015-339">
        [339]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Due to the end of deliveries of Chevrolet vehicles to Europe by the end of 2015 to focus on its core European brands, Opel and Vauxhall, the American-made Chevrolet Volt will not be available in Europe beginning in 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340">
       <a href="#cite_note-340">
        [340]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341">
       <a href="#cite_note-341">
        [341]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In July 2014, Opel announced that due to the slowdown in sales, the Ampera will be discontinued after the launch of next generation Volt, and between 2014 and 2018, Opel plans to introduce in Europe a successor product in the electric vehicle segment.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Opel_weak_sales_342-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Opel_weak_sales-342">
        [342]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Deliveries to retail customers of the
      <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt_(second_generation)" title="Chevrolet Volt (second generation)">
       second generation Chevrolet Volt
      </a>
      began in the U.S. and Canada in October 2015 as a 2016
      <a href="/wiki/Model_year" title="Model year">
       model year
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt2016_96-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt2016-96">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Canada2015_97-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Canada2015-97">
        [97]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Availability in the American market is limited to California and the other 10 states that follow
      <a href="/wiki/California_Air_Resources_Board#California_zero-emissions_vehicle" title="California Air Resources Board">
       California’s zero emission vehicle
      </a>
      rules. It is scheduled to go on sale as a 2017 model year in the 39 remaining states by the second quarter of 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Volt2016_96-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Volt2016-96">
        [96]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to General Motors the second generation Volt has an upgraded powertrain and uses a battery pack with new chemistry that stores 20% more electrical energy and uses fewer cells.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343">
       <a href="#cite_note-343">
        [343]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344">
       <a href="#cite_note-344">
        [344]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Its improved battery system and drivetrain allow the Volt to deliver an EPA rated
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 53 mi (85 km), and to improve its fuel economy in gasoline-only mode to 42 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      (5.6 L/100 km; 50 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPAVolt2016_345-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPAVolt2016-345">
        [345]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fisker_at_speed_in_the_fog_trimmed.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="301" data-file-width="510" height="130" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Fisker_at_speed_in_the_fog_trimmed.jpg/220px-Fisker_at_speed_in_the_fog_trimmed.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Fisker_at_speed_in_the_fog_trimmed.jpg/330px-Fisker_at_speed_in_the_fog_trimmed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Fisker_at_speed_in_the_fog_trimmed.jpg/440px-Fisker_at_speed_in_the_fog_trimmed.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fisker_at_speed_in_the_fog_trimmed.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Retail deliveries of the
        <a href="/wiki/Fisker_Karma" title="Fisker Karma">
         Fisker Karma
        </a>
        began in the U.S. in November 2011 and production was halted in 2012.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Retail deliveries of the
      <a href="/wiki/Fisker_Karma" title="Fisker Karma">
       Fisker Karma
      </a>
      began in November 2011. The Karma had an EPA rated all-electric range of 32 mi (51 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MPGe02_346-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-MPGe02-346">
        [346]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Production was suspended in November 2012 due to financial difficulties,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT032013_347-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT032013-347">
        [347]
       </a>
      </sup>
      with about 2,450 Karmas built since 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters062013_348-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Reuters062013-348">
        [348]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As a result of
      <a href="/wiki/Flash_flood" title="Flash flood">
       flash floods
      </a>
      caused by
      <a href="/wiki/Hurricane_Sandy" title="Hurricane Sandy">
       Hurricane Sandy
      </a>
      in October 2012, 16 Karmas caught fire and another 330 units were lost when an entire shipment from Europe was flooded while being parked at
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Port_Newark-Elizabeth_Marine_Terminal" title="Port Newark-Elizabeth Marine Terminal">
       Port Newark-Elizabeth Marine Terminal
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT112012_349-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT112012-349">
        [349]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Flooding2012_350-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Flooding2012-350">
        [350]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fisker_Automotive" title="Fisker Automotive">
       Fisker Automotive
      </a>
      filed for
      <a href="/wiki/Bankruptcy" title="Bankruptcy">
       bankruptcy
      </a>
      in November 2013, after the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Energy" title="U.S. Department of Energy">
       U.S. Department of Energy
      </a>
      auctioned its debt and sold it to Hybrid Technology LLC.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351">
       <a href="#cite_note-351">
        [351]
       </a>
      </sup>
      About 1,600 units were sold in the United States through December 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top6Global2013_352-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top6Global2013-352">
        [352]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 533 units were sold in Europe through December 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353">
       <a href="#cite_note-353">
        [353]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Netherlands was the top selling European market for the Karma, with 188 units sold through December 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NetherSales2011_13_354-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NetherSales2011_13-354">
        [354]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-107.jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-107.jpg/220px-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-107.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-107.jpg/330px-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-107.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-107.jpg/440px-11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-107.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:11-09-04-iaa-by-RalfR-107.jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid">
         Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid
        </a>
        was launched in Japan and the U.S. in early 2012, and Europe by mid-2012.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid">
       Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      was released in Japan in January 2012,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JapanStartDate_82-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-JapanStartDate-82">
        [82]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and deliveries in the United States began in late February 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PEVsalesUS_83-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-PEVsalesUS-83">
        [83]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Prius PHV total
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      in
      <a href="/wiki/Blended_mode" title="Blended mode">
       blended mode
      </a>
      is 11 mi (18 km) as rated by EPA.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EPArating_355-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EPArating-355">
        [355]
       </a>
      </sup>
      During 2012, its first year in the market, global sales reached 27,181 units.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PiP2012sales_356-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PiP2012sales-356">
        [356]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of April 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , a total of 75,400 first generation Prius PHVs had been sold worldwide.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TMC9miHEVs_357-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TMC9miHEVs-357">
        [357]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The United States is the market leader with 42,320 units delivered through April 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PiP2015US_358-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PiP2015US-358">
        [358]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales042016US_359-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales042016US-359">
        [359]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Japan ranks next with about 22,100 units, followed by Europe with 10,500 units, both, through April 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TMC9miHEVs_357-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TMC9miHEVs-357">
        [357]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The leading European market is the Netherlands with 4,134 units registered as of 30 November 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether112015_360-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nether112015-360">
        [360]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Production of the first generation Prius Plug-in ended in June 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1genEnd_361-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-1genEnd-361">
        [361]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The second generation Prius plug-in hybrid, the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Prime" title="Toyota Prius Prime">
       Toyota Prius Prime
      </a>
      , is expected to be released in the U.S. by the end of 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriusPrime2_362-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PriusPrime2-362">
        [362]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriusPrime3_118-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-PriusPrime3-118">
        [118]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ford_C-Max_Energi_WAS_2012_0563.JPG">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3369" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Ford_C-Max_Energi_WAS_2012_0563.JPG/220px-Ford_C-Max_Energi_WAS_2012_0563.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Ford_C-Max_Energi_WAS_2012_0563.JPG/330px-Ford_C-Max_Energi_WAS_2012_0563.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Ford_C-Max_Energi_WAS_2012_0563.JPG/440px-Ford_C-Max_Energi_WAS_2012_0563.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ford_C-Max_Energi_WAS_2012_0563.JPG" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The roll-out of the
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_C-Max_Energi" title="Ford C-Max Energi">
         Ford C-Max Energi
        </a>
        began in October 2012.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_C-Max_Energi" title="Ford C-Max Energi">
       Ford C-Max Energi
      </a>
      has an all-electric range of 20 mi (32 km) and was released in the U.S. by mid October 2012. The EPA rated the Energi combined city/highway fuel economy in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      at 88
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_of_gasoline_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon of gasoline equivalent">
       MPG-e
      </a>
      (2.7 L/100 km), 95 MPG-e (2.5 L/100 km) for city driving and 81 MPG-e (2.9 L/100 km) in highway.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Energi2013_14_363-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Energi2013_14-363">
        [363]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnergiREV062014_364-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EnergiREV062014-364">
        [364]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of December 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , a total of 25,552 units have been sold in the U.S.,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USales2012_365-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USales2012-365">
        [365]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales2014US_366-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales2014US-366">
        [366]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales2015US_367-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales2015US-367">
        [367]
       </a>
      </sup>
      525 in Canada,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesCanada2015_368-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesCanada2015-368">
        [368]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 224 in the Netherlands,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NED062015_369-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NED062015-369">
        [369]
       </a>
      </sup>
      totaling global sales of 22,253 units.
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid_(front_quarter_2).jpg">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="771" data-file-width="1280" height="133" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid_%28front_quarter_2%29.jpg/220px-Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid_%28front_quarter_2%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid_%28front_quarter_2%29.jpg/330px-Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid_%28front_quarter_2%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid_%28front_quarter_2%29.jpg/440px-Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid_%28front_quarter_2%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid_(front_quarter_2).jpg" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        The
        <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid">
         Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid
        </a>
        is the world's first diesel plug-in hybrid.
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_V60_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid">
       Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      , the world's first diesel plug-in hybrid, has an
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of up to 50 km (31 mi), and a
      <a href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles" title="Fuel economy in automobiles">
       fuel economy
      </a>
      of 124
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_of_gasoline_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon of gasoline equivalent">
       miles per gallon of gasoline equivalent
      </a>
      (1.8 l/100 km), with carbon dioxide emissions averaging 49 g/km.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABG0311_370-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ABG0311-370">
        [370]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABG1K_371-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ABG1K-371">
        [371]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372">
       <a href="#cite_note-372">
        [372]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Retail deliveries began in Sweden in late 2012
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2011_13_86-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2011_13-86">
        [86]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and the rest of Europe in early 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373">
       <a href="#cite_note-373">
        [373]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The diesel PHV is not expected to be available in the U.S.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABG1K_371-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ABG1K-371">
        [371]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In September 2012, Volvo announced that the first 1,000 units were sold out before the
      <a href="/wiki/Model_year" title="Model year">
       model year
      </a>
      2013 vehicles were delivered to the dealerships. The carmaker ramped up production of the 2014 model year to 5,000 units for 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ABG1K_371-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-ABG1K-371">
        [371]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of June 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , a total of 15,624 units have been delivered in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2012_374-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2012-374">
        [374]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VolvoSales2013_375-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-VolvoSales2013-375">
        [375]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Europe2014_376-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Europe2014-376">
        [376]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2015EUTop30_377-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-2015EUTop30-377">
        [377]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of June 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , sales were led by the Netherlands with 11,001 units registered,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether2013_062015_378-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nether2013_062015-378">
        [378]
       </a>
      </sup>
      followed by Sweden with 2,000 units delivered through December 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2012_374-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2012-374">
        [374]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2013_379-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2013-379">
        [379]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2014_380-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2014-380">
        [380]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweden2014_2015_381-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sweden2014_2015-381">
        [381]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The V60 PHEV was the top selling plug-in hybrid in Europe accounting for the segment sales during the first eleven months of 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EU112013_382-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-EU112013-382">
        [382]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014_Honda_Accord_Plug-In_Hybrid_Sedan_trimmed.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="328" data-file-width="620" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/2014_Honda_Accord_Plug-In_Hybrid_Sedan_trimmed.jpg/220px-2014_Honda_Accord_Plug-In_Hybrid_Sedan_trimmed.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/2014_Honda_Accord_Plug-In_Hybrid_Sedan_trimmed.jpg/330px-2014_Honda_Accord_Plug-In_Hybrid_Sedan_trimmed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/2014_Honda_Accord_Plug-In_Hybrid_Sedan_trimmed.jpg/440px-2014_Honda_Accord_Plug-In_Hybrid_Sedan_trimmed.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Sales of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honda_Accord_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid">
          Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid
         </a>
         began in California and New York in January 2013.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mitsu_Outlander_PHEV_02_2016_BSB_5201.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="2144" data-file-width="3216" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Mitsu_Outlander_PHEV_02_2016_BSB_5201.JPG/220px-Mitsu_Outlander_PHEV_02_2016_BSB_5201.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Mitsu_Outlander_PHEV_02_2016_BSB_5201.JPG/330px-Mitsu_Outlander_PHEV_02_2016_BSB_5201.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Mitsu_Outlander_PHEV_02_2016_BSB_5201.JPG/440px-Mitsu_Outlander_PHEV_02_2016_BSB_5201.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Outlander_P-HEV" title="Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV">
          Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV
         </a>
         has been for two years running, 2014 and 2015, the top selling plug-in electric car in Europe,
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUtop2014_383-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-EUtop2014-383">
           [383]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PHEVs2015EU_384-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-PHEVs2015EU-384">
           [384]
          </a>
         </sup>
         and the world's best selling plug-in hybrid.
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top2015Global_2-1">
          <a href="#cite_note-Top2015Global-2">
           [2]
          </a>
         </sup>
         <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top10_2014_385-0">
          <a href="#cite_note-Top10_2014-385">
           [385]
          </a>
         </sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honda_Accord_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid">
       Honda Accord Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      , with an all-electric range of 13 mi (21 km), was released in the U.S. in January 2013 and is available only in California and New York.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pete_Brissette_87-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Pete_Brissette-87">
        [87]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 835 units have been sold in the U.S. through September 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PEVUSales2013_386-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PEVUSales2013-386">
        [386]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales092014US_387-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales092014US-387">
        [387]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Accord PHEV was introduced in Japan in June 2013 and it is available only for leasing, primarily to corporations and government agencies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388">
       <a href="#cite_note-388">
        [388]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of December 2013
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the Accord PHEV ranked as the third best selling plug-in hybrid in the Japanese market.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389">
       <a href="#cite_note-389">
        [389]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Outlander_P-HEV" title="Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV">
       Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV
      </a>
      was released in the Japanese market also in January 2013, becoming the world's first
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUV" title="SUV">
       SUV
      </a>
      plug-in hybrid in the market.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JapPHEV_88-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-JapPHEV-88">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The European version was released in Europe in October 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390">
       <a href="#cite_note-390">
        [390]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The introduction in the United States was initially scheduled for 2014, and has been delayed several times.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-391">
       <a href="#cite_note-391">
        [391]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392">
       <a href="#cite_note-392">
        [392]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393">
       <a href="#cite_note-393">
        [393]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of December 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , U.S. deliveries are scheduled to begin by the third quarter of 2016 as a 2017
      <a href="/wiki/Model_year" title="Model year">
       model year
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394">
       <a href="#cite_note-394">
        [394]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The SUV has an
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 60 km (37 mi), and a
      <a href="/wiki/Fuel_economy_in_automobiles" title="Fuel economy in automobiles">
       fuel economy
      </a>
      of 157
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_of_gasoline_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon of gasoline equivalent">
       miles per gallon of gasoline equivalent
      </a>
      (MPG-e).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JapPHEV_88-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-JapPHEV-88">
        [88]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Cumulative global sales passed the 100,000 unit milestone in March 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlander100K_119-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlander100K-119">
        [119]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OutlanderPHEV100K_120-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-OutlanderPHEV100K-120">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Europe is the leading market with 65,529 units sold, followed by Japan with 33,730 units, and Australia with 2,015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OutlanderPHEV100K_120-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-OutlanderPHEV100K-120">
        [120]
       </a>
      </sup>
      For two years running, 2014 and 2015, the Outlander P-HEV was the top selling plug-in electric vehicle in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EUtop2014_383-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EUtop2014-383">
        [383]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PHEVs2015EU_384-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-PHEVs2015EU-384">
        [384]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Also, during 2015 the Outlander plug-in hybrid surpassed the Nissan Leaf as the all-time top selling plug-in passenger car in Europe.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top10EU102015_395-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top10EU102015-395">
        [395]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Both in 2014 and 2015, it also ranked as the world's top selling plug-in hybrid, and as the third best selling plug-in car after the all-electric
      <a href="/wiki/Tesla_Model_S" title="Tesla Model S">
       Tesla Model S
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Nissan_Leaf" title="Nissan Leaf">
       Nissan Leaf
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top2015Global_2-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top2015Global-2">
        [2]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top10_2014_385-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top10_2014-385">
        [385]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of June 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the Outlander P-HEV, with about 107,000 units sold, ranks as the world's all-time second best-selling plug-in hybrid and fourth top selling plug-in electric vehicle ever.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TopPEV062016_18-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-TopPEV062016-18">
        [18]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      European sales are led by the Netherlands with 24,572 units registered,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether032016_396-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nether032016-396">
        [396]
       </a>
      </sup>
      followed by the UK with 21,053 units registered, both at the end of March 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mitsu2yrs_397-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Mitsu2yrs-397">
        [397]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the Dutch market the Outlander P-HEV ranked for two months in-a-row, November and December 2013, as the top selling new car in the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NEDrecord1_398-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NEDrecord1-398">
        [398]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NEDrecord2_399-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NEDrecord2-399">
        [399]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of March 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the Outlander P-HEV ranks as the all-time top selling plug-in electric car in the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether032016_396-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nether032016-396">
        [396]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since March 2015 the Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV ranks as the all-time top selling plug-in electric vehicle in the UK.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK10k_400-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UK10k-400">
        [400]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401">
       <a href="#cite_note-401">
        [401]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Combined sales of the three top selling countries, Japan, the Netherlands and the UK, represent 78% of the 101,533 Outlander PHEVs sold globally through the end of March 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402">
       <a href="#cite_note-402">
        [402]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ford_Fusion_Energi_SEL_WAS_2012_0573.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="2000" data-file-width="3000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Ford_Fusion_Energi_SEL_WAS_2012_0573.JPG/220px-Ford_Fusion_Energi_SEL_WAS_2012_0573.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Ford_Fusion_Energi_SEL_WAS_2012_0573.JPG/330px-Ford_Fusion_Energi_SEL_WAS_2012_0573.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1a/Ford_Fusion_Energi_SEL_WAS_2012_0573.JPG/440px-Ford_Fusion_Energi_SEL_WAS_2012_0573.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Deliveries of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_Fusion_Energi" title="Ford Fusion Energi">
          Ford Fusion Energi
         </a>
         began in the U.S. in February 2013.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2013-03-05_Geneva_Motor_Show_7846.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="2848" data-file-width="4288" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/2013-03-05_Geneva_Motor_Show_7846.JPG/220px-2013-03-05_Geneva_Motor_Show_7846.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/2013-03-05_Geneva_Motor_Show_7846.JPG/330px-2013-03-05_Geneva_Motor_Show_7846.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/2013-03-05_Geneva_Motor_Show_7846.JPG/440px-2013-03-05_Geneva_Motor_Show_7846.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a href="/wiki/McLaren_P1" title="McLaren P1">
          McLaren P1
         </a>
         is a limited production supercar released in Europe in October 2013.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Deliveries of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_Fusion_Energi" title="Ford Fusion Energi">
       Ford Fusion Energi
      </a>
      began in the United States in February 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnergiDelivery01_89-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EnergiDelivery01-89">
        [89]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnergiDelivery02_90-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EnergiDelivery02-90">
        [90]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Fusion Energi has an all-electric range of 20 mi (32 km) and an equivalent fuel economy EPA rating of 88 MPG-e (2.7 L/100 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Energi2013_14_363-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Energi2013_14-363">
        [363]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EnergiREV062014_364-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-EnergiREV062014-364">
        [364]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A mid-cycle refreshed 2017 Fusion Energi is scheduled to be released by mid-2016. In addition to a new fascia and other technological upgrades, the 2017 model year has more efficient electric motors, allowing the refreshed 2017 model year Fusion Energi to increase its all-electric range to 22 mi (35 km), and its EPA rated fuel economy in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      to 97
      <a href="/wiki/Miles_per_gallon_gasoline_equivalent" title="Miles per gallon gasoline equivalent">
       miles per gallon gasoline equivalent
      </a>
      (MPG-e) (2.4 L/100 km) for combined city/highway driving. The EPA rating in hybrid operation rose to 42 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      (5.6 L/100 km; 50 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -imp
       </small>
      </sub>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FusionEnergi2017_403-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-FusionEnergi2017-403">
        [403]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404">
       <a href="#cite_note-404">
        [404]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of April 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , over 32,000 units have been sold in North America, with 31,471 units delivered in the U.S.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales042016US_359-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales042016US-359">
        [359]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales2014US_366-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales2014US-366">
        [366]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales2015US_367-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales2015US-367">
        [367]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales2013US_405-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales2013US-405">
        [405]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and about 655 units in Canada.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesCanada2015_368-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesCanada2015-368">
        [368]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The limited edition
      <a href="/wiki/McLaren_P1" title="McLaren P1">
       McLaren P1
      </a>
      supercar was released in the UK in October 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McLarenP1_98-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-McLarenP1-98">
        [98]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first P1 delivery in the U.S. occurred in May 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406">
       <a href="#cite_note-406">
        [406]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The P1 has an all-electric range of 6.2 mi (10.0 km) on the combined
      <a href="/wiki/New_European_Driving_Cycle" title="New European Driving Cycle">
       New European Driving Cycle
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407">
       <a href="#cite_note-407">
        [407]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Production is limited to 375 units to maintain exclusivity. Pricing starts at
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       GB£866,000
      </span>
      (€1,030,000 or
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$1,350,000
      </span>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408">
       <a href="#cite_note-408">
        [408]
       </a>
      </sup>
      With only 12 units manufactured by mid November 2013, the entire P1 production was sold out, with about 75% of the customers opting for some level of customization, raising the average sales price to
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       GB£1 million
      </span>
      (€1,2 million or
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$1,6 million
      </span>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409">
       <a href="#cite_note-409">
        [409]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Only 20 units have been registered worldwide during the first nine months of 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JATO092014_410-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-JATO092014-410">
        [410]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Switzerland is the top selling market with 12 P1s registered during 2014 up to October.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesSwiss2014_411-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesSwiss2014-411">
        [411]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IAA_2013_Porsche_Panamera_S_e-hybrid_(9834184944).jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="848" data-file-width="1280" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/IAA_2013_Porsche_Panamera_S_e-hybrid_%289834184944%29.jpg/220px-IAA_2013_Porsche_Panamera_S_e-hybrid_%289834184944%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/IAA_2013_Porsche_Panamera_S_e-hybrid_%289834184944%29.jpg/330px-IAA_2013_Porsche_Panamera_S_e-hybrid_%289834184944%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/IAA_2013_Porsche_Panamera_S_e-hybrid_%289834184944%29.jpg/440px-IAA_2013_Porsche_Panamera_S_e-hybrid_%289834184944%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Retail deliveries of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Porsche_Panamera_S_E-Hybrid" title="Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid">
          Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid
         </a>
         began in the U.S. in October 2013.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cadillac_ELR_2013_NY_Auto_Show.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Cadillac_ELR_2013_NY_Auto_Show.jpg/220px-Cadillac_ELR_2013_NY_Auto_Show.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Cadillac_ELR_2013_NY_Auto_Show.jpg/330px-Cadillac_ELR_2013_NY_Auto_Show.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/Cadillac_ELR_2013_NY_Auto_Show.jpg/440px-Cadillac_ELR_2013_NY_Auto_Show.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a href="/wiki/Cadillac_ELR" title="Cadillac ELR">
          Cadillac ELR
         </a>
         was released in the U.S. in December 2013.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Porsche_Panamera_S_E-Hybrid" title="Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid">
       Porsche Panamera S E-Hybrid
      </a>
      was released in the U.S. in October 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USlunch_412-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USlunch-412">
        [412]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Panamera plug-in hybrid has an
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 32 km (20 mi) under the
      <a href="/wiki/New_European_Driving_Cycle" title="New European Driving Cycle">
       New European Driving Cycle
      </a>
      (NEDC) test.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ehybrid02_413-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Ehybrid02-413">
        [413]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of August 2014
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , sales in the U.S. totaled 698 units,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USPEVsales082014_414-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USPEVsales082014-414">
        [414]
       </a>
      </sup>
      followed by the Netherlands with 220 units through June 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AB2013_415-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AB2013-415">
        [415]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Groen062014_416-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Groen062014-416">
        [416]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Global sales between January and August 2014 totaled over 1,500 units, presenting 9% of all Panamera models sold worldwide and 1.3% of all Porsche vehicles sold during this period.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417">
       <a href="#cite_note-417">
        [417]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Retail sales of the
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Qin" title="BYD Qin">
       BYD Qin
      </a>
      began in
      <a href="/wiki/Costa_Rica" title="Costa Rica">
       Costa Rica
      </a>
      in November 2013, and sales in other
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Latin_American" title="Latin American">
       Latin American
      </a>
      countries were scheduled to begin in 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinLatam01_92-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinLatam01-92">
        [92]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinLatam02_93-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinLatam02-93">
        [93]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinLatam03_94-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinLatam03-94">
        [94]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The start of retail sales in the Chinese market was rescheduled several times,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinPrice_418-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinPrice-418">
        [418]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinLaunch_419-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinLaunch-419">
        [419]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420">
       <a href="#cite_note-420">
        [420]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinLaunch02_421-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinLaunch02-421">
        [421]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and deliveries began in mid December 2013.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PriceChina_95-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-PriceChina-95">
        [95]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The BYD Qin ranked as the top selling plug-in electric car in China in 2014 with 14,747 units sold, and since ranks as the all-time top selling plug-in electric passenger car in the country.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaTop2014_422-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaTop2014-422">
        [422]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top10PEVs2014_423-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top10PEVs2014-423">
        [423]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaUS092016_424-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaUS092016-424">
        [424]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Again in 2015, the Qin was the best-selling plug-in car in China with 31,898 units sold.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaTop2015_425-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaTop2015-425">
        [425]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaSUV2015_426-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaSUV2015-426">
        [426]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaTop2015EV_427-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaTop2015EV-427">
        [427]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Since its introduction, cumulative sales in China totaled 65,178 plug-in hybrids through September 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaUS092016_424-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaUS092016-424">
        [424]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Also, the BYD Qin was the world's second best selling plug-in hybrid car in 2015 after the Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top2015Global_2-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top2015Global-2">
        [2]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A
      <a href="/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle" title="Battery electric vehicle">
       pure battery electric
      </a>
      version, the Qin EV300, was released in China in March 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-QinEV300_428-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-QinEV300-428">
        [428]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Cadillac_ELR" title="Cadillac ELR">
       Cadillac ELR
      </a>
      was released to retail customers in the U.S. and Canada in December 2013. The ELR is a limited production
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Luxury_car" title="Luxury car">
       luxury
      </a>
      <a href="/wiki/Coup%C3%A9" title="Coupé">
       coupé
      </a>
      that shares the powertrain of the Chevrolet Volt and has an EPA-rated
      <a href="/wiki/All-electric_range" title="All-electric range">
       all-electric range
      </a>
      of 37 miles (60 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ELR1st_99-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ELR1st-99">
        [99]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Production ended in February 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429">
       <a href="#cite_note-429">
        [429]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Cumulative sales in North America totaled about 2,800 units through April 2018.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430">
       <a href="#cite_note-430">
        [430]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 2,697 units were delivered in the U.S. through April 2016,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales042016US_359-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales042016US-359">
        [359]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales2014US_366-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales2014US-366">
        [366]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales2015US_367-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales2015US-367">
        [367]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and 78 units in Canada through March 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SalesCanada2015_368-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-SalesCanada2015-368">
        [368]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ELRCanada2014_431-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ELRCanada2014-431">
        [431]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Porsche_918_Spyder_at_2014_NY_Auto_Show.jpg">
