         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Sales of the
         <a href="/wiki/Porsche_918_Spyder" title="Porsche 918 Spyder">
          Porsche 918 Spyder
         </a>
         began in Europe in May 2014
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BMW_i8_in_Berlin_trimmed.jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1054" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/BMW_i8_in_Berlin_trimmed.jpg/220px-BMW_i8_in_Berlin_trimmed.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/BMW_i8_in_Berlin_trimmed.jpg/330px-BMW_i8_in_Berlin_trimmed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/BMW_i8_in_Berlin_trimmed.jpg/440px-BMW_i8_in_Berlin_trimmed.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a href="/wiki/BMW_i8" title="BMW i8">
          BMW i8
         </a>
         was released in Europe in June 2014.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/Porsche_918_Spyder" title="Porsche 918 Spyder">
       Porsche 918 Spyder
      </a>
      , with price starting at
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$845,000
      </span>
      was released in Europe in May 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AB1012_432-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-AB1012-432">
        [432]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Deliveries in the United States began in June 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433">
       <a href="#cite_note-433">
        [433]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Production is limited to 918 units sold as a 2014
      <a href="/wiki/Model_year" title="Model year">
       model year
      </a>
      . The supercar is capable of reaching 100 mph (160 km/h) in
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/All-electric_mode" title="All-electric mode">
       all-electric mode
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AB1012_432-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-AB1012-432">
        [432]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and has an EPA rated all-electric range of 12 mi (19 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434">
       <a href="#cite_note-434">
        [434]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The entire production run was sold out by December 2014. The country with the most orders is the United States with 297 units.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435">
       <a href="#cite_note-435">
        [435]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Production is scheduled to end in July 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436">
       <a href="#cite_note-436">
        [436]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 105 units have been registered worldwide during the first nine months of 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JATO092014_410-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-JATO092014-410">
        [410]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The United States is the leading market with 57 cars delivered through November 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-918Spyder_437-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-918Spyder-437">
        [437]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Volkswagen_XL_driver_side.JPG">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="3242" data-file-width="4192" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Volkswagen_XL_driver_side.JPG/220px-Volkswagen_XL_driver_side.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Volkswagen_XL_driver_side.JPG/330px-Volkswagen_XL_driver_side.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Volkswagen_XL_driver_side.JPG/440px-Volkswagen_XL_driver_side.JPG 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Deliveries of the
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_XL1" title="Volkswagen XL1">
          Volkswagen XL1
         </a>
         diesel-powered plug-in hybrid began in June 2014.
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:IAA_2013_Mercedes_S_500_Plug-in_Hybrid_(9834604185).jpg">
          <img alt="" data-file-height="848" data-file-width="1280" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/IAA_2013_Mercedes_S_500_Plug-in_Hybrid_%289834604185%29.jpg/220px-IAA_2013_Mercedes_S_500_Plug-in_Hybrid_%289834604185%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/IAA_2013_Mercedes_S_500_Plug-in_Hybrid_%289834604185%29.jpg/330px-IAA_2013_Mercedes_S_500_Plug-in_Hybrid_%289834604185%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2f/IAA_2013_Mercedes_S_500_Plug-in_Hybrid_%289834604185%29.jpg/440px-IAA_2013_Mercedes_S_500_Plug-in_Hybrid_%289834604185%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/>
         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_S_500_e" title="Mercedes-Benz S 500 e">
          Mercedes-Benz S 500 e
         </a>
         was launched in Europe in the second half of 2014.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Retail deliveries of the
      <a href="/wiki/BMW_i8" title="BMW i8">
       BMW i8
      </a>
      began in Germany in June 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BMWi8First_100-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-BMWi8First-100">
        [100]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The i8 luxury
      <a href="/wiki/Sports_car" title="Sports car">
       sports car
      </a>
      has an all-electric range of 37 km (23 mi) under the
      <a href="/wiki/New_European_Driving_Cycle" title="New European Driving Cycle">
       NEDC
      </a>
      test.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-i8Launch_438-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-i8Launch-438">
        [438]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Pricing for the 2015 BMW i8 destined for the U.S. market starts at
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$135,925
      </span>
      (€103,000 or
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       GB£86,800
      </span>
      ) before any applicable
      <a href="/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#United_States" title="Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles">
       government incentives
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProdSpecs_439-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ProdSpecs-439">
        [439]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Global deliveries to retail customers totaled 1,129 units through November 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BMWi112014_440-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BMWi112014-440">
        [440]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_XL1" title="Volkswagen XL1">
       Volkswagen XL1
      </a>
      was released to retail customers in Germany in June 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VWXL1first_101-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-VWXL1first-101">
        [101]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The XL1 has an all-electric range of 50 km (31 mi). The limited production XL1 is available only in Europe and pricing starts at €111,000 (~
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$146,000
      </span>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VWXL1_441-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-VWXL1-441">
        [441]
       </a>
      </sup>
      VW expects its diesel-powered XL1 to achieve 0.9 l/100 km (260 mpg
      <sub>
       <small>
        -US
       </small>
      </sub>
      ), becoming the most fuel-efficient car in the world.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-XL1_442-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-XL1-442">
        [442]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Sales of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Audi_A3_Sportback_e-tron" title="Audi A3 Sportback e-tron">
       Audi A3 Sportback e-tron
      </a>
      began in Europe in August 2014,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443">
       <a href="#cite_note-443">
        [443]
       </a>
      </sup>
      with the first 227 units were registered in Germany in August 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Germany082014_102-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Germany082014-102">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Global registrations totaled 415 units up to September 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JATO092014_410-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-JATO092014-410">
        [410]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The A3 e-tron has an all-electric range of 50 km (31 mi)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A3etron_444-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-A3etron-444">
        [444]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Retail sales in the U.S. are scheduled to begin in early 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445">
       <a href="#cite_note-445">
        [445]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first 76 units of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf_GTE" title="Volkswagen Golf GTE">
       Volkswagen Golf GTE
      </a>
      were registered in Germany in August 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Germany082014_102-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-Germany082014-102">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Golf GTE has an all-electric range of 50 km (31 mi)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VW_GTE_446-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-VW_GTE-446">
        [446]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 321 units have been registered in Europe through September 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JATO092014_410-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-JATO092014-410">
        [410]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first units of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_S_500_e" title="Mercedes-Benz S 500 e">
       Mercedes-Benz S 500 e
      </a>
      were also registered in Germany in August 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Germany082014_102-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Germany082014-102">
        [102]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The S 500 has an all-electric range of 30 km (19 mi). Sales in the U.S. began in 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-S500PHEV_447-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-S500PHEV-447">
        [447]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 38 units have been registered up to September 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JATO092014_410-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-JATO092014-410">
        [410]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first four units of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Porsche_Cayenne_S_E-Hybrid" title="Porsche Cayenne S E-Hybrid">
       Porsche Cayenne S E-Hybrid
      </a>
      were registered in September 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-JATO092014_410-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-JATO092014-410">
        [410]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The plug-in Cayenne has an all-electric range of 14 mi (23 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448">
       <a href="#cite_note-448">
        [448]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 45 units have been sold in the U.S. through November 2014.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USPEVsales112014_449-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-USPEVsales112014-449">
        [449]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>

      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">

         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         Deliveries of the
         <a href="/wiki/BYD_Tang" title="BYD Tang">
          BYD Tang
         </a>
         SUV began in China in June 2015
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
        <div class="thumbimage">
         <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:20150404_Hyundai_Sonata_PHEV_1.jpg">

         </a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left">
         The
         <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyundai_Sonata_PHEV" title="Hyundai Sonata PHEV">
          Hyundai Sonata PHEV
         </a>
         was released in the U.S. in November 2015.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Retail deliveries of the
      <a href="/wiki/BYD_Tang" title="BYD Tang">
       BYD Tang
      </a>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/SUV" title="SUV">
       SUV
      </a>
      began in China in June 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaEV062015_450-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaEV062015-450">
        [450]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Tang has an all-electric range of 80 km (50 mi).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BYDTangSpecs_451-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-BYDTangSpecs-451">
        [451]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 45,163 units have been sold in China through September 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaUS092016_424-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaUS092016-424">
        [424]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaSUV2015_426-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaSUV2015-426">
        [426]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Tang ranked as the top selling plug-in electric car in China during the first three quarters of 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ChinaUS092016_424-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-ChinaUS092016-424">
        [424]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The first demo units of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Passat_GTE" title="Volkswagen Passat GTE">
       Volkswagen Passat GTE
      </a>
      were registered in Germany in January 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452">
       <a href="#cite_note-452">
        [452]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The Passat GTE has an all-electric range of 50 km (31 mi) and it is the first plug-in hybrid available as both
      <a href="/wiki/Sedan_(automobile)" title="Sedan (automobile)">
       sedan
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Station_wagon" title="Station wagon">
       station wagon
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PassatGTE_453-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PassatGTE-453">
        [453]
       </a>
      </sup>
      A total of 88 units have been registered in Germany through July 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454">
       <a href="#cite_note-454">
        [454]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_XC90_T8" title="Volvo XC90 T8">
       Volvo XC90 T8
      </a>
      plug-in hybrid was released in Europe in the second quarter of 2015, and in the U.S. in August 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sales082015US_455-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sales082015US-455">
        [455]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The XC90 T8 has an EPA rated all-electric range of 14 mi (23 km), with some gasoline consumption (0.1 gal/100 mi).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VolvoXC90T8_219-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-VolvoXC90T8-219">
        [219]
       </a>
      </sup>
      According to Volvo, sales of the plug-in variant represent 20% of Volvo XC90 global sales by mid-March 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456">
       <a href="#cite_note-456">
        [456]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyundai_Sonata_PHEV" title="Hyundai Sonata PHEV">
       Hyundai Sonata PHEV
      </a>
      was released in selected markets the United States in November 2015. The Sonata has an all-electric range of 27 mi (43 km).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457">
       <a href="#cite_note-457">
        [457]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The first units of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_GLC_350_e" title="Mercedes-Benz GLC 350 e">
       Mercedes-Benz GLC 350 e
      </a>
      were registered in Germany the second quarter of 2016. The GLC 350e has an all-electric range of 31 km (19 mi)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458">
       <a href="#cite_note-458">
        [458]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459">
       <a href="#cite_note-459">
        [459]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The first units of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_GLE_550e" title="Mercedes-Benz GLE 550e">
       Mercedes-Benz GLE 550e
      </a>
      were delivered in the American market in June 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460">
       <a href="#cite_note-460">
        [460]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The GLE 550e has an all-electric range of 12 km (7.5 mi)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461">
       <a href="#cite_note-461">
        [461]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Retail sales of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_740e_iPerformance" title="BMW 740e iPerformance">
       BMW 740e iPerformance
      </a>
      began in Germany in July 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-740eiPrice_462-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-740eiPrice-462">
        [462]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Deliveries in China began in September 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463">
       <a href="#cite_note-463">
        [463]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The 740e has an all-electric range of 14 mi (23 km)
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BMW740e_215-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-BMW740e-215">
        [215]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <dl>
      <dt>
       Conversions
      </dt>
     </dl>
     <p>
      Before the launch of mass production plug-in hybrids,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aftermarket_kit" title="Aftermarket kit">
       conversion kits
      </a>
      and services were available in the United States to convert production model
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
       hybrid electric vehicles
      </a>
      to plug-ins.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYTXH_147-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYTXH-147">
        [147]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464">
       <a href="#cite_note-464">
        [464]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The regular
      <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius" title="Toyota Prius">
       Toyota Prius
      </a>
      has been commercially converted, using these aftermarket kits and
      <a href="/wiki/Tax_incentive" title="Tax incentive">
       tax incentives
      </a>
      , to a plug-in hybrid by
      <a href="/wiki/CalCars" title="CalCars">
       CalCars
      </a>
      and a number of third-party companies.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465">
       <a href="#cite_note-465">
        [465]
       </a>
      </sup>
      On a smaller scale, PHEVs have been sold as commercial passenger
      <a href="/wiki/Van" title="Van">
       vans
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-uvett_466-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-uvett-466">
        [466]
       </a>
      </sup>
      utility
      <a href="/wiki/Truck" title="Truck">
       trucks
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467">
       <a href="#cite_note-467">
        [467]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468">
       <a href="#cite_note-468">
        [468]
       </a>
      </sup>
      general and school
      <a href="/wiki/Bus" title="Bus">
       buses
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469">
       <a href="#cite_note-469">
        [469]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470">
       <a href="#cite_note-470">
        [470]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a href="/wiki/Motorcycle" title="Motorcycle">
       motorcycles
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Scooter_(motorcycle)" title="Scooter (motorcycle)">
       scooters
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-471">
       <a href="#cite_note-471">
        [471]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and military vehicles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472">
       <a href="#cite_note-472">
        [472]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hybrid_Electric_Vehicle_Technologies,_Inc" title="Hybrid Electric Vehicle Technologies, Inc">
       Hybrid Electric Vehicle Technologies, Inc
      </a>
      converts diesel buses to plug-in hybrids, under contract for the
      <a href="/wiki/Chicago_Transit_Authority" title="Chicago Transit Authority">
       Chicago Transit Authority
      </a>
      .
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Fisher_Coachworks" title="Fisher Coachworks">
       Fisher Coachworks
      </a>
      is developing a plug-in hybrid, the Fisher GTB-40, which is expected to get about twice the mileage of a regular
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_bus" title="Hybrid electric bus">
       hybrid electric bus
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473">
       <a href="#cite_note-473">
        [473]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <div style="clear:both;">
     </div>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Sales_and_main_markets">
       Sales and main markets
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Sales and main markets">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Overview">
       Overview
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Overview">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      As of December 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the global stock of highway-capable plug-in hybrid electric cars totaled 517,100 units, out of total cumulative global sales of 1.257 million light-duty
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
      (41.1%). The global ratio between all-electrics (BEVs) and plug-in hybrids (PHEVs) has consistently been 60:40 between 2014 and the first half of 2016, mainly due to the large all-electric market in China. In the U.S. and Europe, the ratio is approaching a 50:50 split.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474">
       <a href="#cite_note-474">
        [474]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="By_country">
       By country
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: By country">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="thumb tright">
      <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
       <a class="image" href="/wiki/File:PEV_Registrations_Netherlands_2010_2013.png">
        <img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="772" data-file-width="964" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/PEV_Registrations_Netherlands_2010_2013.png/300px-PEV_Registrations_Netherlands_2010_2013.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/PEV_Registrations_Netherlands_2010_2013.png/450px-PEV_Registrations_Netherlands_2010_2013.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/PEV_Registrations_Netherlands_2010_2013.png/600px-PEV_Registrations_Netherlands_2010_2013.png 2x" width="300"/>
       </a>
       <div class="thumbcaption">
        <div class="magnify">
         <a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:PEV_Registrations_Netherlands_2010_2013.png" title="Enlarge">
         </a>
        </div>
        Annual registration of highway-capable plug-in electric vehicles in the Netherlands between 2010 and 2015. Plug-in hybrids had an 84.4% market share of the Dutch plug-in electric passenger car segment, the highest share of any country in the world.
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether2012_2014_475-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Nether2012_2014-475">
          [475]
         </a>
        </sup>
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether2011_13_476-0">
         <a href="#cite_note-Nether2011_13-476">
          [476]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </div>
      </div>
     </div>
     <p>
      Global sales of plug-in hybrids grew from over 300 units in 2010 to almost 9,000 in 2011, jumped to over 60,000 in 2012, and reached almost 222,000 in 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlook2016_19-3">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlook2016-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of December 2015
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the United States is the world's largest plug-in hybrid car market with a stock of 193,770 units, followed by China with 86,580 vehicles, the Netherlands with 78,160, Japan with 55,470 units, and the UK with 28,250.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlook2016_19-4">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlook2016-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      More than 122,000 light-duty plug-in hybrids were sold during the first half of 2016,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlook2016_19-5">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlook2016-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global1H2016_477-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Global1H2016-477">
        [477]
       </a>
      </sup>
      raising the global stock to about 640,000 highway legal plug-in hybrid electric cars, out of total global sales of over 1.5 million light-duty
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_car" title="Plug-in electric car">
       plug-in electric cars
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlook2016_19-6">
       <a href="#cite_note-Outlook2016-19">
        [19]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global1H2016_477-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Global1H2016-477">
        [477]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global1.5mi_478-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Global1.5mi-478">
        [478]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The Netherlands, Sweden, the UK, and the United States have the largest shares of plug-in hybrid sales as percentage of total plug-in electric passenger vehicle sales. The Netherlands has the world's largest share of plug-in hybrids among its plug-in electric passenger car stock, with 83,686 plug-in hybrids registered at the end of August 2016, out of 95,088 plug-in electric cars, representing an 88.0% share of the Dutch plug-in car stock.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether082016_479-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nether082016-479">
        [479]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Sweden ranks next with 16,978 plug-in hybrid cars sold between 2011 and August 2016, representing 71.7% of total plug-in electric passenger car sales registrations.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2012_374-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2012-374">
        [374]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2013_379-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2013-379">
        [379]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SwedenSales2014_380-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-SwedenSales2014-380">
        [380]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweden2014_2015_381-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sweden2014_2015-381">
        [381]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweden082016_480-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-Sweden082016-480">
        [480]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Plug-in hybrid registrations in the UK between up to August 2016 totaled 45,130 units representing 61.6% of total plug-in car registrations since 2011.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK2012_2013_481-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UK2012_2013-481">
        [481]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK2014_482-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UK2014-482">
        [482]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK2015_483-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UK2015-483">
        [483]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK082016_484-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-UK082016-484">
        [484]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In the United States, plug-in hybrids represent 47.2% of the 506,450 plug-in electric cars sold between 2008 and August 2016.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-US500k_485-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-US500k-485">
        [485]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In November 2013 the Netherlands became the first country where a plug-in hybrid topped the monthly ranking of new car sales. During November sales were led by the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Outlander_P-HEV" title="Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV">
       Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV
      </a>
      with 2,736 units, capturing a market share of 6.8% of new passenger cars sold that month.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NEDrecord1_398-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NEDrecord1-398">
        [398]
       </a>
      </sup>
      Again in December 2013 the Outlander P-HEV ranked as the top selling new car in the country with 4,976 units, representing a 12.6% market share of new car sales.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NEDrecord2_399-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-NEDrecord2-399">
        [399]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486">
       <a href="#cite_note-486">
        [486]
       </a>
      </sup>
      These record sales allowed the Netherlands to become the second country, after Norway, where plug-in electric cars have topped the monthly ranking of new car sales.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NEDrecord1_398-2">
       <a href="#cite_note-NEDrecord1-398">
        [398]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487">
       <a href="#cite_note-487">
        [487]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of December 2013
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , the Netherlands was the country with highest plug-in hybrid market concentration, with 1.45 vehicles registered per 1,000 people. Most of the growth of the Dutch plug-in hybrid stock took place in 2013, with 20,164 units sold that year representing a rate of growth of 365% from 2012.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Top6Global2013_352-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Top6Global2013-352">
        [352]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether2011_13_476-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nether2011_13-476">
        [476]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The dominance of plug-in hybrids in the Netherlands is reflected by the fact that, since their inception in 2011 up until August 2016, four out of the top five registered plug-in electric models are plug-in hybrids. As of 31 August 2016
      <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
       <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
        [update]
       </a>
      </sup>
      , among all plug-in passenger car registered in the Netherlands, the Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV leads registrations (24,729), followed by the Volvo V60 Plug-in Hybrid (14,846), the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf_GTE" title="Volkswagen Golf GTE">
       Volkswagen Golf GTE
      </a>
      (9,668), the
      <a href="/wiki/Tesla_Model_S" title="Tesla Model S">
       Tesla Model S
      </a>
      all-electric car (5,391), and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Audi_A3_Sportback_e-tron" title="Audi A3 Sportback e-tron">
       Audi A3 Sportback e-tron
      </a>
      (5,015).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nether082016_479-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Nether082016-479">
        [479]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The following table presents the top ranking countries according to its plug-in hybrid segment market share of total new car sales in 2013:
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto">
      <tr>
       <th align="center" colspan="6" style="background-color: #ffdead;">
        Top 10 countries by plug-in hybrid market share
        <br/>
        of new car sales in 2013
        <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488">
         <a href="#cite_note-488">
          [488]
         </a>
        </sup>
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th style="background:#ffdead;">
        Ranking
       </th>
       <th style="background:#ffdead;">
        Country
       </th>
       <th style="background:#ffdead;">
        PHEV
        <br/>
        market
        <br/>
        share
        <sup>
         (1)
        </sup>
        <br/>
        (%)
       </th>
       <th style="background:#ffdead;">
        Ranking
       </th>
       <th style="background:#ffdead;">
        Country
       </th>
       <th style="background:#ffdead;">
        PHEV
        <br/>
        market
        <br/>
        share
        <sup>
         (1)
        </sup>
        <br/>
        (%)
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr align="center">
       <td>
        1
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg/45px-Flag_of_the_Netherlands.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">
         Netherlands
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        4.72%
       </td>
       <td>
        6
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="500" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Iceland.svg/21px-Flag_of_Iceland.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Iceland.svg/32px-Flag_of_Iceland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Flag_of_Iceland.svg/42px-Flag_of_Iceland.svg.png 2x" width="21"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Iceland" title="Iceland">
         Iceland
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        0.25%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr align="center">
       <td>
        2
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1600" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/35px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/4c/Flag_of_Sweden.svg/46px-Flag_of_Sweden.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
         Sweden
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        0.41%
       </td>
       <td>
        7
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1100" data-file-width="1800" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_Finland.svg/23px-Flag_of_Finland.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_Finland.svg/35px-Flag_of_Finland.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Flag_of_Finland.svg/46px-Flag_of_Finland.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Finland" title="Finland">
         Finland
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        0.13%
       </td>
      </tr>
      <tr align="center">
       <td>
        3
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/9e/Flag_of_Japan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Japan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">
         Japan
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        0.40%
       </td>
       <td>
        8
       </td>
       <td align="left">
        <span class="flagicon">
         <img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom.svg.png 2x" width="23"/>
        </span>
        <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">
         United Kingdom
        </a>
       </td>
       <td>
        0.05%

     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="By_model">
       By model
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: By model">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
     <p>
      The following table presents the top selling plug-in hybrid models with global sales of around or over 15,000 units since the introduction of the first modern production plug-in hybrid vehicle in December 2008, and summarizes sales in the top selling countries for each model through December 2015:
     </p>
     <table class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto">
      <tr>
       <th colspan="6" style="text-align:center; background:#abcdef;">
        Global sales of top selling highway-capable plug-in hybrids and top markets by country or region
        <br/>
        between December 2008 and December 2015
       </th>
      </tr>
      <tr>
       <th rowspan="2" style="background:#ABCDEF;">
        Model/
        <br/>

       <th rowspan="2" style="background:#abcdef;">
        Market
        <br/>
        launch
       </th>
       <th rowspan="2" style="background:#abcdef;">
        Global sales
       </th>
       <th colspan="3" style="background:#abcdef;">
        Top selling markets
       </th>
      </tr>

     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Future_production">
       Future production
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Future production">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Further information:
      <a href="/wiki/List_of_modern_production_plug-in_electric_vehicles" title="List of modern production plug-in electric vehicles">
       List of modern production plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Plug-in vehicles that were developed only for demonstration programs include the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ford_Escape_Hybrid#Plug-in_hybrid" title="Ford Escape Hybrid">
       Ford Escape Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volvo_V70_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Volvo V70 Plug-in Hybrid">
       Volvo V70 Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Suzuki_Swift#Plug-in_vehicles" title="Suzuki Swift">
       Suzuki Swift Plug-in
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Audi_A1_e-tron" title="Audi A1 e-tron">
       Audi A1 e-tron
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dodge_Ram_1500_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Dodge Ram 1500 Plug-in Hybrid">
       Dodge Ram 1500 Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Volkswagen_Golf_Variant_Twin_Drive" title="Volkswagen Golf Variant Twin Drive">
       Volkswagen Golf Variant Twin Drive
      </a>
      .
     </p>
     <p>
      PHEVs scheduled for market launch between in 2016 and 2018 are the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hyundai_Ioniq_Plug-in" title="Hyundai Ioniq Plug-in">
       Hyundai Ioniq Plug-in
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Toyota_Prius_Prime" title="Toyota Prius Prime">
       Toyota Prius Prime
      </a>
      (second generation Prius PHEV),
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cadillac_CT6_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Cadillac CT6 Plug-in Hybrid">
       Cadillac CT6 Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chrysler_Pacifica_Hybrid" title="Chrysler Pacifica Hybrid">
       Chrysler Pacifica Hybrid
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Audi_Q7_PHEV" title="Audi Q7 PHEV">
       Audi Q7 PHEV
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_E-Class" title="Mercedes-Benz E-Class">
       Mercedes-Benz E 350e Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      ,
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMW_530e_iPerformance" title="BMW 530e iPerformance">
       BMW 530e iPerformance
      </a>
      , and
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Honda_Clarity_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Honda Clarity Plug-in Hybrid">
       Honda Clarity Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525">
       <a href="#cite_note-525">
        [525]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526">
       <a href="#cite_note-526">
        [526]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527">
       <a href="#cite_note-527">
        [527]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528">
       <a href="#cite_note-528">
        [528]
       </a>
      </sup>
      In total,
      <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">
       Mercedes-Benz
      </a>
      plans to introduce 10 new plug-in hybrid models by 2017.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MBphevs_107-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-MBphevs-107">
        [107]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_ASX_Plug-in_Hybrid" title="Mitsubishi ASX Plug-in Hybrid">
       Mitsubishi ASX Plug-in Hybrid
      </a>
      is scheduled for market launch in Europe and other markets in 2017.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529">
       <a href="#cite_note-529">
        [529]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Government_support_and_public_deployment">
       Government support and public deployment
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Government support and public deployment">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Subsidies_and_economic_incentives">
       Subsidies and economic incentives
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Subsidies and economic incentives">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles" title="Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles">
       Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Several countries have established
      <a href="/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles" title="Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles">
       grants and tax credits
      </a>
      for the purchase of new
      <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle" title="Plug-in electric vehicle">
       plug-in electric vehicles
      </a>
      (PEVs) including plug-in hybrid electric vehicles, and usually the economic incentive depends on battery size. The U.S. offers a
      <a href="/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#United_States" title="Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles">
       federal income tax credit
      </a>
      up to
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$7,500
      </span>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IRS2009_530-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-IRS2009-530">
        [530]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and several states have additional incentives.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PluginAm_531-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-PluginAm-531">
        [531]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The UK offers a
      <a href="/wiki/Government_incentives_for_plug-in_electric_vehicles#United_Kingdom" title="Government incentives for plug-in electric vehicles">
       Plug-in Car Grant
      </a>
      up to a maximum of
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       GB£5,000
      </span>
      (
      <span style="white-space: nowrap">
       US$7,600
      </span>
      ).
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532">
       <a href="#cite_note-532">
        [532]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533">
       <a href="#cite_note-533">
        [533]
       </a>
      </sup>
      As of April 2011, 15 of the 27
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Union_member_states" title="European Union member states">
       European Union member states
      </a>
      provide tax incentives for electrically chargeable vehicles, which includes all
      <a href="/wiki/Western_Europe" title="Western Europe">
       Western European
      </a>
      countries plus the
      <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">
       Czech Republic
      </a>
      and
      <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">
       Romania
      </a>
      . Also 17 countries levy
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions" title="Greenhouse gas emissions">
       carbon dioxide
      </a>
      related taxes on passenger cars as a disincentive. The incentives consist of tax reductions and exemptions, as well as of bonus payments for buyers of all-electric and plug-in hybrid vehicles,
      <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric_vehicle" title="Hybrid electric vehicle">
       hybrid vehicles
      </a>
      , and some
      <a href="/wiki/Alternative_fuel_vehicle" title="Alternative fuel vehicle">
       alternative fuel vehicles
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT072911_534-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-NYT072911-534">
        [534]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ACEA2_535-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ACEA2-535">
        [535]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h4>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Other_government_support">
       Other government support
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Other government support">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h4>
     <dl>
      <dt>
       United States
      </dt>
     </dl>
     <p>
      Incentives for the development of PHEVs are included in the
      <a href="/wiki/Energy_Independence_and_Security_Act_of_2007" title="Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007">
       Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536">
       <a href="#cite_note-536">
        [536]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Energy_Improvement_and_Extension_Act_of_2008" title="Energy Improvement and Extension Act of 2008">
       Energy Improvement and Extension Act of 2008
      </a>
      , signed into law on October 3, 2008, grants a tax credits for the purchase of PHEVs. President
      <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
       Barack Obama
      </a>
      's
      <a href="/wiki/New_Energy_for_America" title="New Energy for America">
       New Energy for America
      </a>
      calls for deployment of 1 million plug-in hybrid vehicles by 2015,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537">
       <a href="#cite_note-537">
        [537]
       </a>
      </sup>
      and on March 19, 2009, he announced programs directing $2.4 billion to electric vehicle development.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-538">
       <a href="#cite_note-538">
        [538]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      The
      <a href="/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act_of_2009" title="American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009">
       American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009
      </a>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539">
       <a href="#cite_note-539">
        [539]
       </a>
      </sup>
      modifies the tax credits, including a new one for plug-in electric drive
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conversion_kit" title="Conversion kit">
       conversion kits
      </a>
      and for 2 or 3 wheel vehicles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540">
       <a href="#cite_note-540">
        [540]
       </a>
      </sup>
      The ultimate total included in the Act that is going to PHEVs is over $6 billion.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541">
       <a href="#cite_note-541">
        [541]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      In March 2009, as part of the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/American_Recovery_and_Reinvestment_Act" title="American Recovery and Reinvestment Act">
       American Recovery and Reinvestment Act
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Department_of_Energy" title="US Department of Energy">
       US Department of Energy
      </a>
      announced the release of two competitive solicitations for up to $2 billion in federal funding for competitively awarded cost-shared agreements for manufacturing of advanced batteries and related drive components as well as up to $400 million for
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transportation_electrification" title="Transportation electrification">
       transportation electrification
      </a>
      demonstration and deployment projects. This announcement will also help meet the President
      <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">
       Barack Obama
      </a>
      's goal of putting one million plug-in hybrid vehicles on the road by 2015.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542">
       <a href="#cite_note-542">
        [542]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Public deployments also include:
     </p>
     <ul>
      <li>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USDOE" title="USDOE">
        USDOE
       </a>
       's
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/FreedomCAR" title="FreedomCAR">
        FreedomCAR
       </a>
       .
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/US_Department_of_Energy" title="US Department of Energy">
        US Department of Energy
       </a>
       announced it would dole out $30 million in funding to three companies over three years to further the development of plug-in hybrids
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-543">
        <a href="#cite_note-543">
         [543]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/USDOE" title="USDOE">
        USDOE
       </a>
       announced the selection of Navistar Corporation for a cost-shared award of up to $10 million to develop, test, and deploy plug-in hybrid electric (PHEV) school buses.
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544">
        <a href="#cite_note-544">
         [544]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       DOE and
       <a href="/wiki/Sweden" title="Sweden">
        Sweden
       </a>
       have a
       <a href="/wiki/Memorandum_of_understanding" title="Memorandum of understanding">
        MOU
       </a>
       to advance market integration of plug-in hybrid vehicles
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545">
        <a href="#cite_note-545">
         [545]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PHEV_Research_Center" title="PHEV Research Center">
        PHEV Research Center
       </a>
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/San_Francisco" title="San Francisco">
        San Francisco
       </a>
       Mayor
       <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Newsom" title="Gavin Newsom">
        Gavin Newsom
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/San_Jose,_California" title="San Jose, California">
        San Jose
       </a>
       Mayor
       <a href="/wiki/Chuck_Reed" title="Chuck Reed">
        Chuck Reed
       </a>
       and
       <a href="/wiki/Oakland,_California" title="Oakland, California">
        Oakland, California
       </a>
       Mayor
       <a href="/wiki/Ron_Dellums" title="Ron Dellums">
        Ron Dellums
       </a>
       announced a nine-step policy plan for transforming the Bay Area into the "Electric Vehicle (EV) Capital of the U.S."
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sfgov.org_546-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-sfgov.org-546">
         [546]
        </a>
       </sup>
       and of the world
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-calcars1_547-0">
        <a href="#cite_note-calcars1-547">
         [547]
        </a>
       </sup>
       There are partnerships with
       <a href="/wiki/Coulomb" title="Coulomb">
        Coulomb
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/Better_Place" title="Better Place">
        Better Place
       </a>
       and others are also advancing. The first charging stations went up in San Jose
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-calcars1_547-1">
        <a href="#cite_note-calcars1-547">
         [547]
        </a>
       </sup>
       (more information in
       <a href="/wiki/Plug-in_hybrids_in_California" title="Plug-in hybrids in California">
        Plug-in hybrids in California
       </a>
       ).
      </li>
      <li>
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Washington_(U.S._state)" title="Washington (U.S. state)">
        Washington State
       </a>
       PHEV Pilot Project
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548">
        <a href="#cite_note-548">
         [548]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
      <li>
       Texas Governor
       <a href="/wiki/Rick_Perry" title="Rick Perry">
        Rick Perry
       </a>
       's proposal for a state $5,000 tax credit for PHEVs in "non-attainment" communities
      </li>
      <li>
       <a href="/wiki/Seattle" title="Seattle">
        Seattle
       </a>
       , that includes City's public fleet converted vehicles, the
       <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Seattle" title="Port of Seattle">
        Port of Seattle
       </a>
       ,
       <a href="/wiki/King_County,_Washington" title="King County, Washington">
        King County
       </a>
       and the
       <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Puget_Sound_Clean_Air_Agency" title="Puget Sound Clean Air Agency">
        Puget Sound Clean Air Agency
       </a>
       <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549">
        <a href="#cite_note-549">
         [549]
        </a>
       </sup>
      </li>
     </ul>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">
       GM
      </a>
      's roadmap for plug-in ready communities includes: consumer incentives to make this early technology more affordable; public and workplace charging infrastructure; consumer-friendly electricity rates and renewable electricity options; government and corporate vehicle purchases; supportive permitting and codes for vehicle charging; and other incentives such as
      <a href="/wiki/High-occupancy_vehicle_lane" title="High-occupancy vehicle lane">
       high-occupancy-vehicle (HOV) lanes
      </a>
      access
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550">
       <a href="#cite_note-550">
        [550]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <dl>
      <dt>
       European Union
      </dt>
     </dl>
     <p>
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electrification_of_transport" title="Electrification of transport">
       Electrification of transport
      </a>
      (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electromobility" title="Electromobility">
       electromobility
      </a>
      ) is a priority in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Union_Research_Programme" title="European Union Research Programme">
       European Union Research Programme
      </a>
      . It also figures prominently in the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/European_Economic_Recovery_Plan" title="European Economic Recovery Plan">
       European Economic Recovery Plan
      </a>
      presented November 2008, in the frame of the Green Car Initiative.
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Directorate-General_for_Mobility_and_Transport_(European_Commission)" title="Directorate-General for Mobility and Transport (European Commission)">
       DG TREN
      </a>
      will support a large European "electromobility" project on electric vehicles and related infrastructure with a total budget of around €50 million as part of the Green Car Initiative.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551">
       <a href="#cite_note-551">
        [551]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="Supportive_organizations">
       Supportive organizations
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=43" title="Edit section: Supportive organizations">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <p>
      Organizations that support plug-in hybrids include the
      <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Fund_for_Nature" title="World Wide Fund for Nature">
       World Wide Fund for Nature
      </a>
      , its International Director General James Leape remarked, "the cars of the future ... should, increasingly, be powered by electricity."
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552">
       <a href="#cite_note-552">
        [552]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Also
      <a href="/wiki/National_Wildlife_Federation" title="National Wildlife Federation">
       National Wildlife Federation
      </a>
      has done a strong
      <a href="/wiki/Testimonial" title="Testimonial">
       endorsement
      </a>
      of PHEVs.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553">
       <a href="#cite_note-553">
        [553]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      <a href="/wiki/CalCars" title="CalCars">
       CalCars
      </a>
      (with their
      <a class="external text" href="http://www.calcars.org/news-archive.html" rel="nofollow">
       PHEV news service
      </a>
      and
      <a class="external text" href="http://www.calcars.org/carmakers.html" rel="nofollow">
       "What car makers are saying about PHEVs"
      </a>
      ) is dedicated only to the PHEV and has proposed a Prepayment Plan, where buyers would pay $1,000 to reserve a plug-in car and the federal government would match each payment with $9,000, all of which would go to carmakers.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554">
       <a href="#cite_note-554">
        [554]
       </a>
      </sup>
      CalCars is also promoting public funds for conversion of internal combustion engines to plug-in vehicles.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555">
       <a href="#cite_note-555">
        [555]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      Other supportive organizations are
      <a href="/wiki/Plug_In_America" title="Plug In America">
       Plug In America
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alliance_for_Climate_Protection" title="Alliance for Climate Protection">
       Alliance for Climate Protection
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Friends_of_the_Earth" title="Friends of the Earth">
       Friends of the Earth
      </a>
      , the
      <a href="/wiki/Rainforest_Action_Network" title="Rainforest Action Network">
       Rainforest Action Network
      </a>
      ,
      <a href="/wiki/Rocky_Mountain_Institute" title="Rocky Mountain Institute">
       Rocky Mountain Institute
      </a>
      (Project Get Ready),
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556">
       <a href="#cite_note-556">
        [556]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the San Francisco
      <a href="/wiki/Bay_Area_Council" title="Bay Area Council">
       Bay Area Council
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sfgov.org_546-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-sfgov.org-546">
        [546]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Apollo_Alliance" title="Apollo Alliance">
       Apollo Alliance
      </a>
      , the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Set_America_Free_Coalition" title="Set America Free Coalition">
       Set America Free Coalition
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-557">
       <a href="#cite_note-557">
        [557]
       </a>
      </sup>
      the
      <a href="/wiki/Silicon_Valley_Leadership_Group" title="Silicon Valley Leadership Group">
       Silicon Valley Leadership Group
      </a>
      , and the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plug-in_Hybrid_Electric_School_Bus_Project" title="Plug-in Hybrid Electric School Bus Project">
       Plug-in Hybrid Electric School Bus Project
      </a>
      ,
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558">
       <a href="#cite_note-558">
        [558]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <p>
      FPL and Duke Energy has said that by 2020 all new purchases of fleet vehicles will be plug-in hybrid or all-electric.
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559">
       <a href="#cite_note-559">
        [559]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>
     <h3>
      <span class="mw-headline" id="NiMH_battery_patent_encumbrance">
       NiMH battery patent encumbrance
      </span>
      <span class="mw-editsection">
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        [
       </span>
       <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit&amp;section=44" title="Edit section: NiMH battery patent encumbrance">
        edit
       </a>
       <span class="mw-editsection-bracket">
        ]
       </span>
      </span>
     </h3>
     <div class="hatnote" role="note">
      Main article:
      <a href="/wiki/Patent_encumbrance_of_large_automotive_NiMH_batteries" title="Patent encumbrance of large automotive NiMH batteries">
       Patent encumbrance of large automotive NiMH batteries
      </a>
     </div>
     <p>
      Some battery formats and chemistries (
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nickel%E2%80%93metal_hydride_batteries" title="Nickel–metal hydride batteries">
       nickel–metal hydride batteries
      </a>
      ) suitable for use in PHEVs are tightly patented and were not licensed for use by PHEV manufacturers, thereby slowed the development of
      <a href="/wiki/Electric_car" title="Electric car">
       electric cars
      </a>
      and PHEVs before the
      <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_Oil_Crisis" title="2008 Oil Crisis">
       2008 Oil Crisis
      </a>
      .
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boschert06_7-1">
       <a href="#cite_note-Boschert06-7">
        [7]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TheCarThatCould_560-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-TheCarThatCould-560">
        [560]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ocweekly20030515_561-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ocweekly20030515-561">
        [561]
       </a>
      </sup>
      <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ovshinsky20081014_562-0">
       <a href="#cite_note-ovshinsky20081014-562">
        [562]
       </a>
      </sup>
     </p>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.atitle=Tesla+Model+S+Was+World%99s+Best-Selling+Plug-in+Car+in+2015&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeff&amp;rft.aulast=Cobb&amp;rft.date=2016-01-12&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hybridcars.com%2Ftesla-model-s-was-worlds-best-selling-plug-in-car-in-2015%2F&amp;rft.jtitle=HybridCars.com&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <i>
          The Tesla Model S was the top selling plug-in electric car in 2015, followed by the Nissan Leaf and the Mitsubishi Outlander P-HEV. About 106,000 units of the Volt/Ampera family have been sold worldwide between December 2010 and December 2015.
         </i>
        </span>

          <span style="display:none;">

       <li id="cite_note-TopPEV062016-18">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-TopPEV062016_18-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>

          <sup>

            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          Cobb, Jeff (2016-08-01).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.hybridcars.com/renault-zoe-and-bmw-i3-join-the-50000-sales-club/" rel="nofollow">
           "Renault Zoe and BMW i3 Join The 50,000 Sales Club"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           HybridCars.com
          </i>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2016-08-02
           </span>
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.atitle=Renault+Zoe+and+BMW+i3+Join+The+50%2C000+Sales+Club&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeff&amp;rft.aulast=Cobb&amp;rft.date=2016-08-01&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hybridcars.com%2Frenault-zoe-and-bmw-i3-join-the-50000-sales-club%2F&amp;rft.jtitle=HybridCars.com&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <i>
          As of June 2016
          <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
            [update]
           </a>
          </sup>
          , cumulative global sales of the top selling plug-in electric cars were led by the Nissan Leaf (about 225,000), Tesla Model S (over 129,000), Votl/Ampera family (over 117,000), Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV (about 107,000), Toyota Prius PHV (over 75,000), BYD Qin (56,191), Renault Zoe (51,193), and BMW i3 (almost 50,000).
         </i>
        </span>
       </li>

          </span>

          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2016-08-31
           </span>
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.au=International+Energy+Agency+%28IEA%29%2C+Clean+Energy+Ministerial%2C+and+Electric+Vehicles+Initiative+%28EVI%29&amp;rft.btitle=Global+EV+Outlook+2016%3A+Beyond+one+million+electric+cars&amp;rft.date=2016-05&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.iea.org%2Fpublications%2Ffreepublications%2Fpublication%2FGlobal_EV_Outlook_2016.pdf&amp;rft.pub=IEA+Publications&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^

          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>

       <li id="cite_note-TopSix2015-108">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-TopSix2015_108-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation news">
          Cobb, Jeff (2016-01-18).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.hybridcars.com/top-six-plug-in-vehicle-adopting-countries-2015/" rel="nofollow">
           "Top Six Plug-in Vehicle Adopting Countries – 2015"
          </a>
          .
          <i>
           HybridCars.com
          </i>
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2016-02-12
           </span>
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.atitle=Top+Six+Plug-in+Vehicle+Adopting+Countries+%93+2015&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeff&amp;rft.aulast=Cobb&amp;rft.date=2016-01-18&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hybridcars.com%2Ftop-six-plug-in-vehicle-adopting-countries-2015%2F&amp;rft.jtitle=HybridCars.com&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <i>
          About 520,000 highway legal light-duty plug-in electric vehicles were sold worlwide in 2015, with cumulative global sales reaching 1,235,000.
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.hybridcars.com/one-million-global-plug-in-sales-milestone-reached/" rel="nofollow">
           Plug-in hybrids represent about 40% of global plug-in electric vehicle sales
          </a>
          .
         </i>
        </span>
       </li>

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.atitle=Mitsubishi+Sells+100%2C000th+Outlander+PHEV&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeff&amp;rft.aulast=Cobb&amp;rft.date=2016-05-03&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.hybridcars.com%2Fmitsubishi-sells-100000th-outlander-phev%2F&amp;rft.jtitle=HybridCars.com&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <i>
          As of March 2016
          <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
            [update]
           </a>
          </sup>
          , the world's top selling plug-in electric cars are the Nissan Leaf (over 218,000), Tesla Model S (about 120,000), Chevrolet Volt and Ampera variants (over 110,000), Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV (over 100,000), and Toyota Prius Plug-in Hybrid (75,000). All figures cumulative global sales since market launch.
         </i>
        </span>
       </li>
       <li id="cite_note-OutlanderPHEV100K-120">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         ^
         <a href="#cite_ref-OutlanderPHEV100K_120-0">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             a
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-OutlanderPHEV100K_120-1">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             b
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
         <a href="#cite_ref-OutlanderPHEV100K_120-2">
          <sup>
           <i>
            <b>
             c
            </b>
           </i>
          </sup>
         </a>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation pressrelease">
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.mitsubishi-matters.co.uk/2016/05/19/global-mitsubishi-outlander-phev-sales-pass-100000-mark/" rel="nofollow">
           "Global Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV Sales Pass the 100,000 Mark"
          </a>
          (Press release). UK: Mitsubishi Motors UK. 2016-05-19
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2016-05-22
           </span>
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.btitle=Global+Mitsubishi+Outlander+PHEV+Sales+Pass+the+100%2C000+Mark&amp;rft.date=2016-05-19&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mitsubishi-matters.co.uk%2F2016%2F05%2F19%2Fglobal-mitsubishi-outlander-phev-sales-pass-100000-mark%2F&amp;rft.place=UK&amp;rft.pub=Mitsubishi+Motors+UK&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <i>
          As of March 2016
          <sup class="plainlinks noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;">
           <a class="external text" href="//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Plug-in_hybrid&amp;action=edit">
            [update]
           </a>
          </sup>
          , a total of 65,529 units have been sold in Europe (21,052 in the UK and 44,477 in the rest of Europe), 33,730 in Japan, 2,015 in Australia and 259 in the rest of the world, for a total of 101,533 units sold worldwide.
         </i>
        </span>
       </li>

          <a class="external text" href="http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/topten.jsp" rel="nofollow">

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.au=U.+S.+Environmental+Protection+Agency+and+U.S.+Department+of+Energy&amp;rft.btitle=Fueleconomy.gov%27s+Top+Fuel+Sippers+%28EPA+Ratings%2C+All+Years%29&amp;rft.date=2015-12-04&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fueleconomy.gov%2Ffeg%2Ftopten.jsp&amp;rft.pub=fueleconomy.gov&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <i>
          Excludes all-electric vehicles. Click on the tab "Top Fuel Sippers (EPA Ratings, All Years)" - The 2013-2014 Chevrolet Volt has a combined fuel economy of 62 mpg-e, while 2016 Volt has a combined fuel economy of 77 mpg-e. The BMW i3 REx has a combined fuel economy of 88 mpg-e
         </i>

       <li id="cite_note-EPAMost082014-197">
        <span class="mw-cite-backlink">
         <b>
          <a href="#cite_ref-EPAMost082014_197-0">
           ^
          </a>
         </b>
        </span>
        <span class="reference-text">
         <cite class="citation web">
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U._S._Environmental_Protection_Agency" title="U. S. Environmental Protection Agency">
           U. S. Environmental Protection Agency
          </a>
          and
          <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Energy" title="U.S. Department of Energy">
           U.S. Department of Energy
          </a>
          (2015-08-14).
          <a class="external text" href="http://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/topten.jsp" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          . fueleconomy.gov
          <span class="reference-accessdate">
           . Retrieved
           <span class="nowrap">
            2015-08-17
           </span>
          </span>
          .
         </cite>
         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.au=U.+S.+Environmental+Protection+Agency+and+U.S.+Department+of+Energy&amp;rft.btitle=Top+Fuel+Sippers+%28EPA+Ratings%2C+All+Years%29&amp;rft.date=2015-08-14&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.fueleconomy.gov%2Ffeg%2Ftopten.jsp&amp;rft.pub=fueleconomy.gov&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">

          <a class="external text" href="http://www.greencarcongress.com/2014/03/20140311-lin.html" rel="nofollow">

        <span class="reference-text">

         <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20071128130530/http://www.epri-reports.org/Volume2Part1R2.pdf" rel="nofollow">

          </a>
          and
          <a href="/wiki/Natural_Resources_Defense_Council" title="Natural Resources Defense Council">

         </i>
         . Retrieved July 21, 2007.

         <span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3APlug-in+hybrid&amp;rft.btitle=USGS+Mineral+Commodities+Summaries+2009&amp;rft.date=2009-01&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fminerals.usgs.gov%2Fminerals%2Fpubs%2Fmcs%2F2009%2Fmcs2009.pdf&amp;rft.pub=U.+S.+Geological+Survey&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook">
          <span style="display:none;">
          </span>
         </span>
         <i>
          See page 95
         </i>
         .
        </span>
       </li>
